text:
Most choices were really great (avoid the chickenparm - awful.) like my crab-stuffed ravioli, over broccoli rabe.  St. Louis Ribs were fall-off-the bone tender.

There is a slight "SYSCO" pre-fab element to the food - but for the most part we love a nice weekend lunch here.  Burgers (patty melts, southwest style) are a solid choice.  Upgrading to Sweet potato fries is a good idea!

Yes, it's expensive.
No, you can;t do your "regular" shopping here but it is terrific for taking kids.

We came for the "No Kid Hungry" cupcake event (for $3 kids could decorate a chocolate or vanilla cupcake) and the kids (both age 9) loved it.

My daughter loves to shop the bulk candy department and there are some unique holiday gift ideas here also.  Look into their cosmetics (Pacifica for CHEAP!) and chocolate bar sections.

No, it's not cheap - but there are some unique items here that I can't get at Whole Foods (aka Whole Paycheck) nor Trader Joe's.

I confess, I am a Sephora and Ulta shopper - I price compare on ebay, also and it pains mne to pay retail after spending YEARS in the spa industry.  Meanwhile, I stock up on Tweezerman, NARS, Lorac, MUFE (Makeup Forever) and other staples at this Center City location.

The ever-changing line up of staff (usually young overly-made up MUAs) is friendly and usually pretty knowledgable about makeup.  Skin care?  Not as much.

Meanwhile, I love Sephora - and have since its creation.
It continues to evolve.

Needed mass quantities of Guac, Pico 'n Chips for a picnic stat.
Qdoba to the rescue - for $21 and change we had plenty for all.

Upon my teen daughter's pleading request, I caved and picked up 2 take out items at the now-dreaded Qdoba in Springfield.

What'd'ya know?  Everything was fresh and great again.  It helped that there was a new (at least new to my eyes) manager and that we cam at 11:50 AM on a Thursday before the lunch hordes had descended.

Steak burrito and Steak burrito bowl (both with Guac) were both great.

I truly hope the "badness" of the past is in the past.
Management and team makes all the difference.  The female team lead (front counter) is friendly and good!  Give her a raise!
Had another lunch here with the 'rents and this time service was great and we had cappucinos (very good ones) along with the soup & salad.

This is the same as the "Falafel Cart" reviews - same guy on 20 & Market.
Line down the block.

You get what you get - and it's usually good - but I like Mama's better,
Meanwhile, people LOVE this cart.

This remains our go-to Rita's and the young teen staff is friendly and polite - in the summer (evenings) the lines can get longer.  We enjoy an occasional custard or "wooder" ice treat here.

Tip:  Ask for the kiddie size to save calories and money.

Benches and tables to sit at outdoors.

I am a huge proponent of food co-ops, locavores, slow foodism, sustainable agriculture and the like - so I was thrilled to visit the medium-sized - very crowded Weaver's Way.

We have very few of these types of food coops in Philly - but when I lived in NYC there were many - in Brooklyn and Manhattan - where you could both shop and participate as a member.

Even though it's not flawless - there is a big space issue - I am so happy to have them here and I will continue to buy my brown eggs, brown rice, and brown bread here when I am in the nabe!

Oh - and they sell locally farmed Christmas trees and greens during the holiday season.

Go Weaver's!!!

I wandered in, as I am new to the area, and ordered take-out (a lunch special - came to 9.95 plus tax).  Next time I will call ahead or maybe dine in.  Took 11 minutes to get the food (was told 15 - so that was great!).

Chicken pad thai was a tad greasy but good and a large portion.  Standard American-Thai loaded with sugar, which I happen to like from time to time.

Tulip dumplings were good but unremarkable.
Thankfully they were steamed and not deep-fried.

I would definitely come back for lunch, but this is still not the greatest Thai food.  Pensylvania - even the great city of Philadelphia still has yet to find me a good thai place.  

The one in Bala is OK (Chang Mai?), and the one in University used to be good.
The Little Thai Market in Reading terminal Market is the best I have gotten.
The 2 pseudo-Thai places in Media both suck.  Sorry, but they do.

So for Suburban Thai?  Thai Orchid is looking like my new place.
The 2 ladies serving were lovely and courteous.
Super easy parking (and you can head to Giant afterward to shop.)

Next time I will do my litmus test of Tom Kha.
See you in about a week!

Well, it's 6 years later and Tokyo Sushi is still here and seems to be larger than I remember it.  I picked up a 3 roll combo from the pre-made case at $12 which have 4 pieces each of tuna (fine), salmon (fine) and Yellowtail (surprisingly very good) with scallions - all in brown rice and rather large pieces.

I am pleased and Shall return now that I am back in this area again.

Seems more like a "real" sushi place now and less like "supermarket" sushi.

Next time I will order some nigiri to order.

My only complaint?  $7 - $9.5 for a sinlge handroll (They call theirs a demaki vs. temaki)???
Way too high.  

All in all very pleased and will return - and soon!

While we still prefer Fellini's in downtown Media (not sure if they are the same owner or not - but the menus are very similar) we had a good experience - especially with Jessica, our helpful, friendly server.

Fellini's offers solid Italian (and lots of pasta) dishes.  Salads and Antipasto are also good here.

Crowded as heck on weekends - we squeaked in at 6:45 PM on a Saturday and somehow lucked out - there was a line to get in minutes later.

Love the Chicken with Eggplant in Aurora sauce (rich and fattening - but so tasty.)
Decaf cappuccino for dessert was spot-on!

As said before - BYOB - can get noisy from drunk and happy customers.
Carbo-load!

I had a very pleasant 4 star experience an Nooddi - but it is really a 3 star kinda place (needs a makeover!).  But - I happened to get there before 6 PM and got the early dinner special which is a great value.

A cup of Tom Kha soup. 2 steamed crab dumplings (delish!) and a generous portion of Chicken or Tofu Pad-See-Yu.

Loved every bite.
And my wallet thanked me.

Great service - place was empty on a Thursday at 5:40 PM.

No, it's not the best Thai ever - but it'll do and I will be back - and likely soon.

3.5 - 4 stars - a very nice Acme as Acme's go.
I run in here on occaision for fried chicken (or grilled) - when it is fresh, and milk and other things.

Convenient location - and I can stop at Gentile's before or afterward.

Food is great - atmosphere is ZERO - you are eating in an open kitchen of a Mexican grocery store. 

The people working here are so kind and the tacos al pastor are authentic and delcious.  The sopes are good but heavy for me - so next time tacos!

Delicious Guacamole and home made Horchata and Jamaica (Sweet!).

I am thrilled to have found this place - and they are gonna need more tables.
It is packed at lunch time.

Delicious!

I have now had lunch here twice (both times I had fresh delicious salads) and I am a fan.  Good service, clean comfortable booths and tables, and a large bar.

French onion soup was a tad too salty for my taste and pasta dishes (at lunch) are close to $20 so I will pass on those - but for salads and burgers (my dad had an amazingly good patty melt) we will be back again and again.

OK, the hot Aussie bartender is still there (Big plus.) but a few things have changed.  3 of us had dinner at Xochitl on sunday night.
We were made to wait until about 7:20 (at the crowded bar) for our 7 PM reservation.  Not a huge deal, since I was intent on ordering Dona Florindas.

Well, they changed the way they make them and now they use apricot infused tequila instead of pineapple infused tquila - but hot bartender made me one old school.  TERRIFIC.

The 3 of us each ordered the Sunday Special - 3 courses plus Guac for the table for $35.00.  It was a ton of food - and a good value.

The table-side guac was top of the line, as usual.  So delicious.  Once we ate it and had our apps (I had a fresh and sublime shrimp cocktail with jicama and mango) we were too full for the entrees.  I enjoyed my skirt steak with unique "Avocado fries".  My friend special ordered a mixed grill and did not like it.  I felt bad for her.

Meanwhile, DH had the pork and enjoyed it.  I never eat pork, but it looked well prepared.

Since I was so full - I ate about 3 bites (yummy, tender, succulent bites) of the steak and had it boxed to go.  We still had dessert coming and I was jonsin' for churros.  Well, they came out burnt.  Such a shame - as we had eaten them twice before.  DH had the chocolate cake which was rich and delectable and came with a Cajeta ice cream.

All 3 of us had the Mexican Hot chocolate - and I like Xochitl's version even  better than the Aztec one at the Naked Chocolate Cafe.  (Nakeds is too spicey for me.)

So it wasn't quite the 5 star experience that we had on the 2 prior visits - but it was still very, very good.  It just kinda feels like (maybe its the economy, maybe it's just a factor of restaurant age) service and food quality are slipping a little.

Don't get sloppy, Xochitl.  We're counting on you for a 5 star visit when we return.

And I will return (not sure about my friend though.).

OK - It's realy a 3 star place but our food and service were so nice on a frigid January night that I will round up to 4 stars.

The place is, indeed, a "hut" - you have to walk around outside to get to the bathrooms and the decor is sparse - but Nikita - our server/cashier - saved the day with her congenial manner.

To top it off my friend and I both loved our huge platters of Oxtail Stews in a rich brown saucewith plantains (not dry - very nice) and rice - fragrant with allspice and studded with beans.

A $5 (ouch) side of roti bread was the perfect accompaniment.

I loved my meal - and will return.

Believe it or not we had an excellent time at cracker barrel  with our party of 5.on a not-to-busy Friday night (5-7 minute wait for a table).  The little one loved her food (fried shrimp) and she and my MIL shopped in the gift shop and bought "Mad Libs" and an old-style box of Cracker Jack.  (The little one had never had cracker jack before and wondered about the prize.)

After a carb and fat loaded meal (not good for the diet at all) we relxzed on rocking chairs out front (for sale) and played checkers.

The staff especially Judi (trainer) in the gift shop and Justin or server were all terrific.

Is this my favorite place?  No way.  But it beats Denny's or Perkins any day and you can get pancakes for dinner!

This is our go-to Rita's - for it's spacious parking lot, clean picnic tables and benches, and sweet teen-aged girls running to show.

Our 8 year old and I both get kiddie sized (ASK)  water ice or custards - and the kiddie portion is PLENTY in my opinion.  I love the coffee custard but is is GONE (forever??) now - so I get chocolate or swirl.

DD often gets lemon, blue raspberry or swedish fish flavored "wooder" ice.

The blendini is fun, too.
And now they have sundaes (unlimited toppings like hot fudge, "jimmies"/Sprinkles, whipped cream and a cherry).  ASK for the kiddie size - it's cheaper, smaller and just as satisfying.

Indulgent and a diet breaker for sure - but a summertime must in PA!

After not coming to the Aston diner in years, our party of 6 had a very nice lunch (specials are a good value and come with soup and dessert) for under $70.  Service by "Barb" was great and we enjoyed the food.

Burgers, grilled cheese, Chicken Caesar salad, Cobb Salad with shrimp (instead of chicken) [$14.95] with mammoth portions (took some home).

Glad things have improved.
We'll return,

Tacos al Pastor - I dream of you...

They are slowly improving the dining area - but still needs work.
meanwhile, for $2.50 a pop I get tacos al pastor - the REAL DEAL and a luscious side of guac (also $2.50).

Pico de gallo here is fresh - but super spicy with jalapeno chunks and raw onion - so bring breath mints.

Horchata is also great.

LOVE IT HERE.  Please open one in Media/Aston!!!

I had a lovely first-ever experience at Fresh Market.
All 4 staffers I spoke with were friendly and helpful.

They carry Stonewall Kitchen Jams and Sauces - so I snagged a $7 jar of swanky peach jam.  I love stonewall - and if I buy it here I don't have to pay shipping.

They also had HINT water on sale for $1 a bottle - so I got 8 bottles.
I also picked up 3 bottles of Australian Water infused with flower essences.  I am a Bach Flower Essences Practitioner so I am curious to see what it tastes like (should just taste like plain water) and if it works.  

They also carry Vosges chocolate bars and other high end goodies.
Produce looked great - albeit pricey and meat case looked good but I doubt I wll buy any.

I liked it here alot and will be back.
It's a little pricey - but it's closer to my house than Whole Paycheck (aka Whole Foods).

Pho, summer rolls, iced coffee, vermicelli, broken rice plates, all the staples in a quick-service format. Mid-priced and great for lunch. Come right when they open at 11:30 to beat the lunch rush.

New digs with a clean restroom. For now.
Old-school (read:  no gas station) Wawa with everything you need.

My faith has been restored.
Stopped in solo tonight out of sheer craving for sushi.

I sat, alone, at the bar and chatted with Alan, Don (sp??) and my lovely server Amanda.  FANTASTIC service - and very good, fresh fish.

I am more of a purist and do not care for gloppy sauces - but the Tuna Tartare (with a bit of chopped mango, avocado and fried shallots mixed in) was perfect.  Fresh tuna - chopped - not minced.

The plate was garnished with at least 4 sauces though.  (All delicious - miso, cilantro oil, mayo, red wine reduction)

3 pieces of yellowtail sashimi (one order) and one temaki (hand roll) and I was stuffed.

I shall return - happily, now!

Love these guys!  The name-sake ravioli is delicious and affordable - usually frozen and many varietys.  Great tortellini, too - meat or cheese (I love the meat).  Take it home and cook it up!


The real deal - straight from sou-philly.  Oh - and they support the Mummers - so go to P&S!

The beauty uber-store.  I really miss the flagship location in New York (it closed) but tnow there are Sephora's popping up all over.  Believe it or not, Sephora has really streamlined their brand selections over the years.  They used to carry TOO MANY brands.  Now it's just about right.

Since I am in the beauty bix and hate paying retail - I usually browse and try products here - but buy elsewhere.  However, I will say that in a pinch I run here for things I really need now - like Caudalie, MUFE (Make Up For Ever) and Ojon Hair Care.

This is like the grocery store for me.  Can't survive without it.

5 stars for the food!  What a fabulous find in a Girard Ave. location.
We enjoyed our dinner here very much!

I had a Pineapple Strawberry Daiquiri (BYO Booze) and some amazingly good ceviche - shrimp and tillapia.

My husband's chicken enpanadas were so good, too (I got a bite!).

For entrees he had a tender and flavorful shredded pork with super-fresh corn tortilla black refried beans and rice. He liked it alot.  I really loved the Eggplant Tower - a great vegetarian (NOT VEGAN - it's overloaded with 2 kinds of cheese) choice served over white rice and a home-made tomato & onion sauce.

Desserts are very well done here, too at $6-$6.50 each we tried the banana crepes and cheesecake bunuelos.

Delicioso! We can't wait to come back (The crab & shrimp enchiladas and Carne Azada are calling to me.)! They also do weekend brunch - which sounds marvelous.

Service by our sweet cambodian server (He's a doll!) was attentive and great.

And a big thanks to Eversave (the groupon knock-off) without whom I never would have tried this place.

A super-great find!

A great place for a quick lunch with a multitude of choices.  The "small" salad is HUGe - and you get to choose your own ingredients.

The have hot pasta and baked potatoes, a few hot entrees and sides each day, subs, hoagies, soups, chili and great sandwiches and wraps.

And the catering a great and cost effective.  Try the STRAWBERRY SHORTCAKE.  (mmn, mnn!)

Also a great spot for breakfast - they do oatmeal well.

Ate here one day at about 2 Pm for a late lunch out of sheer desparation with DH and 9 year old kiddo.  Kiddo bitched and moaned at first b/c she wanted Subway.

She wound up very happy with her basic chicken & cheese quesadilla - no pico.
She also liked the guacamole. And demolished the side of black beans.  (Who knew - kiddo eats beans?)

DH & I each had "the usual" naked burritos (burrito bowls) loaded with beans, rice, meat and toppings.

A calorie binge - but worth it.
We got in and out and back on track.

OK, first let me make it perfectly clear that I don't DO truck food, but today I was absolutely STARVING and this cart (Near Drexel/Hahneman) on the North East corner of 15 & Race - which usually has a huge line every day - was nearby.

So for $3.50 I took a leap of faith and got beef w/ broccoli (no sauce) over brown (aka fried) rice.

It's good.

Really!

I might even come here again.

Friends don't let friends spend fourbucks on Charbucks!
That said, I occaisionally splurge on a $3.00 iced latte served up by Brie (sp??) at the Passero's in Suburban station. Or a lovely Cafe au Lait for $2.45 in the afternoon.

The roasted-bitter espresso they use still has a good flavor and the service far supasses that of Charbucks.

Passero's is some of the best coffee in the city (that and La Colombe) - so I will be back.

Budget permitting. Love it here!

I don't get to come here very often any more - but when I do I try to come when the place is DEAD EMPTY - like today - a random Thursday at 2 PM.  Dead.

As a result?  Fan-tabulous service from Stefan (from Serbia) and the lovely bartender (Jamie?  James?).  Seriously - great, great service.

The food - as always - is solid but mabe just a few tweaks could up the game even more.  I especially enjoyed the crab salad (made for the burger of the month - but I asked for a side of it and they were so kind to oblige me).

Jose, baby, you done good!

I love it here when I get here at 11 AM and the lunch rush has not hit yet.
Today I ordered by phone and waltzed in and out with my Green Lemonade (a must), Sweet potato fries and a veggie burger.

So hip.

So city.

So veg.

So cheap?  (Not so much - $15.64 for those 3 items)

LOVE IT!

Want the Fifth star?  Get a BATHROOM, please.

Never disappointed at VW - especiallyy when I split a burger with a friend (the kitchen will gladly cut it in half) so I can indulge in a 1/2 order of lobster mac & cheese.  Decadence!


No room for anthing else - except for a $14 shot of whiskey.

Mmmmn Mmmmn good!

Wow - such awful reviews for this place.  Sure it's sky-high prices - but you are paying for the convenience factor.  Decent produce, frozen foods, dairy, meat and prepared foods.

I go here for emergency purchases, certainly not to do my everyday shopping.

GLad they exist.  Grocery stores are few & far between in Center City.

Excellent lunch-time fare - but man, oh, man the crowds at 12:45 are just CRAZY.
Meanwhile our order came quickly and the gals up front and hard working gals and guys in the back really know how to WORK IT.

Excellent Customer service.
Great Food. - I have the Udon Salad and a Green Lemonade.

I'll be back - and SOON!  (But next time at 11:30 or 11:45 - I can't deal with the crowds.

A nice, relatively new and very clean Qdoba with amazingly no line at 12:15 on a Monday.
I zipped in and out with my taco salad bowl.

Good stuff - no issues.

3 ladies running the front counter were pleasant and delivered great customer service.

I will be back - and likely soon.

Ditto and Tritto wehat they already said!  I usually get the (enormous) platter.
You get what you get and you don't get upset!

Mama's Falafel is good, too.  (Right down the street.)

Still some of the best coffee in the city - and still a line (that moved pretty quickly) every morning in Suburban Station.

Pricey but so much better than Dunkin or Charbucks.

The Café au Lait and Lattes (the will used your favorite type of cows or nut milk) are so delicious.  Like dessert in a cup for breakfast (and I don't even get any flavored syrups - just a plain latte or au lait is so creamy and sweet.)

Yum!!!!

I have past by this stripmall bar a bazillion times but never wanted to go in. Last night my friend who is a Delco native, dragged me in there for her old high school reunion.

The bar was PACKED with middle-aged ex-Sun Valley graduates.  Renee, the lovely and gorgeous hostess, sat us at a table. 

At 9 PM a live duo began jamming out 70's and 80's covers.  They were pretty good, too.

Best of all, we even got Mary, our overworked server, to smile.  She brought us some surprisingly delicious food including a Mammoth-sized wedge salad. 

I literally ate a head of lettuce.

Lettuce and vodka. 
I was a happy camper.

So pleasantly surprised by this neighborhood jawn with solid food, drinks, live music and terrific service.

We love you, Mary!

We stopped in (had a 6:15 reservation) as a party pf 5 for Opera Night (a $4 charge PER PERSON so be aware) on a crisp autumnal Monday.  Not too crowded (the Monday night and $4 charge helped with that I am certain!) and the service was just fine.  Note:  Please tell people when they call on Mondays about the $4 charge.  We had no idea until we saw it on the menu.

We heard 3 arias by Heidi and one included a very talented tenor - can't remember his name.

Caprese salad makes a good app for 2 or 3 to share - delicious fresh mozzarella balls and a mound of lettuce (lettuce??) and fresh basil in the center.

Entrees included an uber-rich gnocchi Gorgonzola, spaghetti carbonara, ravioli marinara, chicken parm (for the 9 year old - and she loved it) and my dish - Shrimp Scampi.  Delicious and HUGE - nearly everyone took something home.

No room for dessert - but other people's looked great.

We love Fellini's and are so happy that they are now open for LUNCH on weekends - so maybe, just maybe, we can take our parents there next time.

Since then we have been back for weekend lunch a few times and it is very good (Try the Linguine alla Vongole).  The only complaint?  My 9 year old does not like their hot chocolate.  Says it is bitter.  However, I love their cappucinos!

A surprisingly GOOD experience with Dorjee (our Teppan chef) and our server.
Excellent Sunday-lunchtime service for our table of 10, celebrating a birthday.

The lunch menu is a good value - the "Lunch Boat" - I chose salmon - a teeny piece of salmon - comes with sashimi, edamame, tempura (all in small portions - perfect) and soup/salad.

My daughter (age 12) devoured the tuna tataki app. and a plate of nigiri.

We enjoyed the food and service, while watching the onion volcano.
Nostalgic.

A hair's bredth away from 5 stars - the food, deluxe cocktails and service are 5 star - the cramped, crowded digs and icky single bathroom make it down to 4.

We stopped in for drinks and were not at all disappointed.
Wonderful bartenders who explained every exotic sounding thing we asked about.  Great selection of draught beers and ales (even a cider on tap).

Love it!

GET THE BURGER!

A strong 4 stars for Village Whiskey from me!
A good friend and fellow yelper squeaked into the bar at around 8:45 PM on a snowy Tuesday.  There just happened to be 2 great seats waiting for us.  (I don't know if this place is worth a long wait)

Service from Sasha was excellent and she is so friendly and helpful.
We started off with an order of fried pickles and shared the DELICIOUS pickled artichokes.  (These are the best thing I tasted that night and worth a re-order)

My companion had a delectable veggie burger topped with a fried egg (Wowza!) and guacamole.  The lady next to us had a beef burger topped with an egg as well and they sure know how to fry an egg here!
(Incidentally the couple next to us also shared the duckfat fries topped with shortribs and cheese sauce - looked so heavy - like a heart attach on a plate.  I bet it ROCKED!

Anyhow, we continued with an order of "tater tots' that were so rrefined they'd put Ore-Ida to shame.

And an order of pickled golden and red beets that I wound up barely touching and had packed up to go.

The best thing to me?  The delicious lemon oil-scented whipped ricotta that accompaied the pickled dishes.  Also a tasty tapenade and fresh, thin slices of baguette.  Nice!

I will definitely come back here.

What a cute (albeit small) "retro" feeling place.

Even with the mixed reviews I had been wanting to try Spasso for over a year.
Last night - a slow-as-heck Monday night was the night to do it.

While this may be a truly 3 star place, I am giving them a 4 for the excellent service we got (along with $4 cape-codders) at the bar.  The caprese salad was not the best - it was served with iceberg lettuce (who does that??) and was swimming in low-grade olive oil. For $5 on happy hour it was fine.  Normally it's $8.50 and I would not order it again. (Which is a shame because I love a good caprese.)
Bartender was cute and very personable also.

Dinner was better - we were seated right away (dining room was only about 1/4 full) and our (young, pretty) server was perfectly fine.

Food was actually great - veal with spinach and crab-meat served with al dente fettuccine.  Large portion so I took 1/2 home.  My friend had veal parm - which looked average.  (Veal was deep fried underneath the sauce and cheese. Chocolate mousse cake was OK for dessert but the cappuccino was Excellent.

I can certainly understand why some don't like it here as there are many unprofessional chinks in the Spasso armor.  The dining room below the chair rail MUST be re-painted.  It is a deep brown color and everywhere a chair has bumped there is a white chip out of the paint (looks bad).  Also the female servers and hostesses tend to collect in a gaggle at the hostess stand or by the kitchen and chat (they were bored and it was slow ) - or out back for a smoke.

Not truly a 4 star place - morel like 3, 3.5 but we had a great night and I am feeling generous.

I'll be back for happy hour for sure.

Our office uses Crocodile Catering (and a few other companies) because that are reliable (never late - which is key here) and have "safe" choices.  Salads are fresh and sandwiches are plentiful.  We usually get a cold breakfast (bagel platter and cut fruit bowl or a Sandwich/Wrap platter with salads for lunch.

I have not tried any of their hot food options.

A solid option for business/corporate catering.

Another wonderful (and huge portion sized) meal - this time for lunch on a Sunday at Fellinis.  The Shrimp Scampi, Veal Parm, Caprese Salad, Chicken Scarp and Linguine with Crabmeat (in a red sauce) were all terrific.

Great service, and re-done restrooms!

Love it here.

5 stars for our service today from Lallo.
Also the new dinining room is great.

Some of the BEST cappucino we have ever had.

The only thing preventing 5 stars?  Too loud!  Crazy-loud - even at lunch time.  (The ceilings maybe?)

Pina's Pizza has 2 or 3 locations around Doylestown, but this location in Chalfont is where my family are regulars. So much so that Anna Maria set out Diet Cokes for my parents before the car was even parked.

She knows us all by name.
So the service is always 5 star.

The food is good - solid Pizzeria staples and cheese-steaks.  Deliciously garlicky garlic knots (with chucks of garlic - you will need to brush after wards!) and fresh salads.  The cheese on the caprese is fresh and wonderful.  

Portions are generous.

We love it here and return over and over.

Plus - Anna Maria gives us mini canolli for dessert.
Wow!

Fellini's Media is a BYO located in an historic building - the site of an old Cigar Shop.  The place is PACKED especially on weekends - we showed up (no reservation) on a Saturday night at 7:45 PM and lucked out.

The placed was a cacophony (sp?) inside, but we managed to snag one of the 2 outdoor tables on a September night that was not hot and not cold.

FAB!

Rose and Chris (and about 3 other server/bussers) were terrific - and man, were they workin' it.  Our bread, butter, ice water and bruschetta arrived right away.

Soon after, our HUGE, moderately priced entrees - Chicken Contadina for the husband, Penne Sophia Loren for me.  (Took half home - so nice, I'll eat it twice.)

A great spot for sure, in Media.

5 Star service from Vera (hostess) and our amazing and attentive server, Kaitlyn.  Wow - we were seated outside on a hot, sticky, humid Father's Day and Kaitlyn was just on point!

Our party of 6 truly enjoyed the sweet potato fries and fried brussels sprouts (sans bacon) which we all shared and wolfed down.

For entrees we enjoyed a variety of burgers (brioche buns), flatbread, "power bowl" and a "healthy" salmon on pita called "The Edinburgh".  I would totally come back here.

Great place for families at lunch and a different, noisier crowd at night.

Chicken Caesar salad and Matzoh Ball Soup (sans balls) were both great and delivered to my door by a caring friend.

I would definitely try them again.

2 words are all you need to know:

Strawberry. Shortcake.

End of story.
Has been serving up law firm cakes for years.  Decades even.

Yes, please!

Stopped in on a whim for a quick bite and boy am I ever glad!  They have alot of great Korean food (bi-bim bap with tofu is a winner!) as well as sandwiches and salads.

The owner/lady/cashier is a doll.

Love it here.

Had not been to Fellini's in a few years - yes years.
Went with a group of 5 ladies about a month ago and again tonight.
We sat in Juana's section both times - and Juana is a terrific server.

The food can vary from a 3 to a 5 depending on what you choose.

The burrata appetizer (special) and caprese (on the main menu) are always safe and delicious lower-carb choices.

The pastas are terrific but alas, I can't do the carbs any more.

Solid "classic" Italian-American dishes.

There's a very special place in my heart for the crummy ole 'WYCK.  First of all - they served me drinks when I was about 15/16 years old - but that was many years ago - I won't say HOW many.  So a star for the underage mem'ries.

It's also the place I had my first ever Rob Roy.

You can get all the old school cocktails here - and beers on tap and in bottles.  The food is surprisingly good and safe.  They used to serve a tasty cheese ravioli - but that was a long time ago - not sure if they still do.

But man, that Rob Roy - what was I thinking????

I have never eaten in the restaurant, but this review is for the EXCELLENT job done by Karen and her team.  They catered a dessert corporate event for my company and everything was beautifully presented and delicious.

The desserts included moist two-bite cupcakes in chocolate, vanilla and (was that) carrot with a coconut frosting.  Decorations were so cute.  Lemon squares, brownies and a gorgeous key lime tart.

Along with lemonade and iced tea (I, of course, made an Arnold Palmer) it was just right for our event.

Brava!

I now have NO excuse to not come and eat at Curds & Whey.
A much needed upscale version of wawa - with sandwiches and convenience foods, plus beverages and yogurt.  Sorely needed so I am thankful it's here.

The Porch - the newly constructed slab of fresh sidewalk and tables & chairs - provides FREE miniature golf all during July 2012.
Concerts at lunchtime.
A new Farmers Market on Wednesdays (11 AM - 2 PM thru beginning of October) complete with Mom Pops (YUM - read that review next!).

Check them out - and let's help get 30th Street re-re-revitalized.

This review is for Mexican Post Express (the one in the bottom of the Comacast Center).  I am so happy they now have a Mexican option in the Comcast Center.  

While I am not a huge fan of the sit-down branches of Mexican Post (we have often been to the Cherry street location, which is near our home.), the Express offers a less expensive option and is great for lunch.

They also participated in the Yelp Spring Festival and had muy delicioso Spinach Flauta.  I hope they'll add it to their every day menu.  (But somehow I doubt that.)

So, muchas gracias to Mexican Post Express for offering the hungry lunch crowd a quick and tasty burrito, taco or enchilada.

3 or 4 stars from me for Coffee Beanery inside the Concord Mall.  The lady attending the counter on a quiet weekday morning at 10 AM was personable and we had good service.

I have an Iced 1/2 caff latte and my friend had an iced (regular) coffee.

No issues.

Stopped in for lunch and would up ordering the eggs Florentine - and they were PERECT.  So satisfying on a cold wintery day.  It was very busy (They do a big lunch business).

A go-to lunch spot or for "breakfast all day".

Old-school décor.  Pay up front.

I am not a big Indian Food lover - but I do love the breads.
That said, a group of 4 coworkers (including me) went for lunch here and indulged in the $8.95 lunch buffet.

Everything was fresh (We arrived right after 12 noon) and not too picked over.
I enjoyed the Chicken Tikka Masala (very mild and basic), rice, Saag Panir and fresh naan.  Galub Jamun for dessert is always a treat - and Chinnar's is good.

We also ordered a freshly cooked (off the menu) order of Aloo Paratha (Bred with potatos) and that was terrific.

I prefer to order freshly cooked meals over the buffet - but for $8.95 you can't beat the selection and value.

Next time if we come for dinner I want to try a lamb dish.
And yes, we'll be back - likely soon.

Great customer service from Dontae and my food was ready in a flash - even during a busy Thursday lunch rush.  Line moves quickly.  Tables get crowded, so I carried out.

Excellent choice in fast food if you stick to grilled nuggets and super food side.
This is a very nice, well run, clean Chipotle.  My Chicken Burrito Bowl was a bit too spicy for some reason today - but otherwise - it's just the way I like it.

Cafe Riviera provides a lunch buffet of hot items (with cold pasta or green salad along side) for our corporate cafe once a week and man, is it ever delicious.

The meatballs, Italian sausage (with peppers and onions) and Chicken Cacciatore are classics and so well executed -even for a mass buffet.

So pleased - and now I wanna go to the restaurant!

This review is specifically for the terrific makeover I received at the MAC counter by Cynthia.  She is a bit older, experienced makeup artist and made me look FAB.

I like many of MAC's products and the $55.00 minimum purchase to have your look done is really no biggie - once you pick out a few items.  I spent more like $100.  (Ssssh - don't tell my husband.)

Anyhow - give Cynthia a try at MAC - she knows what she's doing and is not pushy at all.  I really enjoyed meeting her.

Went for lunch again with a coworker.
Chicken Tikka Masala is excellent.

Freshly-baked Naan (even on the buffet - you can get a fresh basket of naan included).

A lovely selection.
Price is now $9.95 for lunch - we must have goten a special or something last time it was $8.95.

Not a big deal. - for $10 you can eat yourself silly.

I am not a big Panera girl - but I have eaten in quite a few of them.  Went here for lunch when it was crowded but not crazy (when it's crazy I won't go.)

Monday - Friday ferom 12 - 1:30 the joint is packed with pharmaceutical folks wolfing down their salads, soups and sandwiches.

I got a 1/2 size salad (plenty) and a cup of delicious lemon chicken orzo soup.
I wish they offered that one more.

Salad was on romaine and it was boring but fine.
Soup was very good.
Came out for about $10.

A good quick-fix for lunch.

I was having a challah emergency (and they only bake real Challah on Fridays - appropriately enough) but I got 2 braided Briche rolls that looked like little round mini-challahs and it worked out fine.

Thank goodness they were there!

I have also had the odd croissant and breakfast treat here - very good stuff - especially their almond croissant.  Soooooo flaky & buttery and good.

A colleague of mine prdered a huge cookie and brownie tray from Panera for an office event and the cookies (HUGE - and about 450 calories a piece) were delicious.

The Chocolate Chipper and Double Chocolate with Walnuts (and white confection pieces) were snapped up in minutes.

I did not try the brownies but they looked great and also disappeared.

Quick and easy - plus they have a drive through. (The morning coffee rush is a bit hectic).  I usually get an iced coffee (I walk in) during the summer.
They have everything a basic DD has - coffee, donuts, sandwiches and cold drinks.

No issues from me - but I do not come here a whole lot.

Really good food and great Iced Coffee - pus decent service (but it was really hot in there this last time we went for lunch.

The Chicken over broken rice (or banh) is great and the Chinese broccoli  in garlic sauce was crispy and tender and cooked to perfection.

And you can get flaming rum drinks, too - though we never do.

Love Vietnam for a quick comforting meal.

Should be called the "DiBruno's: market - although there are several other shops.  A Capital Teas, Tabouli, an Asian Place and a great Flower shop.

Only 2 places selling fresh produce.

1 fish market.

Clean and fun to visit.
Bring money.  Parking can be tough.

Fantastic Food - including Kabobs and Gyros and a terrific lunch special for $7.95.  Very small place and super casual.

Quick, friendly service and delectable sides like Cauliflower & Sabzi!

Yum!!!!

When I moved to Philly after spending 10 years in New York City (1 year in Brooklyn) the diners here were a let-down.  Meanwhile, I am so happy to find the Oregon (I prefer it to the "classic" Melrose).  They have great old-school waitresses full of spunk and bite.

The food is terrific and the Italian Dinners (Chicken Francese, Cacciatore, etc.) are enormous and restaurant quality.)  What a deal.

Salads are fresh and crisp as is the attitude of the patrons.

LOVE this place with or without my 4 year old in tow.
Viva the Oregon Diner.

We came at the end of the day (around 4 PM) on Sunday so the shelves were fairly barren - but my 11 year old and I shared a HUGE Mexican cookie/cake and a churro (delicious).

Lady helping spoke little English but had a bright smile.
Inexpensive.

Wish they offered a place to sit and eat,  (Philter - a cafe is next door).

Very welcome treats!
CASH ONLY.

Ate at Azie on Main in Villanova (It's around the back of the shopping center next to the STAPLES) as part of a large group - 27 people - in a semi-private room.

We had a set menu which was very good - but I have a feeling the "regular" menu is even better.

Good options for pescetarians.

Nice service.  Gorgeous decor.

Will be back soon.

Lately, my office crew has wanted to go to Panera so i have now been to this one quite a few times and have my "pick 2" order down to a science.

I am starting to actually like it here now - I always ask for an apple instead of the bread that comes with the meal.
If I get a beverage I blow about $12 (close to $13) so I try to just get water.
Otherwise my choices are about $10 - $11.

I like to stare at the baked goods in the case but I never get any.

I was sooooo pleasantly surprised by our group of 5's dinner (yes - try it for dinner - less crowded than the lunch rush) at a huge table (that can seat 7 or 8) in the D-town Panera (fairly new location).

While prices are a bit high for "cafe style" fast food - the soups and breads are tasty (if not caloric) and our 8 year old loved the $11 Shrimp Sandwich. Plus - somebody's gotta wash the real nowls and flatware they serve on (This is not a Saladworks!).

Some items took a long time to come out - but were worth the wait.

We'll be back for sure.

Between OK and Iovine's the RTM has your produce needs more than adequately met.
I usually check Iovine's first and then head to Ok's for whatever did not appeal over there.

They also have good prices on bananas.
Some of the discounted bagged produce you must use it right away (use it or lose it).

Cute place.  I hope they make it.
Expensive coffee drinks - along the lines of Starbucks or Burlap and Bean.

Easy to get out (or in but not in (or out) since they are right on 252 and if there is traffic getting in (or out) is bad if you need to make that dreaded "left turn".

Good customer service and I love to support local businesses.

Once again my (now) 9 year old and I made the annual pilgrimage to Macy's, the Holiday Light Show and Chritmas Village (Dicken's).

She loves it - BUT - now the show is every 2 hours.
It's mayhem.

They need to go back to every hour or 30 minutes.

Also - to have your picture taken with Santa is free - but the photos start at $16.99 (plus tax).  OUCH!

They catered an event for me with cold salads (mozzarella balls, pasta etc.) Very good food and decent prices.  Will use again.  I should clarify - they made the food - but I had to come pick it all up.

Still - a great option.

This is our local Bruster's and it is open YEAR ROUND - though much more crowded in summer.  The gals runnin' the show are friendly and kind to our 9 year old who LOVES the orange & vanilla parfaits (5 scoops of ice cream/sherbet is an obscene amount so she eaits it in 2-3 sittings.)

We like it just fine.
Have been back several times now.

A close female friend and I dined at Stella tonight.
The weather was sublime and we sat inside - but right by the LARGE open floor to ceiling windows - so we had the best of both worlds - inside and al fresco.

We BOTH ordered a plate of the special app - a gloriously fresh mozzarella and heirloom tomato (yellow, orange, red, brown and purple) salad.  It was lightly and PERFECTLY dressed with a basil infused oil and a sweet balsamic (decent quality - not the cheap stuff, but not the 17 year old either).  It sang on the palate.

I am hankeing to try the meatball and risotto app - next time.   (And there WILL be a next time.)

Next we split a pizza.  Let me preface this by saying that I am not (shocking, I know) a pizza lover.  I am a pasta lover, but never really "get off" on pizza.  

Stella's pizza is very, very good.  (My friend says it's better than Osteria - but the pie she had as Osteria was burnt.)  Thin crust - but not ridiculously thin.  (I dislike "pizza on a cracker")  Thin in the middle and medium rise (with some puffiness) on the edges.  We had #11 - Spinach.  It was a white pie with a healthy hit of garlic, toasted pine nuts (Oh, yeah, baby!!), the ideal amount of fresh, bright green, sauteed spinach, and a few heavy handed spinkles (globs?) of a sundried tomato/oil puree.  Definitely tasty - and worth a try for those of you who like spinach.

One negative?  No substitutions on pie.  They make 'em how they make 'em.

One positive?  GREAT service by our your server (can not remember her name - but she was really nice and attentive.)

Another thing... only gelatos for dessert.  We skipped dessert here and opted to get some home-made cakes at "More than Just Ice Cream".  But I bet their gelato is good.  (However, Capogiro is not too far, ya know...)

Anyhow - Starr strikes again with a good (and not overly decorated - thank goodnees) spot.

Note to the hard-working pie men (and gals):  Please keep the pies crispy on the bottom - nobody likes a soggy pie.

JOB WELL DONE.

Oh - another thing - we really wish you'd take reservations.  Thankfully at 5:30 on a May Sunday we (2 people) did not need one and were seated quickly.  Hooray!

Real-deal authentico Mexican "bodega style" - no atmosphere, tiny space and a bit "grubby" but man, the food is good.  Squash blossom quesadillas and very solid tacos al pastor.  Real Horchata, too.

Lovely service. Inexpensive.

Can't wait to return.

Our group of 4 came here for lunch at 11:45 on what turned into an insanely busy Driday lunch rush.  You gotta come early or the waits are long.

We shared 20 wings (double fried, K-style spricy and soy) and each got entrees.

Note - way to much food.  Next time just the entrees or fewer wings.

The food was great - the Gal-bi (beef) costs $4 extra but for me it is worth it.

We like Giwa too, but Koreana is a winner in my book.
I shall return.

Wanted to go to Yia across the street but it was a Monday and they were closed.  So a friend and I went to Desert Rose - and this time the food was much better than I remembered from a few years back.

I had a Chicken Shwarma platter and they gladly substituted cucumber slices for the pita bread.  The cucumber/tomato salad here is terrific and always fresh.

Moroccan Tomato soup was a tad too acidic but the pine nuts were a delicious addition. 

Fresh mint tea afterward is always refreshing.

Pleasant service.

Yum! Scaramuzza'a frozen pasta - available at local deli's and even at Acme.
Love it! Competitively priced and cooks up straight from the frozen state.

I have gotten the Linguini, Fettucini and Manicotti.

Good stuff!

A coworker took me here for dinner and I was fully expecting good sushi (and I was not disappointed) but what really made me smile was the incredible Galbi/Kalbi!  Wow - complete with 5 panchan (potatoes, bean sprouts, kimchi, broccoli and cucumber salad).  

Some of the best Korean I have had in a long while.

The spicy crunchy tuna rolls are delicious here and they have a FULL BAR.
Lovely lady (owner??) served us.

Can't wait to return.
Jazz once a month!

I am astounded at how good the food was here for a late lunch.
The hostess, however, had a very sour disposition - perhaps tempered by thescreaming throngs of 6 year olds assembled for a noisy birthday party.  We asked to sit elsewhere.  This displeased her all the more.

But the 2 star hostess was quickly forgotten when sunny Stephanie arrived to take our drink orders.  The food came quickly and was delicious - everything from the (somewhat high priced) kids meal for the kiddo, to DH's sandwich to MIL's mushroom pizza.

I had a 1/2 order ("small plate" of pasta wit chicken, broccoli andlemon pesto.  
It was great.  Honestly!

I can't believe I now like it here.
Wow.

Wow - much better than King of Tandoor.  We had a very inexpensive ($8-$9) lunch today at Saffron.  What a pleasant place.  The saffron colored decor with black accents, the delicious Chicken Tikka Masala, the Mango Lassi - everything was great.

2 very nice tag-team male servers.  They even made me a poori (not on the menu) and my friend had a scrumptious garlic naan.

Fresh and wonderful!  Can't wait to try it at dinner time.
Yay!  D-town got a Primo's!  I like the Nonna's veggie (as a wrap) or the Milno.  The fresh mozzarella is so good on the sandwiches here.  LOVE PRIMO'S.

I am absolutely astounded at how good the food was here for a late lunch with our party of 7.

The hostess, however, had an unfriendly disposition - perhaps tempered by thescreaming throngs of 6 year olds assembled for a noisy birthday party.  We asked to sit elsewhere.  This displeased her all the more.

But the 2 star hostess was quickly forgotten when our sunny female server arrived to take our drink orders.  The food came quickly and was delicious - everything from the (somewhat high priced) kids meal for the kiddo, to DH's sandwich to MIL's mushroom pizza. They also have a full bar - so I had a (well) vodka and cranberry juice.

I had a 1/2 order ("small plate") of pasta with shrimp and a few chunks of lobster in a scampi-esque sauce.  
It was great.  Honestly! (I asked for it light on the sauce so it was not swimming in oil.  YAY!)

I can't believe I now like it here.
A chain.
Who knew that would be possible?

A solid place for take-out - does not seem to be as popular for dine in. Pizza, Garlic knots, Focaccia (fresh) and Salads (big!) were all solid and did not disappoint.

Friendly service.

Restroom was moderately scary.  Needs to be cleaned more often.

They also have a soda fountain like the ones at Wawa where you can make any flavor drink you can imagine.

Good pizza and a huge variety of slices or (better yet) get a whole pie baked fresh.

My colleague brought in cookies and muffins to share with the team from Pure Bread and the Red Velvet/chocolate chip muffin (or, shall I say unfrosted cupcake) was terrific! I had half - but now I want another half!

I am sufficiently sugared-up for the day.

We are now coming here about every 3 months so that I can have my shakshuka fix. That and the beef short ribs and silky-smooth hummus are faves. The tomato soup with Manchego cheese shaved over the top is worth a try, too, if you like tomato soup. 

Don't miss the fresh mint tea, too.
Great service the last few times.

Very happy now!

I think it says alot that downtown Media now has 2 bubble tea joints and soon will have 2 dim sum spots.  Meanwhile, Kung Fu Tea is brand new (about a month old) and spacious and clean with a ton of sugar-laden tea and coffee/tea and slush and bubble-tea choices.

They also offer rice balls and crepes (Did not try yet).

Speedy service (they call your number so hang on to your recepit), so sit in a booth or on a comfy couch and play a game of Jenga or Uno.

Then, sip and enjoy.

A great spot!
Boba Tiki needs to watch out.

Great for take out.
Fabulous Gyro sandwiches, platters, kebabbs and afghan delights including fried cauliflower and (oily but good) eggplant.  Spinach is great, too.

Love it here!

Peri at Night Kitchen bakery did our (gorgeous) 3 tiered wedding cake in 2008.  It was beautiful to look at and 2 of the 3 tiers were delicious.  The top tier was white cake with Lemon curd and it was slightly dry, but the middle tier (carrot cake no raisins) and bottom tier (Moist deep chocolate cake with chocolate mousse) were both scrumptious.

The cakes here are made with love and attention to detail.  I recommend them highly.

Got a simple take out order of Chicken with Broccoli (light sauce), brown rice, steamed pork dumplings (so tasty) and classic Moo Shu Pork.   Everything was terrific.

Very impressed as my expectations were low - I usually don't like Chinese - too greasy and many have "gloppy" sauces.  This did not.  

Wow.

I will be back - and maybe dine in next time so I can try their Peking Duck - if a place does Moo Shu well (good pancakes, hoi sin) they MIGHT just do the duck well.

THANK YOU!

I agree with Dave H.  Bucks County is sorely lacking in the Thai Department.  (And how I loves me a good Thai meal - especially that Tom Kha Gai!)

Meanwhile - Siam Cuisine does a very nice job in holding me over for West Coast Thai.  Prices are moderate, service is good and food is tatsy (if predictable.).  Even had a nice DUCK breast dish a while back.

My parent's are old-school and to them Italian is adventurous - so I can't get them to go there too much - but I did manage to get them to go with me once years ago and I my mom liked the Chicken Basil Curry.

I will definitely be back.

@Christopher - they had a Belgian called Delirium Tremmens tonight.
Interesting brews for sure here. (8.5% alc.)

I had avoided coming here for years.
Really.
Years.

I had such bad experiences with the Uno (then called Pizzeria Uno) in the early '90's that I just never wanted to deal.

So tongiht our party of 7 dined for aboout $100 - very reasonable (But few of us ordered alcohol - and no apps, no desserts).  My 6 year old loves it here and - get this - gobbled up all of the steamed broccoli.  The side order of steamed broc is $2.99 and worth every penny.  I got one for me and one for her (along with our pasta dishes.  Wow.

My faith has been restored in Uno - and Steven our young server was very friendly and had a great attitude - and the hostess Lori (sp??) addressed me by name - twice.

Oh - and ironically nobody ordered pizza.  And we all enjoyed or pastas, burgers and chicken dishes.
Great for kids and families.


Such a pleasant surprise.

Had a great and moderately priced (no longer cheap!) large lunch here (we took a bunch home).  Great service and tasty basic diner food.  Excellent soup.

I love diners!

Huge menu - eat breakfast whenever you like.
Nicer than the Melrose (IMO).  Food at Oregon Diner is a little bit better (also MHO).
this is our go-to Wawa WITH Gas - and it is always busy but you can get in & out fast.  no issues.

This place - as many, many others have said is a hidden gem with really, truly good and inexpensive Mexican food.  The Huaracche (I got mine with Al Pastor) was $7.50 and enormous.

Home-made horchata and a variety of aqua fresca.

Plus you can shop for REAL Mexican goods and groceries.

Our server Jeanette (sp??) was a doll.

Can't wait to return.
It almost makes Norristown bearable.

My 11 year old will occasionally want to come here - and they are open all year -round (but of course, busier in summer).  Prices are a little high - but ice cream, parfaits and other treats are very good and service is just swell.

One day a week (Thursday? I forget) there is a deal if you BYOB (Bring Your Own Banana) for a cheaper banana split.  I thought this was a scream - but we have never done it.

Imagine... BYO Banana!!!

Cracks me up.

Also if your small child is under a certain height they get a free kiddie cone.

I used to eat at the Full Moon many moons ago - so boy was I glad to find that it's still Egg-cellent after all these many moons!

Yesterday my huband, 6 year old and 2 cousins met for a noon-time brunch at the Full Moon (they also serve dinner - once a month on the Full Moon).  I had a decadent crab, tomato & spinach topped eggs benedict - one of the best I've ever eaten.

Service was great - the place is small and they don't take reservations - so come early or be prepared for a bit of a wait.  (We lucked out and were seated right away.)

Nice waitstaff, great food in a moon-decored casual atmosphere.

Now, if only I could explain to my 6 year old not to moon people.

A full service Wawa with clean restrooms and a gas station.  Can get crowded but service is always quick and friendly with all the staples that every Wawa has.

I come here about 4-6 times per year.

Sabrina's - you have redeemed yourself.  (or maybe I've just figured out when to come and what to order??)

I dined solo (and was greeted and served promptly and properly) tonight and enjoyed a 1/2 sandwich, soup and salad ($1.00 extra for salad instead of fries).  The plate also had a home-made slaw of cabbage, carrot and sweetened, dried cranberries.  A nice plate!

Also enjoyed my (you betcha!) Arnold Palmer.

Iskra was a doll and I am now much more optimistic about Sabrina's.
When they get it right, they really get it right (and when they screw up - the screw up bigtime.)

Here's my take - DO NOT GO at brunch/breakfast time.

Come here for dinner.
And try the stuffed (dessert posing as breakfast) french toast.

Every time I am dragged to Uno I am amazed that it is as good as it is.  My dad and I came here during COVID (masks on) and sat in the empty bar area and a bar-booth.

We both had burgers.  BIG (8 oz) juicy, perfectly cooked and topped with whatever you wish (I had Cheddar, tomato and lettuce).

I was able to get steamed broccoli instead of fries.  Yay!

Honestly?
It was really good.  For a chain.

The key is NOT getting pizza, I think.

I had a lovely solo dining experience at El Rey on a scorching hot Wednesday Night.  My servers Justin and Isaiah were both terrific and very knowledgeable about food and the menu items.

Since I dined alone I had only one item from the menu (and I can't wait to return to try more).  I had the short rib torta and it was BIG (Huge, and messy - definitely NOT a date night food.), but more importantly it was Excellente!

The braised beef shortrib was tender, yet charred (they do this at the end for presentation) and tasted so flavorful and succulent with just the right amout of fat to taste great but not too fatty.

The sauce - made of guajillo (sp??) peppers and tomato, really tasted like tomato sauce to me - but what do I know?  The best part?  A FRESH - I mean uber-fresh - baked roll - almost like a mexican "fat" baquette with a crunchy crust and a white, airy inside.  (Yes, I know trop carbs, but who cares when the Bread is shipped in from Parc!!!)

They even re-did the back bar as a swanky faux speak-easy.

Yes, it's pricey - but I bet if you order the right things you can have a 4 star night easily at El Rey.

Oh - and even though the place is blaringly-loud - it's still less noisy than Distrito - but I gotta say - Distrito's food still ROCKS my world.

I shall return.  Next time with friends!

Finally we a got a chance to eat inside the restaurant and the food is every bit as terrific inside as it was on those balmy summer nights.

We started with the super-fresh (just made) $8 guacamole and chips.  (Plus their 4 house made salsas.  Our 10 year old loves the salsa Roja and I like the Chipotle one.

El kiddo had the surf & turf fajitas which she loved and I had a special - small steak and chicken enchilada.  Husband had pork ribs al pastor (delish!).

Kudos to Greg (who was not there that night) Nina and Sidney (Sydney?) for terrific friendly service - even with problem with their POS.

We love you!

I like Jos. A. Bank when they are having sales (which is nearly always).
Ran in here quickly to buy my man some duds.

Excellent service.

Makes for good gifts.

Update:  I bought a bunch of stuff here in February 2015 for a Valentine's gift for my husband.  I needed to return 2 items and they accepted them back (unopened with receipt) with no issues.  Easy Peasy!  GREAT SERVICE.

The next best thing to a trip to Cape Cod - I tried the Taste of Maine which is a 1/2 roll each of shrimp, lobster and crab for $20 - including a drink (I got a pellegrino) and a bag of Cape Cod chips (I got BBQ and saved them for later).

Good sized rolls and the crab one was really excellent. I also loved the lobster one.
Not too much mayo and the roll was toasted and lightly buttered (a classic split-top) just as it should be.

Can't wait to go back. (I went at 11:40 right before the line started to form.  Smart move!
Just got back from a lovely Sunday 2 hour session of blueberry and peach picking.  From March - December there is something to do that's great at Linvilla.

Just stopped in for a quick bowl of vermicelli with spring rolls and sliced beef.
On a cold night - this place (still in dire need of a makeover) serves a great, warming meal for under $10.

Love it here!

Truly Delightful prepared and Packaged foods.
Not so much delightfulness?  The place could use a good cleaning and the parking situation is a bit crazy.  (I wound up at the McDonald's nearby - no spots in the back nor the front.)

wish they had fresh produce too.

Stocked up on some of the BEST stuffed grape-leaves i have EVER had.  plus eggplant salad (a little oily) and delicious meat pies and bakalava.

Don't miss the Lahmahjoon!!!!

LOVE THIS and wishing them many more years of success.

Dining Under the Stars (Wednesday night in the summer) can be a big ole mess - super crowded, long waits for a table, long waits to order, long waits to get food.

Surprisingly - this was NOT the case and we. lucked. out.  Greg and his amazing team at Dos Gringos honored our 6:45 PM reservation (all 3 people in our party were present) and sat us right when we arrived at 6:30 PM (WOW!).

The wait staff was uber-busy so we waiting a while - but not very long for menus, chops/salsa (so good) and that fabulous $10 guac.  Yup.  Guacamole is $10 here.  But we love it.

Vegetable enchiladas and surf & turf fajitas are family faves.

We keep coming back (even after Hildago opened - which we also enjoy).
See you next time!

Another excellent night at Dos Gringos with 5 star servce from Nina, Billie, Jess & of course, Greg.  

Our 9 year old devoured the "surf & turf" fajita platter.

Delicious coffee drinks and a plethora of syrups (Butterscotch latte anyone?) if you are into diabetes in a cup.

Funky-eclectic male baristas.  

Decent prices and a fun-in-the-sunny window seating area.

Love.

Greg and his staff treat our party of 3 like royalty during our "Dining Under The Stars"  (aka chaos out in the heat).  Possibly "Duning out in the Mist" due to the light rain and heavy cloud cover.  Still, the place was hoppin' and the food was poppin'.

Our 9 year old get a chicken quesadilla and rice & beans which she loved.  She also plowed through the guacamole abd the mild red salsa.

I love the specia that night - Crab (real lump crabmeat) and goat cheese enchiladas.  The pale green avo-jalapeno crema was terrific over top of it.  Rich and decadent.

So close to 5 stars - why not?  Hubby did not care for the braised beef enchiladas - he said the shortribs last time were better.  I did not try his dish but it looked flippin' fantasstic to me.

Love this place - and love to Greg and his hard working staff (front and back)!

Now they have all 4 ramen options in a vegetarian broth with great veggies!
Also for Summer 2013 there is a great cold ramen salad ($11.00).
HOORAY FOR VEG-Friendly options.

I love it here - but it is sooooo salty - but today the lady said if I tell her they can make them less salty.

This time I got the Vegetarian Miso (regular size is plenty big for me - but they also have a large size) and a side of tender Toriniku Pork (I like it better than the Cha su).  I skip the egg and extra noodles (no need for me - but if you like poached eggs they offer it as an add-on.)

So happy they are here!
This is one place where I like takeout better than eat in - as they pack the broth and noodles/goodies separately and I love that!!!
And they accept LevelUp.

Just got back from the CHAOS that is Linvilla during halloween season.
We enjoyed a fabulous hayride and bonfire - complete with long sticks and marshmallows for toasting and small cups of home-pressed Linvilla apple cider.

I also bought (naughty me) a half-dozen apple cider donuts which were still warm and disappeared quickly.  YUM!

It would be 5 stas but for the commercialism that is rampant and grows larger every year (they have 2 enormous parking areas and they are both always packed.)

Want to really enjoy Linvilla - come when it's not Hallowwen and get the same great treats, seasonal rpdocue and less people/kids/lines/chaos.

Still don't accept credit cards - but they do have take out - that is well packed (broth and goodies in separate bowls). I also love the little piece of nori that comes when you get Shoyu.  You can also add bean sprouts and/or bok choy for a small upcharge.

I tried the Shio this time - and liked it better than the Shoyu.  Both are salt-laden, though. And I also enjoy the Miso - but that may be from the drizzle of black garlic "nom nom" sauce on top.

Next time will try the (limited time offer) Pork Cheeks or the Soft-Shell crab buns!  (pricey stuff - but I bet it's great.)

The bad part?  With all the extra goodies (no need for extra noodles in my opinion, unless you are a big eater and famished) I usually spend about $10 on ramen.  YIKES.

Had a much better experience - this time for dinner - and the grilled beef summer rolls ($6.50) were so tasty and fresh.  Pho was average - but worked.  Broken rice platters are a good value. Friendly service and a fun experience.

I am NOT a fan of chains - and truly not a fan of Outback (in fact, I stay away from most of the steaks there), but today our party of 5 - including my parents who LOVE Outback had a great Sunday lunch.

Part of what made it so great was that the place was EMPTY at 12 noon on a Sunday.
Thus, we had attentive service and no waiting to be seated.

Bliss.

I enjoyed a 1/2 rack (4) of ribs and my 7 year old ate 2 of them.  Plus a kids meal of "mac-a-roo" - and steamed broccoli.  The kid ate like a champ.

Do I love the food here?  Not really.  Is it 5 stars?  No way.
But we got a decent 4 star meal out of a 3 star place.
Good for kids (mine at least.)

Go at an off-peak time for this formula-cooking meat fest.

P.S.  - for $5 they serve up an enormous and very good key lime pie on a graham cracker crust.

Odd service (from hostesses - not server - she was great) and excellent "fresh" food for a pricey but delicious lunch.  Crab Cake Wedge salad was terrific as was a simple side of roasted red beets with sliced almonds.  Sweet & Crunchy and so easy to scarf down.

A fizzy glass of sparkling raspberry lemonade was refreshing and light.

Love it here.  Wish I could afford to come more often.

Try the Toriniku (pork cheek) special - or get a side order of it.
If you are a pork fan this is BETTER than the pork belly.  Still fatty, yes, but very tender.  Super flavorful.

All the broth here is very salty to me, but still a tasty winter treat.
Tip:  add Bok Choy and Bean Sprouts!

Very clean, well-run Starbucks.  Parking lot around back.
No issues.

Two words.

Tomato Pie.

All you need to know.

I nicknamed this place Bun Cali - because i much prefer to get the bun here - tho the Pho is good, too.

My little daughter likes the Sugar Cane shrimp.

CHEAP, fast and a good Viet-fix when you need one.
Decor is very basic and could use a clean-up.

How do they do it?  And they've been doin' it for years?

The country place serves good down-home/bar type food and is sooooooo cheap.  Great drinks - and yes, sometimes the crowd is bikers and other times "church ;adies" so you never know what you're gonna get.

I miss it.  I live in Philly now and am too far away to go to COuntry Place - but I have fond memories.

We went to this "rustic sports bar" on a lovely summer day with family - not realizing that it is a chain.  The food was surprisingly good - Potstickers (though frozen, very tasty) and Cobb Salad (nice FRESH romaine) among them.

The outdoor seating is fun - but we opted ti sit indoors in the a/c.

Service by Sarah our server was great and friendly.

If we are in Medford lakes again we would return for lunch - but I bet dinner and happy hour are crowded and noisy.  Lunch is nice & quiet.

The salads (especially in summer) and ceviches here are amazinglt fresh and flavorful.

I really ejoy it here, especially earlier in the evening before it gets too noisy and corwded.

LOVE the food at El Rey.

5 star service for the bar staff (Matt and Allyssa) and our fabulous, attentive server, Valarie.  The atmosphere and vibe were perfect on a busy Friday evening.

Cocktails for Happy Hour (4 - 6:30 PM) are a great value at $8.  For $13.25 - not so much.  I had a Cucumber Gin/White Cranberry concoction and it was refreshing and enjoyable.

The food was just OK.
The highlight for me were the $4.75 brussels sprouts - I got them sans bacon and they were perfectly roasted and wonderful.  

The salad I chose was where things fell short.  I ordered the heirloom tomato and mozzarella salad (a dish I have had at many places, prepared in many different ways).  The "herb crust" on the mozz just ruined it.  (And I could tell is was good, quality mozz underneath.)  Also the tomatoes.  The small, mulit-colored tomoatoes were fine - but the thickly sliced green tomato (the "meat" of the dish") was over ripe and mushy.

Ick.

My friend got (what I was thinking of getting and should have gotten) the veggie sampler for $15.50.  Next time (if it is still available) I will get that.  The black bean taco and roasted tofu looked great.

So 3 star food and 5 star service/decor equals about 4 stars.
Pretty darned good for a chain.

I have never been to John's restaurant, Pizza & Pasta - but they are a godsend to those of us who work at the Amtrak Mechanical Yard.  John brings us goodies like spinach &  ricotta pizza, salads and penne with chicken & broccolli 3 days a week.

The crispy chicken salad with hard boiled egg and Ken's Honey Mustard Dressing was great!  Lettuce (albeit iceberg) was crispy, fresh and rust-free.

Pasta dishes are a little too heavy on the garlic and oil for my tastes  - even when I ask for them "light" on the sauce.

I also tried a cheesesteak roll (Pizza dough wrapped around cheesesteak meat and American cheese).

If you call in your order in advance, they will make you whatever you like.  The other day I had a REAL Veal Parm with spaghetti and delicious (garlicky) garlic bread plus a can of soda for $8.50!!!

Today I had eggplant parm platter (no cheese) and it was PERFECTION - John had just gotten cases of farm-fresh eggplants.

We really appreciate having a nice hot meal nearby!  And they bring it right to our workplace!
Thanks to Pizza & Pasta for their efficient catering.  I can't wait to try more items.  They bring the food right to our door!  God bless 'em!

4-5 stars for sure.  I am a huge proponent of greenmarkets and farmers markets and headhouse is no exception.  LOVE IT!  We got some terrific summer fruits here last summer and I can't wait to come bacak agin in May & June to snag some fresh berries.

Oh - and the fresh tomatoes in season are SLAMMIN'!
Bring some cash.

Our family is a big Dos Gringos fan, but they really need to figure out a few things.
We had a large group (12 people) and they could not seat us all together.  We made due a few feet apart.

Also the new male server is a little abrasive.  It's "his way or the highway".  I kinda miss the nice ladies at lunch time - but I guess they no longer work the dinner shift.

Also - do NOT come here for Dining Under the Stars (aka Chaos out in the Heat).  Service is way, way slow - and we know they are doing their best - but it's not working.  Demand is too high for supply.

Ran out of chips, ran out of mild salsa (made more).  

In the mean time, the pitchers of Mango and Lemon/Lime margarita mix are terrific and after a few shots of tequila none of us cared.

Food was excellent - Chicken Enchiladas, Veggie Enchiladas, Fish Tacos and of course the AMAZING surf & turf fajitas.

One more small gripe:  We were changed a $2.95 sharing charge, but the platter was not split for us.  Basically we were charged for the server to give us 2 bread plates.  Wha?????  I don't mind paying a small sharing charge if it means the platter will, indeed, be split to share.  Ours wasn't.

Sorry to come off harshly - we still love you guys - but there are some areas for improvement.

Lunch?  Come here.
Dinner (not on a Wednesday)?  Come here.
Catering?  Come here.
Large Group?  Don't come here.
Dining out in the Chaos?  Do NOT come here.

Yvonne - who usually works evenings at the main register - is a lovely lady.
Both she and another sales associate helped me in the cosmetics department.

Even though i usually shop at the Walgreen's in Aston, I come to Paoli from time to time as it is on my way home from work.

The cosmetics lady was very helpful and I was able to get a name-brand gel manicure kit (including LED lamp) for $30 with coupons and deals.

Very pleased.

Summer after summer, means softball games and post-game Gallucio's for Pizza (still greasy), Wings (The BBQ ones are great) and Beer.

Very attentive service - especially for a bar.

Wonderful to sit out back and chill.
They treat our 7 year old well, too - and bring her fettucine with butter.

Now that's we are local-yokels, Linvilla is all the more pleasant.
We now live about 5 minutes away - so we go during off times - like March (when all the veggies are 50% 0ff) and get our fresh apple cider donuts (skip the pies - they are not made there - but they are BAKED there), and feed the chickens, goats and an ostrich or two.

Great playground for my 7 year old.
We might even have her birthday party here.

It is madness in October, though.
Just madness.

Well, my husband & I finally tried this place - we've driven by a bunch of times but never went.  And we would consider returning (although Shiroi Hana is more convenient for us - and lately I've been really into Vic's.)

The place was nearly empty at 5:30 on a Friday.  The hostess asked if we had a reservation and we told her that we did not.  She made a negative face so I asked her if that was a problem (The place was empty except for one male couple lingering - and they were there before we got there AND after we left.).  She said no and seated us.

I stopped by the sushi bar to bow to the chef and take a peek at the fish.  Looked good.  Chef recommended the Red Snapper and O-Toro.  

We started with an order ($3.00) of Pork Wasabi Shumai.  - 2 large shumai.  Tasty and very wasabi-ish.

My husband ordered a bowl of udon (very tasty dashi broth) a spicy tuna roll which he loved, and a negi-hamachi roll which was just OK.

I got a special roll (Jay roll?) with rice "pops" on it - good but I did not care for the spicye-level of the tuna filling.  It was too hot for me.  (And I had asked for it mild.)  I bet if you are a spicy lover you'd like the rolls here.

Tuna was fresh - but not the yellowtail.  Also my $6.00 piece of O-Toro was gristley and GROSS.  What a shame.  Toro should be a mouth-gasm and this was not.

The best sushi I got was the Inari stuffed with chopped tuna (spicy tuna - this time WAS made mild) and garnished with chunks of avocado and a few pine nuts.  The pine nuts really made it so special.  I would DEFINITELY get that again.

For dessert we had the green-tea icecrem filled mochi which was very good.

Oh - and they do NOT make their own tamago - it's frozen - so we did not order any.
A good source for spices and dried herbs.  Not as much fun as Penzey's - but good prices on most things.

Oh no!  They are closed?  I hear the Franklin Fountain people bought them.
I hope they re-open soon.  They were great last spring for Easter Bunnies!

A friend and I finally got a chance to try Nom Nom (the name kills me!), and it made me lament for the five dollar bowls of ramen from Larme Dosanko back in NYC "back in the day".

Wow for ramen this is pricey stuff.  $8.00 for the regular bowl (I got Shoyu, friend got Kari).  We both got the poached egg (I was "meh" about it - will skip it next time) and extra noodles (WOW!  Should not have done it - but got to take some home.)
The extra noodles are $1.85 ish and worth it.

We also shared an order of pork buns which rival those at Chifa.  VERY good!  Wish they'd do a non-pork bun (Tofu??).

Oh - and they NOW OFFER TAKE OUT.

PLEASE start taking credit cards!!!

PLEASE!!!!

The frozen custard is quite good.  I am not a water ice eater - but I love the custard at Rita's.  News flash! Their "Gelatti" is NOT Gelatto.  It is a bastardization combo of water ice and custard.  Whatever.  It tastes good.

Bring on the coffee flavored frozen custard, please.

We went to tequila's last night for Tres de Mayo (instead of dealing with the Cinco de Mayo crowds).  Margaritas were not nearly as heavenly as in the past.  Too sweet and "lemonadey" this time.  Oh well.

Meanwhile, the food was good - but not 5 star.  My dish (at least to me) was the best - a special of Langostino, split and grilled and sauced with a yummy tequila, garlic and pepper sauce.  Flavorful - but not too hot & spicey.

Tequila's makes one of the BEST Caesar salads EVER,  It can run heavy on the dressing, so i always ask for it lightly dressed and last night's was up to par and delicious.

Our female server (her name escapes me) was lovely and attentive.

The BEST 5 star part of the meal was the Tres Leche cake (which the 3 of us split - we were stuffed).

The worst - which made me downgrade from 5 to 4 stars - was the queso fundito.  Just tooo heavy and greasy.  A big crock of melted cheese.  (I didn't order it - I never would have in a million years.)

Bring back the FRESH lime margaritas and I'll quickly re-up you to 5 stars.  Tequila's is a great restaurant.  I recommend it to out of town guests often.

Oh - and please start taking reservations.  (Right now they'll only reserve for parties of 6 or more.)

Conveniently located right in Center City - but pricey and a limited selection on items my 8 year old artiste actually uses.  Great in a pinch - and get the student card for a discount (which makes it worth it).

We shop here, Pearl (now closed), Uterecht, AC Moore, Michaels, JoAnnes Fabrics and lots of other places for crafting supplies, canvas, paints and brushes.

We even get the kiddo her own French Easel (but not from here!) - so she can apply to Studio Incamminati when she's ready.

Had a memorable meal with top-notch service from Ella at Casta Diva tonight.
My good friend and I both had the beet salad to start (so delicious and fresh).  She had the salmon with crispy skin and red wine sauce.  (A generous piece - or "portion")  I enjoyed the salmon tartare stuffed cannaloni app as an entree.

La Colombe coffee and our own BYO wines sealed the deal.

A great night with stellar food.

The only downer?  Cash only.  Wish I'd known that before we went.

All vegetables (not fruit) are 50% off from Jan 1 - March 31 every year!!!
It is a terrific deal and we now buy 95% of our veggies at Linvilla (includes tomatoes which technically are not a veggie).

Love the winter veggie sale!

Also in 2016 apples (many varieties) are 69 cent per lb!  Stock up!!!!!

It was a cold rainy November night when I stumbled into Pho Cali - and believe it or not I actually ordered Pho!  I ordered the "rare steak" pho for $6.50 - and it was great - but the steak (very thinly sliced and tender) was not rare.  I guess the steaming hot broth cooked it through by the time it got to me.

The Pho came with a plate of traditional garnishes - fresh white bean sprouts, slices of green jalapeno, fresh lime,

Delicious!  And for $6.50

Digs could use a makeover.

Not bad for a chain.  My 3 year old daughter likes to watch the "pizza man" make pizza - so she, of course, loves it here.

It's better than Olive Garden - but not as good as Bensi's - in the "Scheme of mock-Italian chains".  It is also less noisy in atmosphere and decor than the obnoxious Buca di Beppo.

I'd go here if it was nearby - but would NOT go out of my way to eat here.
At least it's not too expensive.

Hesrchel's meets with my approval:

Dr. Browns?  Check
Extra lean corned beef?  Check
REAL Rye bread?  Check

Service with a smile?  Double check.  What nice young men.

If I gotta have a jewish deli style corned beef sandwich - I come here!
Save me a Diet Dr. Brown's cream soda!
It's fine.  Decent coffee and tea drinks, a reasonably clean restroom, and plenty of seating to work for a while or just relax.  Great location near the "Gayborhood" and Jefferson.

Stopped into El Rey this time during happy hour - and man, WHAT A DEAL.  I got 2 of the $1 tacos - one chicken and one fish (the fish taco was perfect!!!  Cabbage, lime-cilantro-crema and fresh fish).

I also had a $4 house margarita.

If you are around early in the evening and need a tasty snack - you can't beat the $1 tacos at El Rey!  They are small - but 2 or 3 or 4 of them together are plenty.

Good service, too.  I am still lovin' it here!

Went here for a very nice linner (that's half way between lunch and dinner) at about 4 PM on a rainy Sunday.

Since the lunch specials end at 3 PM, we ordered off the regular menu.  DH had a spokie pizza which he enjoyed and I got the dinner portion (enormous - took 2/3 of it home!) of chicken picatta, no capers.

Very good.
Quite good for a chain.
Really.

Excellent service as well (the place was dead from it being 4 PM on a rainy Sunday).

Delivery one night - our first time ever and it won;t be the last - but - we have never set foot in the place.  I suspect takeout is their forte.  Mei Fun is delish - and not greasy.  Spare ribs are a saucy greasy mess.  Dumplings are old-school doughy with pork  - el kiddo loved them, grown ups less so.

So far we just might convert from Da Shin to Jing Fong.  We miss old owners of Da Shin.
