This review is for the Doylestown Starbucks in the historic Fountain House - that for years & years was a bank.

As you may know - if you read my reviews - I am not a big Fourbucks (aka Charbucks) fan, but this location - smack-dab in the middle of town - is a keeper.  The multiple room layout makes for a good spot to cozy up with a (burnt tasting overpirced)  coffee drink.

My little daughter likes the iced green tea lemonade.

A nice location with decent service for a Starbucks.  About as good as a Starbucks can get.  (Oh and boy, can it get crowded with yuppies!).

OK, I am upgrading them to 4 stars now.
My husband, daughter & I have come here many times now after every softball game (win or lose).

DD is 5 and she loves the (greasy - blot it off with napkins first) pizza.
I love the fettucine - perfectly cooked - aldente but somehow light tasting.

We also play the electronic bowling game in the corner of the bar.

Yes, the place is a bit "divey" but they sometimes have live music - and the back patio can be very nice if it's not too hot 'n humid at night.

The 4th star is now added for nostalgia.  We are making memories.

OMG.

Shrimp Scampi over Linguini - came with 6 big shrimp, just the right amount (but alot) of garlic & oil - not too oily/buttery.

Carby BLISS in a foil pan.

I love ya, John!

Cutesy-diner-cum-coffee-shop.  We went on a Friday night and I had the panko-crusted mahi-mahi (Fish o' the day) and DH had the "blue plate" special.

Food was above-average and surprisingly good.
Service (by cute high-school/college guys) was friendly and the under-age eye candy made me feel slightly strange.

Ask about the "Lucky Buns" for dessert.

Alas, my buns are far too large on their own - so no "Lucky Buns" for me.
I'll  stick to the mahi-mahi with lovely brown & wild rice and veggies.  (FRESH green & wax beans and baby carrots.)

YUM!

We made a reservation that afternoon for "dining Under the Stars"  (aka chaos Out in the Heat) and were pleasantly surprised by only a 15 minute wait (others waited up to 25 minutes) for our table for 3.

Greg - one of the owners - treated us so very well - as did all the servers and bussers - especially Sarah.  

Our 8 year old enjoyed the guacamole, rice & beans and chicken quesadilla kids meal.

The best bite of the night?  My husbands app - a shortrib quesedilla made with queso fresco and diced pear and onion.  Scrumptious!

I enjoyed my shortrib entree - and DH had enchiladas.  Very filling - we took some home.

No issues here at all - and much better food than the Cantina on State.  We can' wait to come back on a non-Wednesday - I bet it's even better!

Many thanks to all at Dos Gringos - they were workin' it - for a lovely evening.

My little 4 year old adored Linvilla (Lynn-ville) because there are animals here and our "home orchard" (Solebury Orchard - which ROCKS by the way) does not have animals.

This is a great place for a class field trip -especially around Halloween with the Hayrides and pumpkin & Apple picking and cider making.  A great place.

Fantastic take-out food last weekend from Chin's.
Note:  Now they are CLOSED MONDAYS.

Try the chicken and broccoli and Shrimp with snow peas.
10 ingredient (House special) fried rice is NOT greasy and full of goodies.
Meaty. big spare-ribs and classic (doughy but tasty) steamed meat dumplings.

The only game in D-town!

I usually stop at this Wawa - on a busy stretch of Baltimore Pike - for gas.  That said, it is easy to get in and out here as long as you are "going that way".  I do not usually get food/coffee here.

Convenient for gas.

American may run on Dunkin, but Dunkin' does not run me!
In the mean time - every once in a great while I get a hankerin' for a DD Iced Coffee - so if I am in Suburban station I go to this location.

Service is VERY quick and efficient (they have multiple lines) - even during the insane morning coffee rush.

I never get donuts - and very rarely food items (I actually kinda like the toast sandwiches there - but at 500 - 800 calories for BREAKFAST there is just no way!!), but I love the iced coffee - especially in the summertime.

This update and higher 4 star rating is for the IMPRESSIVE catered feast we had at my office today.  The lady who delivered it, set up the sterno, poured the raspberry (unsweetened) iced tea and catered to our every whim was terrific.

Large pans of spaghetti, meatballs, chicken parm, ravioli in a creamy-blushish-basilish sauce, 2 kinds of salad, 2 desserts.

WOW.

FOOD COMA.

And - it was all hot and very tasty.  Maggiano's - you have redeemed yourself.

A solid choice in this part of Media - and very convenient to Rt 1.
Full bar - and pricey but good cocktails and many beers.
A vast take out and catering section.

Don't miss their signature pistachio crusted chicken tender - especially if they have just made a fresh batch.  They really are delicious.

Salads are good too.

Wow - I remember when this used to be Tilly's.
What an improvement.

Great spot for a diner-style breakfast or a basic lunch sandwich.
I usually go for breakfast.

You can get home fries or a hash brown pattie.

Decent hot coffee, too.
Not super expensive.

A good choice.

We had a luncheon here in one of the private banquet rooms for about 30 people.  The food and service were bith excellent.  Green salad, rolls and butter, a basic penne marinara pasta course followed by a choice of 2 entrees. Crab cake or Chicken Marsala.  Both were delicious.   Super creamy (was it homemade?) Vanilla ice cream fir dessert. Sounds like no big whoop,  but it was soooooo rich tasting. I put some in my coffee. Very good coffee, too.

Rob (server) and the young lady at the door were very kind.

I would definitely come here for dinner or plan a special event here. Plus they have their own parking lot.

Great!

Well, now that Hong Kong Jack's is dead and gone - Chin's is THE only game in town for Classic Chinese-American.  (There are 2 small take out joints that keep changinbg hands down 611 toward Warrington).

Chin's offers perfectly safe Cantonese and a few Szechuan dishes - and all the classics you'd expect.  Service is fast (especially if you call in a take out order and then drive over to pick it up) and friendly.

Our only gripe?  They don't open until 2 PM on Sundays - so lunch on a Sunday is out.

I stick with the salads here, although a coworker gets the stir fry and likes it.  The Cobb Salad (I make a few changes to it using the touch screen ordering sustem) is a bit steep ($12 when I get through with it.) but the portion is immense and I can eat some at 3 or 4 PM if I get hungry again that day.  It will not keep well the next day.

The staff is underpaid and disinterested which I fear will cause long term service issues.  The 2 guys at the wok - working very hard - were clearly ticked off about something.  Then, the oven started to smoke.

Crispy-drama at lunch.

OMG, Dunkin' has taking over the universe - including Suburban Station with multiple outposts.

That said I never eat donuts, but I do occasionally succumb to temptation and get a hot or ice latte as is seasonally appropriate.

Passero's in Suburban has far superior coffee and food but is also more money - natch.

It is still cheaper that Charbucks (FiveBucks?) and they have oodles of flavors/syrups (I pass on those.)

For a "regular" cuppa joe - Dunkin or Wawa are my go-to's.
Thanks for being here when we need you, Dunkin. You are taking over the WORLD.

Fantastic Thai - the same stuff as the now-closed Thai Chef in Philly.
Tom Kha (Coconut) soup is divine and not too thick and not too watery.
DUCK Pad Thai was a bit sweet but the noodles and duck were both perfectly cooked.

(MEAT of choice) - we opted for pork - in Thai Basil sauce was very mildly spicy (tolerable for even a light-weight).  Delish.

Casual, friendly service.

I contacted Pitruco about hosting a private event.  They were responsive and wonderful.  While my budget won't support it right now ($750 minimum for about 50 people at $15 per person), I will definitely consider them for future events. (The event I am having is for about 20-25 people only.)

If you are having a big graduation party or family reunion, it'd be so cool to have the Pitruco truck roll up and crank out fresh pies for your guests.

A gal's gotta dream...
Maybe some day Pitruco will come rolling up to MY driveway.

Stopped here on an early Saturday morning, with "mixed precipitation"  to use the restrooms and grab a Starbucks.  There was NO LINE at Starbucks - wow!  Usually there is a huge one.

Very pleasantly surprised with the Starbucks.

Bathrooms need a touch up - a few toilets had urine in them - unflushed.  Ick.

Cold Hiyashi Ramen (regular with Cha su or Vegetarian) is a summertime treat.
I get mine with the sauce/dressing on the side.

Blissful carbo-loading.

I got there at 11:45 just before the lunch rush hit and got in and out with my take out bag.  Sweet!

3 or 4 stars depending on what you get.  Yes, you can eat there but there is zero atmosphere - so we get it as take-out.  My vegan kid likes the vegetable lo mein (no egg).

A little greasy, inexpensive - reminds us of the take out Chinese we used to get in Brooklyn.

No frills, no issues.

Is it the most amazing food ever?  Heck no, but it is cheap, fast and tasty and once in a while we will come here.  Counter-man/Manager is always kind to us - never had a problem with service.

Hornberger's delivered a lovely two-tiered mini wedding cake to our office for a wedding shower.  The buttercream icing and sugar flowers over a tasty (dense) vanilla (pound?) cake was delicious and gorgeous.

Easily fed 20 people (4 inch round over a 6 or 8 inch??).

Had a great take-out meal from Chin's on Monther's Day (did not want to deal with crowds at restaurants).  Beef and brocolli, chicken with cashew nuts, spare ribs, one egg roll (for my old-school relatives), pepper steak, house-special fried rice (really good) and chicken lo mein.

All were hot and fresh (They open at 2 on Sundays) and better than last time.

Tip:  ask for "light on the sauce" to mitigate the grease factor.

3.5 stars - I will be gracious and round up to 3.
Creed's is reminiscent of a by-gone era.  (Seafood Shanty?  Conti's Cross Keys Inn?)  It definitely has an old-school vibe in décor, service and food.

The food itself was actually excellent. We went for lunch and it was around $45 including tax and tip for 2 (no booze, no desserts).
I had a shrimp cobb salad and the ingredients were all super fresh and tasty.  
My friend had a very nice looking (but small) crab cake over spinach.

Service was attentive and fine - but this is NOT a place to go if you are in a rush.
Leisurely.  Sedate.  Safe.  (No nouveau cuisne here, no fusion)  A good place to take your parents - or rather have them take YOU.  Bring money!

Located inside the Booth's Corners Farmers Market (Hours are limited to Fridays and Saturdays except during holidays and special events when there could be more hours).  Grecian Delights is an inexpensive and absolutely DELICIOUS counter-style restaurant.  Nikki - our server - was terrific and the gyros, grilled chicken, salad, tzatziki and especially that Avgolemono soup were all Yia-Yia approved.

I can't wait to dine here again - or get a $20 gyro special (with a big salad and baklava) to go for a quick dinner for 2.

I LOVE IT.

Super yum!!!

There used to be 2 KC's but I think the one on 11th Street has closed.
Thank goodness the 10th Street location still purveys oodles of freshly baked breads, cakes and sugar-y confections.

The fried donuts and buns are so good - and when you get them while they're hot - Oh what a treat.

I vote each election at the nearby Chinatown fire department - so I pass buy KC's on my way to work after I vote.  I always get a croissant (Chinese style) or a sponge cake "cone" wrapped in paper.

It is decadent to munch away on such a treat while riding the SEPTA bus west on Market.

And all for under $1.50!!!!

Sign me up!

For $11.95 the lunch special - includes drink and choice of Tom Yum soup, Dumplings, Egg Roll (fried) or Fresh Spring Roll (Summer Roll - not fried) is a very nice meal.

I have tried the Bun (Rice Vermicelli also, Masuman Curry (very good) and Tofu with Eggplant.

A little greasy and sweet - but solid Viet/Thai especially for out here.
The Philly area's Thai choices are lacking.  This place is Vietnamese with a few Thai dishes also.

So far I have come 3 times for lunch - and that is after visiting Thai Orchid nearby twice.  This place - for me anyway - is better.

Soooo cheap and very good cakes and sponge cones.  My daughter loves it here.  They also have numerous flavors of bubble tea.

We have come here 3 times now for the delcious cream cake, shrimp dumplings (fried and greasy - but pretty tasty, too.) and superb egg custard tarts.

2 tiny tables to sit at - so get it to go if you can.  DD & I tend to sit and people watch.  She just LOVES it here and the nice ladies behind the counter love her.

Very reasonble prices, too.  They treat my blue-eyed, sandy haired 4 year old like a rock star.  She's give it 6 stars!

Today (a Wednesday) was my first go at the East Norriton Salad Works.
Since the mad rush was over on Tuesday (Every Tuesday all "standard" salads are $6.99), there was hardly any line on a Wednesday.

I got a "pick 2" combo - 1/2 an avocado BLT and a 1/2 salad.
Everything was fine and even the lettuce mix was fresh.

No issues so far.
I will be back - but NOT on a Tuesday.  It's worth 2 extra dollars to NOT wait in that line.
I may experiment with online pick-up ordering.  But I fear the Tuesday crowds.

I am very thankful to Kennedy Food Garden for being there over the years.
Rebecca at the front counter and the deli guys are friendly and service oriented.

The shrimp salad is still a fave as well as the kasha and potato knishes.

I can get milk, juice and sliced fruits and veggies here in a pinch.

They are my winter savior!

Even though I much prefer to shop at the Giant in Aston (or Whole Foods in Glen Mills when time and budget permits), I stopped in here and customer service was so, so, so much better than at Giant.

I bought a jar of jam for my dad and it turned out not to be the right kind.
They took it back 5 days later (unopened, of course) with no receipt. This is a rare occurrence and I was hoping they would not give me any problems.

I am very pleased.

I really love Harvest - but during peak times the acoustics are LOUD!!!!!
Our server Ian was terrific and explained the menu and dishes well.  My husband enjoyed the shortrib entree.  Potstickers ($10 - ouch!) were fried and IMO over cooked.

I enjoyed the quinoa salad - and a small was plenty for me ($6) and loved the shrimp (2 large deliciously seasoned shrimp) crabmeat cocktail served over gazpacho and a thick slice of yellow tomato.

Love it here - and can't wait to come back.
A little pricey but great for a date or a family meal.

A nice place to hang out and eat/drink/shop.  They've done a nice job with it.  I wonder though, if you live in one of those big, new buildings, does the noise level in the summer (especially on Saturday nights) preclude a quiet family life??

Just sayin'...

Valentine's Day weekend and service by Laura was wonderful even if we could only get a 5 PM or 8:30 PM res.  We opted for 5 PM and there was still a huge crowd.

Appetizer sampler ($20) was great as well as Duck App. The kiddo devoured it.
Sashimi was MUCH fresher and better this time including the ($27) Blue Fin lover's plate and a few pieces of toro ($8 a pop) and Ikura ($4.50).

No room for dessert but we left happy.

This is a review of the Macy's located in the Cheryy Hill mall.  We had a fun day of shopping noth at Nordstrom and here at Macy's.  My friend got 2 amazing pair of shoes at great prices.

The sales are worth checking out.

Many thanks to the Acme on Baltimore Pike in Media for supporting our girl scout troops and graciously allowing them to seel Girl Scout cookies at their stores.

We are so grateful for this!
A good choice for local produce in season - strawberries, preserves and tomatoes in the summertime.

OK, now that my 3 year old is nearly 7 - this place is a wee bit more appropriate.  (Incidentally she had her 6th birthday party and will have her 7th also at North Bowl).  Meanwhile - we popped in for a quick game (she bowled - I watched - our poor server, Dennis (bless his heart) served us 2 glasses of water).  $11.00 for 1 game ($5.95) plus show rental.

Sheesh.  Glad I didn;t order a cocktail.

Meanwhile - the BASE price for a kis party here is now $25 a head.

The music was very loud - but they turned it down for us.
Lanes are clean and seating is comfortable.

Very "clubby" - just as it was when we came here years ago.

The 7 year old loves it! (But - she did say that she likes North Bowl better - and so do I for many reasons.)

It sure ain't the crappy old bowling alley that I grew up with!

Did they re-model?
Something seems better about this beer-stocked deli - snacks, sandwiches and all the usual suspects.

A wide selection of cold drinks.

Good location - and hours.

No issues from me.

Woo Jung (Brother is Woo, Sister is Jung) is a Korean owned Japanese place (with Hwe Dup Bap on the menu!) in a strip mall in East Norriton.  I was honestly scared to even try it but I am so glad I did.  The staff is wonderful and my experience was terrific as a single diner on a dead-empty Friday lunch.

I ordered the $16.95 lunch special which came with 6 pieces of sashimi (all were excellent - included seared/sauced Chu-Toro!  Score!!!!!!) and 3 nigiri (Tuna, Salmon and a white fish - not sure which - not yellowtail).  The accompanying spicy tuna roll was delicious as well.

Miso soup had a slight sweetness of Mirin.
Very nice.

I can't wait to return!!

BYO - and a little pricey for lunch but worth it for a special treat.
Now, maybe they'll add some galbi to the menu???

Thank you, Jung!!!!!

I can not believe how clean, new, slick, friendly and pleasant my experience was at the new (actually 5 mos. old) Panda Express, fast-food Chinese in the Comcast Center.

Normally I can not stand sloppy, gloppy, steam-table, mall Chinese - so boy was I shocked when the food not only looked great (albeit lots of the choices and all of the shrimp choices are fried) but tasted good, too.

Trepidatious bynature I ordered only a small a la carte (1/2 pint) box of Honey Walnut Shrimp (Fried + Mayonnaise + Sugar = health BOMB) and instantly recalled the bygone era of late 1980's Chinese-American fare.

The Manager, Jay,  was very accomodating and said that now - for large orders (and within a few blocks) they will deliver and the offer party trays and catering.  The even have a deal they will do with schools for fundraising.

The wheels are turning...  Perhaps a Panda Feast (for $30 you get 3 large entress and 2 large sides - enough for 4 (easily) to 7 (tiny eaters) people.  A big pan entree $36 - $48 if you pick shrimp feeds about 8 people.

They also have a small catering package for $96 that easily feeds 16.

I am planning a prty soon and will update my review with the results - but so far I am shockingly pleased with Panda Express.

A solid 4 stars (the Beet Salad was 5 star for me) with swanky decor, clean restrooms, great service from Tim and a healthy wine list.  (A few more sparklers by the glass would be nice.

I loved the beet salad app (Got a small for $5) served with pickled SWEET cippolini onions and served atop a small amount of tasty goat cheese cream (not too goaty).  I also enjoyed the mushroom papardelle - loaded with asparagus, garlic slices and of course - lots of 'shrooms.

My partner's food came out cold - but they promptly heated it up.
His sweet potato mash was far to nutmegy for me - but the side of mac 'n cheese ($5) was terrific.  Bison meatloaf was $22 and served with baby carrots and broccolini (a bit salty).

Not 5 stars - but very close - a lovely lunch was $66 without booze and without dessert - so that is a bit pricey.  (My cappucino was $6 - OUCH.

I agree with Caroline AND Emily.  We take our little girl here and she LOVES it - especially all the animals.

They have activities in every season - even winter time.
Xmas trees, Halloween Hay rides, Strawberry picking in spring.

Love it!

And yes - we make her wash her hands after petting the goats and before eating ice cream (or apple turnovers!!!)

Aliitle touristy and a few items in the market have HIGH prices - but hey - the loval produce is terrific.  We love it here.

Had dinner at the sushi bar on a busy Saturday night (no reservation so no tables available - but plenty of sushi bar spots early on).  Excellent service by our server and expediter as well as the 2 "junior level" sushi chefs.

DH ordered edamame and chicken teri (yeah, I know) which he enjoyed.
I had a small (which was huge - I can't imagine how enormous the large must be) Tom Kha which is one of my faves.  I have had Tom Kha at many places and the Tom Kha hear was overly sweet and thick with too much coconut milk and lacked the lemongrass and complexityy that a good Tom Kha should have.  That said - it was tasty but bland.  not exciting at all. Would not reorder it here unless I am having an intense Tom Kha Craving.

The Blue Fin lovers platter was deliciously fresh - and the complimentary veggie naruto roll was crisp and refreshing.

Since aside from Temaki in Media, this is the best sushi we have found (Yes, we've tried Margaret Kuo's and Azie)  we shall return.  And next time we'll make a reservation!

Oh - and the prices are on the high side.

Free internet access and (as I happen to be an ING account holder) access to your banking.

Plus if you wear orange (like that EVER happens??) on certain days your coffee is free.

Kitschy come-ons and cool swag to be had here as well.

I really enjoy banking with ING Direct and the coffe shop is a nice addition.

But they need to clean those bathrooms more often - or else they'll be downgraded to 3 or even 2 stars.  They get GROSS!!!

My daughter enjoys the "square pizza" slices here (She refers to Sicilian as "square pizza") but even she at the astute age of 8 commented, "It's good - but not as good as Brooklyn".

Sums it up perfectly.

Smart kid.  Like her Momma.

We had a terrific time here on opening day (3/27/09) and had makeovers at the jam-packed Chanel counter in the jam-packed cosmetics department.  Scored some great new eyeshadows and Glossimer.

We ogled the David Yurman counter and tried on some fancy shoes.

I adore Nordie's and am so glad there is now one nearby.

No atmosphere - but pretty decent grub - 3.5 stars really, but I feel generous and will give them 4.  The atmosphere is about a 2.

I love the Kasha Knishes here - warmed up they taste almost like the ones I'd get out in Brooklyn.  They also make a good shrimp salad and it's always fresh.  They have a high turnover in the deli case - which keeps the cold cuts fresh.

Very nice people working there, too.

Oh - and it's very inexpensive to eat here - or pick up some groceries and take out foods if you don't feel like cooking.

I am glad they exist - higher prices and all (for groceries) because the convience factor is a big plus - especially in inclement weather.

Without Kennedy and Whole Foods - we'd be sunk.

I am not a fan of Darden/Chain restaurants and my expectations were quite low when a friend suggested we meet for dinner at Bahama Breeze near the King of Prussia Mall.

I arrived a bit early and sat at the bar and had a very nice (classic) mojito.
There is a huge selection of overly sweet and fruity drinks - so a "regular" mojito seemed like a good pick for me.  

My friend arrived and the super-friendly hostess took us to our table.
To start we shared the crab/shrimp stack - very good and fresh tasting.

So many items on the menu are fried or otherwise dietary disasters.

For an entrée I chose (and enjoyed) the grilled salmon with a mango glaze and pineapple salsa.  It was cooked to my liking and not at all dry.  It came with (untrimmed!!!! ick..) haricot vert and sweet plantains.  

I wound up taking about 1/3 of it home - and my kid devoured it instantly.

No room for dessert  - so we paid and left.

I would come back here - but it's not my favorite place.
Meanwhile, for my first time EVER at a BB - it was pretty darned good.
Great service - which surprised me.

I could write a novel about all the great things we have experienced because of Joe Gunn, Chef Adan and the entire staff at Jose Pistola's.

My 8 year old competed in the 2013 MANNA Guac-Off - where Chef Adan's tuna and sambal topped guac took 1st place (my kid came in 5th - which is not too shabby!).

Since then, Chef Adan and Joe have been so gracious to our family and we finally got a chance to experience a veritable feast of Mexican wonders (some with an Asian twist) with 5 star service all the way.

We truly enjoyed the Scallop tiradito, Classic Guac (and the mango pomegranate one), Freshly muddled pear mojitos, anything with that Korean Rib in it (I had a quesadilla), Lobster Tacos ($18 for two) and HUGE burritos.  (My husband loved the short-rib one.)
Choco-Flan and Churros completed the meal - but we were so full we could barely touch them. (Some how we managed (wink-wink).)

The kiddo loved her black bean and BACON (she asked for it special and they made it for her) quesadilla.  Fan-frikkin-tastic!

Can't wait to return.  We were treated like royalty.

We can't thank you enough!!!

Nook graciously supported my kids old day care and donated 24 mini cupcakes.
I won them - and used them for my child's first grade class.  They were the perfect size and came in chocolate and vanilla.  Cute sprinkles on top, too.

Will definitely come back for more cupcakes and to try the coffee drinks.

Excellent, friendly service.

We are thankful for their support and yummy treats,

Came for Christmas Eve with the fam and the place was packed with families and people of all ages.  Excellent service and much higher quality sushi - but TINY portions.  Appetizer was $15 and barely 3 bites.

Meanwhile we loved all that we ordered, especially the salmon tartare.

A great "special occaision" place.

This was my 4th or 5th visit to Harvest over the years and I still like it.  It's a bit steep on the prices for the amount of food but every plate is under 500 calories (unless noted otherwise) so you get the right amount of food.

I had the summer menu for lunch with a delicious Tuna tartar and a Crab/Shrimp cocktail.  All the seafood was fresh tasting and nicely plated and garnished. My friend had a cedar-planked salmon which looked terrific.  Salads here are always fresh.

A $6 cappuccino (ouch) was my dessert.

Very lovely place for a corporate lunch or a date night or girl's night out.

I am assuming this is the four-bucks inside the Target in Glen Mills.
Went there today for a large order for a group and they were pleasant, helpful & quick.

No issues and so glad they are there.

My parents LOVE it here.  It is not a good place for kids, though.  They have a delicious tomato & fresh mozzarella salad - and of course, there's always the BEER.  (They actually brew a substantial amount of it here.)

Dad likes the sandwiches.

It's a nice choice in the midst of the Peddler's Village tourist-trap eats.
I prefer this to the Cock 'n Balls any day.

This is my go-to diner in Media and I enjoy the home made pierogies (even for breakfast!) and grilled shrimp salad very much.

Other items can be hit & miss.
They also have some unique specials like the shortrib-stuffed ravioli.

Service is friendly and great - they are nearly empty on weekdays for dinner time but JAMMED for breakfast on weekends.

Standard diner fare with a few unique home-made touches.

Still lovin' it here - a little pricey ($60 for lunch for 2 sans alcohol/dessert) but so fresh tasting.
Try the Swordfish with crab on top if they still have it.

Summer salads are loaded with heirloom tomatoes that actually taste like ripe, sweet tomatoes.  A lovely selection of ($3) mighty leaf teas.

A great place for date night or dinner with the fam.

Very happy.

The food tastes fine - and the cafeteria style of "design your own" burritos, tacos and quesadillas is catching on fast -but don't be fooled.  It's still fast food - and it is super-duper HIGH in calories.  A typical burrito has 1100 - 1600 calories.  (Naked will reduce it by 330 - as the PLAIN TORTILLA is 330 whopping calories alone.)

That said - I do enjoy the Naked Chicked Burrito, no cheese, small (70 cal) taco-sized torilla on the side.

It's just too hard for me to "hold the guac" and save 220 calories.  That guac - for fast food guac tastes muy bien to me.

By the way - I think Jack-in-the-box owns Qdoba - I know Chipotle is owned by McDonalds.

FAST FOOD - people.
Eat under a health advisory.

Recently changed owners and slowly making improvements.
They still have the BEST La Colombe coffee beverages including lattes, cappuccino, mocha and breve.

Gelato, pastries and a few sandwich options.

Love it here.

This is a really good place - a bit pricier than I'd like - but worth it.  BIG margarita's and a good selection of entrees.  And yes, as said below, it is nice that they use MANCHEGO cheese and not some generic American alternative.

This is as close as you can get to authentic Mex in Bucks County.

Iron Hill redeemed themselves tonight with truly stellar service from Bob and Ashley who gave my 8 year old an impromptu brewery tour in the middle of a Sunday Night dinner service.

French onion soup was SPLENDID and not a bit too salty.  Wonderful and worth the close to $7.  Nacho platters are huge but one suggestion - cheese is needed throughout - not just on the top layer of chips (The end is naked chips)..  DD loved the pasta carbonara with shrimp added ($4 more) and had her sauce on the side so she could decide if she liked it or not.  She did.

A real winner tonight.

We'll be back again.

The Pineville Tavern has changed hands several time over the past 35 years.  In its current incarnation (apparently since 1989 - dayamn I am shoing my age), the food is much improved and it is more of a "real" restaurant - or perhaps a "Gastropub" than a bar.

You can still get sandwiches and burgers and brews, but now you get get real meals as well.

Sit in the back and it feels less like a bar (the bar's out front.)

Update: Oh - and no, I had no idea when I wrote this review that Pineville tavern was gonna be on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives tomorrow night!  ACK!  I bet they'll get real busy!

This is a review for one of the many Nina's waffles & ice cream trucks.  Our company paid for the truck to come out to our facility in Plymouth Meeting, PA for about 2 hours on a hot summer afternoon.

Each employee had a choice of a waffle and/or ice cream or a waffle cone with ice cream.  Many toppings were available.  I chose the waffle (fresh, hot, liege style) with home-made espresso crunch ice cream and a drizzle of chocolate ganache.

The man who made them (fresh - to order) was lovely as well.

WONDERFUL and indulgent treat.

A great idea for a corporate event or large party - rent the waffle truck!

The bakeries in Bucks County have not been that great, but Crossroads is surprisingly good - anbd busy as a beehive on Saturday mornings.

My daughter's itty-bitty (.95 cents) chocolate cupcake was the perfect size of deliciousness and I enjoyed a flaky buttery croissant.

I was very impressed with what we tried and would definitely come back again.

Went to Ben & Irv's during Covid (sat inside - everyone wore a mask when no seated) and Michelle, our server, was beyond wonderful.

Half Sour Pickles are always a good thing.
Classic Deli food with HUGE sandwiches (and prices to match).

Sadly, not as good as some other places - the chopped liver was just OK and the kreplach soup was good but not amazing (next time, Matzoh ball - a better choice).

Plus:  You can order your take out while you eat so it will be ready when you are ready to leave.

Excellent service and good but not orgasmic food.

7 Stones is the perfect blend of hippie and hipster.
Iced La Colombe Coffee, Sandwiches, Salads and a friendly (cute) young barista.

A lovely place for a REAL cuppa.

Back in the early '90's this place was truly innovative - and it still has many, admirable programs and activities.  We nicknamed the White Dog the "Adjective cafe".

A simple dish of corn frittersmight be labeled as:

"Warm fresh sweet corn and roasted red pepper fritters"

The entire menu was so loaded with adjectives that it was hard to find was the noun was!

Anyhow - the food was/is, indeed, very good and many of the ingredients are local or at least regional and organic whenever possible.  I really admire the work that White Dog has done and the viable business they have built.

Go, dog, go!

We had a far better experience at the Ardmore location of NYAJ than we ever did at the Glen Mills one.

First of all the layout, crowd and vibe are a bit different.
We arrived in stages - 7 women in total - and our delightful, albeit overworked server, Melvin, came right away with bread and "dipping oil".

Since we arrived in time for happy hour (must order by 7 PM) we were treated to $5 Sangria, Margarita or Pineapple Pain Killers.  The Sangria, to me, was the tastiest of the 3.  

$6 apps included sliders in 3 varieties (any combination you choose), cheeseburger, mini crab cake (great) or buffalo chicken.  We also tied the waffle fries and lettuce wraps (from the regular menu) and carrot cake for dessert.

We had a great time socializing and listening to the (loud) 80's and 90's background music. 

Shout out to MELVIN for top-tier service.

A good place for take out - they do have a room with card tables & chairs next door for eat-in, but the decor just screams - take out.

 An old-school staff of pizza makers crammed into the busy kitchen turns out terrific FRESHly baked pies.  The cheese, pepperoni/sausage and veggie combo we ordered were terrific.  2 large pies fed 6 adults and 3 yound children.  The veggie pie was my fave - with roasted red & green peppers, broccoli and spincah - so tasty.

I recommend the pizza here.

We had great service (yes, really) from Ariel at Hildago - and the place was nearly empty (so maybe that helped).  My shrimp quesadilla (simple) was excellent and the Sopa Azteca was great, too.   Not cheap - and the $7.95 guacamole, while fresh, was not nearly as good as Dos Gringos nor my 12 year old kid's version.

Meanwhile, the food here is way, way better than at Diego's.

We are so glad to have them here in Media.

A little pricey for what it is...
Free iced coffee giveaway was perfect!

We have always enjoyed the food at the Polish Festival - but you can also get some of the basics (Pierogies, Cabbage Rolls/Gulabki, Coffee and Babka) year-round in the rec-room/cafeteria area under the shrine.

Not particularly inexpensive though - so bring a bit more cash than you might think.  Brings me back to those Polish-fest days!

I am writing thuis review kinda sorta on behalf of my dad (who might even give them 5 stars - he loves it here.).  I have only been here twice and both times (with my parents, of course - who LOVE the fresh mozzarella salad and prime-rib (or is it filet) beef sandwiches.

The first time we went my daughter was a wee 6 or 7 months old and I was in a post-partum haze.  The experience was a drag from soup to nuts.  (Nevermind that we did not order any soup nor nuts).  Mom ordered and raved about her fresh (and milky white) mozzarella and tomato salad.  Dad was in red-meat heaven.

Strangely enough we never actually get any beer here.  (The 'rents don't drink it.)

Then little angel-pie decided to pee in her diaper.  So I had to change her diaper.  And things got ugly.  There was NO WHERE - and I mean no where to change her.  The ladies room was a one-person operation with NO changing tabel and no area.  The floow in there seems icky.

So I whipped out my portable changing pad (waterproof) and tried to subtley and quickly change her on a tabletop in the back hallway.

I was immediately yelled at by a (male) manager to stop.  I basically ignored him - as I was nearly done anyway) and finished wiping the babies butt, threw the dirty things in a plastic baggie, threw the baggie backinto my diaper bag and went back to the table.

I was so ticked off.  I mean, what was I supppsoed to do - there was NO WHERE to change this kid.  A 6 month old baby.

Whatever.

So anhow - thety have great food and a terrific selection of salads - but don't bring a non-potty trained kid here.  (In our case an infant.)

Rant over.

Surprisingly wonderful.  This opld-school diner has friendly "career" waitresses and serves a terrific french onion soup. (Not too salty - and just the right amount of golden brown bubbling chees on top.)

Don't miss the home-made pierogies - a plate of 3 (large) one sauteed in ample amounts of butter and sweet onions.  BLISS (and calories) on a plate.

We really enjoyed stopping in here while house-hunting in the Media area and plan to return.

Every summer/fall I stock up on Billy's fantastic poultry-based (he makes pork based also) sausages which he sells at the Media Farmer's market.  I can't wait to get to his (new location) place in Wilmington.  The chicken/broccoli rabe and chicken/spinach/provolne sausages are delectable.

As aforementioned, parking is inadequate here - but if you go on a Sunday morning you can park at a metered spot in the street and walk across.

A bit pricey - especially for produce - but staples like milk and eggs are on par with Acme or Giant.  Lots of gourmet items and prepared foods.

A nice "chi-chi" market in yuppified D-town.

A great selection of molded chocolate confections and other candies and goodies.
Conveniently located in the RTM.

Bark, non-pareils, peanut butter cups, chocolate covered pretzels, rats, bats and Halloween and Christmas chocolates, too.

Fun!

Pleasantly surprisedby the quality of the food.  Small Plate option of a single Salmon Spring Roll ($5.50) was perfect.  Quinoa Salad was nice but thank goodness I got the cloyingly sweet dressing on the side.  Loaded with sugary fruit puree too.

It's close by - so we'll be back.

John, the owner is such a nice man.
He gave my daughter 2 pretzels and a pretzel dog (with or without cheese).

The pretzels were cooked evenly and not too gooey nor burnt, however there was alot of salt which she picked off.

Good pretzels and located near our house.

We came back to Hildago with another couple who are regulars and they directed me to order the pork tenderloin special, served in a delicious chiorizo sauce and stuffed with Jamon and cheese,   It was amazing. I likened it to a Mexican riff on Pork Saltimboca,

Amazing!

Ariel (The owner's daughter) is lovely as always and the fresh pico, guacamole ($8) an chips are a must.

We love you, Hildago!

Very impressed with the service and food for our group of 8 (supposed to be 12 but 4 people bailed) on a busy Saturday night.  French Onion Soup was perfect - not too salty and not too greasy.

Others enjoyed burgers, veggie quesadilla (loaded with 'shrooms) and guacamole (very good).
Fried calamari is not my thing but the table enjoyed it.

Prices seem to have risen a bit - but it was never "cheap" here.
A great selection of beers of all sorts.  Decent (but pricey) cocktails  ($9 - $13).

Massimo's pizza is located in Booth's Corner's Farmers Market and thus has limited hours.
I got 2 slices and 3 (rather large) garlic knots to go for my 14 year old.
She ate one of the slices (plain) and 2 of the $1 a piece knots right away and seems to really love it.

Later for a second meal she ate the other knot and the remaining slice of "upside-down" pizza - just like plain cheese pizza but cheese is under the sauce.

She liked them both but prefers the classic Neapolitan pie to the "upside down" pie.

All in all?  At $2.50 a slice this is a good way to get pizza by the slice - they have a ton of choices including "square" Sicilian, tomato pie, Hawaiian and many more.

And the garlic knots are, indeed, yummy.

Went to the "unofficial" yelp event last night at ten stone.
Even though I am old and farty and not much of a bar-chick, we had a great time.

It was a lovely evening and we were able to snag a nice table outside.  My husband and a friend of mine ordered beers and I had a vodka cranberry.  (Made with the house vodka - it was pretty bad - I should asked for Grey Goose - Oh, WELL.).

A bit later we got hungry so we ordered a spinach and apple/goat cheese/candied cashews salad (YUM!), a chipotle chicken wrap, a big mug of spicy chicken chili, and another big mug of edamame.  Reaqlly quite good for "bar food".

I will definitely be back!

I dream of El Limon's Al Pastor - it's so good.
The guacaomle/Salsa/chips combo for $5 is a great value.
My kid devoured her huge $9.95 shrimp burrito.  (Dry - but you can also have it with one of 3 terrific sauces).

Even DH enjoyed his salad with Asada.

Love this place - and a free margarita if you simply ask.

Brand spankin' new Chipotle in Media/Lima, PA near the old Granite Run Mall (that has been demolished for brand new stores like this).

We are so glad you are here.

Love those burrito bowls.
Please stop charging over $2 extra for guac.  At Qdoba guac is free (price is built in to base price though.)

Love the kids meals - enough for a grown up.

We had an amazingly great time - food and service (by the lovely Maria) with our party of 6.
It was the first day of the "new" OctoberFest menu and we surely enjoyed it.  Mustard Crusted Salmon, Caesar Salad, Chicken and Pork Schnitzel and of course, great beer and beverages.

The only thing preventing a 5 star rating?  Deafeningly loud - as it was quite crowded (Saturday at 1 PM_ and we sat right near the open kitchen.

Service was quick and attentive.

Lovely!

I dunno - we come here about once a week and never have had an issue - my kid is a vegan so her "bowl" is rice, beans, pico and guac.  Never a problem.  Young staff but they are always fine to us.

Not sure why others have so many problems?   But yes, they do need to clean more.

Run by teens.
Fast food.
Not expecting the "Ritz".

A great dining area with casual places like the crepe place, a juice bar, Buddy's Burgers, Noodle Bowls and an OPlive Oil/Balsamic Vinegar place.

Fun to browse around and eat lunch here.

O.M.Goodness.
The hangover burger could easily be called the Heart Attack burger.

If you are ravenously hungry and have lipitor on hand, then try it.
I ate 1/2 (and a side salad instead of fries) and I need a nap.\

Perfectly cooked burger on a brioche bun with bacon, cheddar cheese and a fried egg.

My diet has been calorie bombed!

Took the other half home.
So good.  So bad.  So good.

I stopped in after seeing the takeout food a coworker got at my new job - 2 minutes away.  It seems like a typical strip-mall take out spot with about 5 green-jade plastic tables.

The whole family runs the place and my pint of Beef & Broccoli (6.75) was just fine - asked for light sauce but still was not so light. The grandson (son?) was there and he is so cute - about 4 years old.  Nice younger lady running the front counter.

You can also get a lunch special from $5 - $7 which includes pork fried rice or white rice.

I will be back - but I don't do Chinese too often.
Maybe in 2 weeks...

Strip mall is easy to get in but hard to drive out of (202 and another busy , divided highway).

Note:  They do not provide water nor ice so you HAVE to purchase a bottle of water (or a soda) or else go without if you are dining in.  I caved and bought a diet coke, but next time I am bringing my own water.

A new-year's day feast with my 12 year-old salmon-loving kid and great sushi.
We actually tried to come at 2:40 PM - they are CLOSED from 2:30 - 5 PM (no "linner").

Lunch is a MUCH better value than dinner, but we love the spicy tuna ball appetizer and salmon plate.  (Ask if they have toro and/or salmon belly - as both are terrific.)
The Tropicana roll ($7.95) is a tasty also.

Friendly service and not crowded.

My friend lives in Kennett Square and I just HAD to get an iced coffee - so off to the trusty Dunkin' we went.

Average prices, place was dead-empty at 4 PM (so speedy service) and all the "usual" DD suspects.

America may run on Dunkin - but Dunkin runs on me!

Long live the iced latte light!

This Dunkin has a drive thru - but in the morning coffee rush (7:30 ish) I usually park and go in -it's faster.

I come here on my way to work.
decent service and clean dining area.

Just got back from IHOP in warrington (down 611) for an early (8:30 AM) breakfast on Labor Day.  Thus they are getting a nice, pleasant, non-mobbed 4 fat beautiful stars from me.

There were 5 in our party and (miracle of miracles) we were seated promptly and cheerfully greeted by a smilling late-teen server "Kelsey".

We ordered pancakes, crepes, eggs and omelettes all around and everything was hot, freshly made and served the way we specified.  I  much prefer IHOPs pancakes to Perkins - but my 3 year old has never met a pancake she did not like.  I also love the crepes - I omit the giant wad of butter-like spread they plop in the middle.  Who needs to eat THAT much fat?

2 for 2!

Now the best part - the check came quickly and was accurate, too boot.

In the past this IHOP has been a crazed 2-3 star mass of strollers and screaming children.  But today's miracle breakfast was just a J.O.Y.

Stay tuned for an update.  (Don't go here during peak times - it's a frikkin' zoo.)

We don't "do" fast food - but - we will on occaision take our little one (now 7 - went there more when she was 4,5 or 6) to play there and eat chicken and fruit cup.

It's fried.  It's not that great for you - but it's way better than McDonald's or BK.
Plus the kids just love that play area.

So we love Chik-Fil-A - on special occaisions.

Absolutely no issues - we came at 7:15 PM on a Wednesday night in the summer - so no line and thankfully, no dried-out old food.

My kid got a steak burrito to go and I did not have to cook.

Seriously.  No issues.

A welcome addition to State Street and a good place to take the kids for a cup or cone of house-made ice cream.

Flavors change periodically but the always have chocolate, cookies and cream, vanilla and at least a few fruit flavors. (Sorbetto?)

Delicious fresh fish, but pricey.
Lunch (Just a special) was $15.95 - so $20 after tax and tip with no beverage.

5 pieces of nigiri and a delightful spicy tuna roll.
The sushi chef (there were 3 or 4 when I went at lunchtime) was de-scaling a huge and beautiful snapper.  Wow.

I still wanted more - LOL.
Friendly server and dark, but elegant digs.

A strange smell when we entered though - not awful or I would have left.

Meanwhile, I can't afford to have lunch here on a regular basis.  The full/dinner menu looks amazing - so maybe I will try a dinner here.

Severino supplies fresh and frozen pasta to restaurants and gourmet stores all over the area.
Good stuff!  And a great selection.

The basic linguine and fettucine are staples for us.
Stuff pastas like cheese ravioli and tortellini are also excellent.

Yuki is now DD & my go-to place for a mid-priced Sushi lunch.  We even take some of DD's friends there and they all love it.  The $25 salmon plate is a bit pricey but at lunch time you can get a 5 piece sushi plate (with a Cali roll) for $12.95 - comes with (excellent) miso soup and (boring, but fresh) salad.

Service is quick and efficient.

Sushi chefs know el kiddo and treat her great!

A fantastic choice for a corporate lunch (or date night dinner) in the "LoMa" - Lower Market area of "downtown" Wilmington, DE.  I had a lunch salad ($16 - ouch but so good!) with pesto shrimp, pine nuts and fusili (just enough).

They also serve delicious La Colombe coffee beverages (I got a latte to go).

Too pricey to eat here every day for lunch but once every few weeks I will be returning for sure!  Fresh ingredients and lovely service.

So pleased.

Stopped in around 6 PM for a $2 promo small iced coffee and a 99 cent donut for el kiddo.

Young teen/college age kids running the show were bored (slow time at 6 PM in August) and disinterested.

Product was fine.

Parking lot truly sucks.

My (nearly) 9 year old LOVES Annie's - even more than Rita's.  Why?  You can get Jimmies (Sprinkles) on your water ice.  And they have the "pink one" (Is that Bubblegum or Cotton Candy) and the "blue" one (Blue Raspberry) and they have soft serve in cups or cones (just OK - I have had better frozen custards - but this is soft serve ice cream - not custard.).

Friendly young teens (mostly gals) working the counter and a line in the summertime.
Gravel parking lot and a big wooden porch to eat on.

If you are a kid?  This is part of a great summer experience.

Bring some small bills - do them a favor.

As a sushi lover, I was sooooo pleased to see this placeopen.  Owned by the same people from Shiroi Hana, I went here with high expectations.

My 5 year old and husband also loved our first meal here last night.  My little one spent a long time looking at the live (huge) scallops and giant orange clams still moving in their shells.

We ordered the shumai for the child (who loved them) and an asoortment of tasty and inventive rolls.  DH liked the triple spicy double tuna roll, and I liked the Hamachi Verde - which I ordered without Jalapeno (I'm a wimp).

We can't wait to come back and try more.

Consistently good.

A great meal last night - DD & I salmon-binged on a Salmon plate and a salmon sashimi appetizer.  The kind chef gifted us with some Salmon Toro, too!  #SlamminSalmon

For chain-BBQ, Mission is darned good. Certain items are better than others, IMO.
The ribs (both spare and baby backs) were fall-off-the-bone tender and super flavorful (even sans sauce).  That said, there are 6 or 7 sauces you can try including a vinegar-based Carolina one.  The ribs did not need sauce - the (dry) brisket, however, not even sauce could save.

The pulled chicken was also very good.

Brisket?  Too dry. 

Sides - mac & cheese, green beans (a little mushy) and cornbread all solid.

A great lunch choice.  And daily they sing the National Anthem at precisely 12 noon - so if you are in a rush get here by 11:45 AM.  The line forms quickly at 12:05 PM.
Breads, pastries and coffee.  Not cheap - but you get what you pay for.  It's GOOD stuff. Small place, gets crowded during the AM coffee rush.

This is a fairly new Chipotle.

I'm a Chipotle fan from back in my Manhattan days - so I was glad to see one open in Warrington.  While I must admit to liking Qdoba a tad more - Chipotle is my go-to place for a Burrito Bol (Naked Burrito) with Chicken, Black Beans and Guacamole.

It's fast and cheap - but watch those calories - I never get cheese and rarely get sour cream so I can justify that guac!

This branch of Chipotle is in a stand-alone building (did it used to be the Pizza Hut - I forget).  It has a cool-gray ambience - a bit industrial looking.  We usally get take out, though so we don't really care.

On the Sunday afternoon when we last visited, the place was loaded with families with young children.

Delicious - and a heck-of-a-lot more athentic Thai food in the Riverfront Market (3 S. Orange Street).

The owner and chef are so sweet and everything is cooked FRESH.  The Tom Ka (I had mine with Chicken) was spicier than I am used to (next time I'll get it wimp-i-fied) but was loaded with veggies, chicken and goodies.  REAL galangal and fresh kaffir lime leaves.

The real McCoy!

NB:  No credit cards.

I echo what many others have said - Wegman's is terrific - and a great choice for a take-home meal.  I got a salmon sushi platter that was so much better than any Acme or Giant (Blargh!) and a lovely selection from the fresh cold salad bar.

Next time I will try the hot foods.

It's such fun to shop here.

A brand-new, super-clean, SORELY needed, Starbucks with a busy drive through in "Brookheaven".  Brookhaven had nothing like this shopping center - until now.  A new Giant, a wine/spirits (State) store, Smashburger, Hand & Stone - and finally - a real Starbucks.

My advice?  Skip the drive through - especially if there are more than 4-5 cars ahead of you and just go in and get your stuff.

Hallelujah,
Great selection and value for fresh produce (and seafood) plus a vast array of international food products.  Good place.  $10 minimum to use credit/debit.

Now that I work nearby I stop in for a quick lunch at Wegman's from time to time - but I always spend way too much on sushi.  (13.99 for a 9 piece platter of nigiri.)
Delicious and fresh though.

I had an excellent first experience at TJs today for lunch in the dining room (the bar was too loud and crowded for my liking).  Cobb Salad was fresh and tasty with lots of white meat turkey and bacon. Crisp romaine.

Nice ambiance and a LARGE list of beers, stouts, porters, ciders and ales.

Can't wait to come back.

A little pricey - but OK.

Lunch specials for $6.99 are a decent value - a 1/2 cheesesteak (huge - can't imagine eating a whole one) and iceberg salad.

Kiddo had a single slice of plain pizza.
Loads of Large screen TVs to watch "the game".

Efficient service.

OK - first of all I got take out - so that might account for the lower review.
Secondly, I had bun  (not Pho) - but here's why I thought Pho Ha was good but not great:

Sugarcane shrimp was soggy (possibly due to take out)
Shredded carrots on top of the Bun were overly pickled/vinegary.

I will be back to try the Pho and the service was GREAT - so friendly and welcoming, but honetsly?  I've have way better bun at Pho Cali and numerous joints in Oakland, CA.

Good prices.

Update:  I went back for Pho (I got the one with diced tenderloin) and awesome Summer rolls.  Excellent.

I have been back a few times and the customer service here is wonderful - Miracle our cashier was so sweet and friendly.

I usually get the spare ribs now - I like them even better than the baby backs.
The "Black Plate" special can vary but once it was BBQ shrimp and they were delicious - I hope they bring them back.  Would love to try salmon, too.

FINALLY a decent sushi spot near my new digs.
It's not Nobu, nor Doma, but the service and decor were great (on a slow Wednesday night0 and best of all the Green Lobster Roll ($14.95) was amazing. (Fresh basil and lobster salad - get the sauces on the side!

Can't wait to come back and try some sashimi - to see how fresh the raw fish is here.

I'll be back!
I love Lee's - for decent cheese steaks and roast beef or turkey hoagies with all the fixin's. They renovated it after the fire and it looks great.  Nice guys (and a few gals) runnin' the show.

2 years later - and thank goodness, La Fia is still here and still has my favorite salads and sandwiches ($12 - $20) for lunch.  A good place to take a client or business colleague.  This part of Market Street needs more dining options so we are thankful La Fia is here!

I had a very different (and better) experience at Uncle Oogie's.  I thought it was GREAT!!!!  It's a Soufilly pizza joint with a small dining area.  We had terrific platters (each was around $12 and came with an enormous basket of delicious garlic bread.

We shoulda split a platter - because they were insanely huge platters of food.  Chicken Parm (delish) and Chicken Olivia - even better with spinach, roasted red pepper and a light balsamic sauce.   Served with spaghetti and tons of rich "gravy".

The meatballs are fried and the "real McCoy".  Delicious.

The "Old Italian" pizza is, indeed loaded with herbs so if you don't like basil - don't get that - but we loved it's thin square crust and lovely sauce.  They also offer a tomato pie and a Margarita in addition to the "plain cheese" pies.  Plus they offer white and specialty pies.

And the hoagies (especially the chicken ones) are huge, fresh and filling.

I love it here and can't wait to go back - or get take out. (But I bet it's better fresh outta the oven and eaten right there.)

This is a solid 3 start place but i am giving it 4 as the food I had happened to be excellent - but i ordered a special.  Lobster Salad on an English muffin with hollandaise (from a mix?? - I got it on the side and it came cold - so that part wasn't excellent).

Very good service for a relaxing lunch.  Not cheap - but not expensive either.
Medium price, medium food, and mediocre decor (needs a re-fresh from 1992).

Lots of older folks eat here - but they often know where the nice quiet places are.

I will definitely be back.

Very good service from our friendly female server.  (Can't remember her name.)
And a full bar!

Fantastic!  Real La Colombe espresso drinks and ice cream AND gelato.
My 11 year old went straight for the "creamsicle" gelato.  A small ($3.25) was plenty.

We had several varieties of Rustica Pizza at the Yelp Philly event on 7/31.  They were so yummy.  I tried the veggie pie with spinach, fresh sliced tomato and ricotta.  YUM!

I also tried a few bites of the Philly-cheese-steak style pie - sliced steak meat, cheese and onions.  (I picked out the onions - as I don't "do" onions).

Even though it's porbably AMAZING if you eat it fresh at their location - it was still AWESOME pizza for delivery.  I can't wait to go to the store and try a fresh pie.

One of the other yelpers has rustica on speed dial - and has it delivered to his home, office and even to certain bars.

Kewl.

Back again and had Mahi Mahi tacos (and a friend got Shrimp tacos) so we each had one of each.

DELISH.

Perfect Arnold Palmer too - and great service in the bar area.


I am lovin' this place more and more.
Not cheap though - $50 for lunch for 2 (I paid, lucky me) with 1 beer and no dessert.

It was my first time at Zama and I dined alone and sat at the sushi bar.
I had completely forgotten that it was restaurant week - and while the set menu looked fetching, I opted for a few a la carte items.

I started off with a trio of handrolls.  The fish was fresh and excellent - but the lovely server, Roxanne - who explained so very many things to me - forgot to tell me that they come wrapped in soy paper.  Had I known I would have requested nori.  (I like the crunch of nori with a hand roll - espescially with the salmon one.)  No matter - they were so perfect.

I also had a side order of ohitashi (spinach) - which I love.  The portion was very small - and it was a side - so I ordered something else.  

Something heavy.
Something decadent.
I so should not have order this - but I did and I loved it, too.

The braised short rib app over crispy larmen.

Oh.  Boy.

The bill including 1 non-alcoholic drink (a refreshing limeade) and tax 'n tip was $40.

Not bad.

Decor is gorgeous - a giant paper koi on the ceining and great light woods and textures throughout.

Zama - I am infatuated and will return soon.  Can you win me over from Doma? You are nearly 5 stars.

We shall see.

This place used to be the Wawa - and it has since improved in cleanliness and product quality, now thatOld Nelson took over.  A good place to get coffe, sandwiches and packed foods.  Plus it's right across the street from a Dunkin Donuts so you can get all your pre-work coffee/donut & smokes and head to the office.

What a fun place for breakfast or lunch.
A friends and I had lunch here (ironically nobody had any coffee).

The food was just fine - and the servers are friendly and cool (great hair and ink!).

A great neighborhood place.  Wish they'd stay open later (close at 2 PM) or do dinner a few nites per week.

Also - note:  cash only.

Still one of the best Sushi spots around.
The tamago is frozen (bad) but the Spicy Tuna Balls are great and the sashimi is solid.
The last time I went I tried a specialty roll (can remember the name) for $14.95 (ouch) and the hamachi sashimi app.  (YUM!).

Ask for sauces on the side if you prefer.
Sushi chef Sam is very nice, too.

I'm still a fan!

This has got to be the cleanest and most well run Rita's that I have ever seen.  The summer-teen/college aged staff is actually pleasant and well mannered.  We stopped by for frozen custards on July 4th weekend and it was a great experience. (As Rita's goes.)

The frozen custard is quite good.  I am not a water ice eater - but I love the custard at Rita's.  News flash! Their "Gelatti" is NOT Gelatto.  It is a bastardization combo of water ice and custard.  Whatever.  It tastes good.

Bring on the coffee flavored frozen custard, please.

I stopped at DiBruno's on a whim at 7:45 AM for a (pricey) breakfast sandwich.  COOKED TO ORDER.  I had scrambled eggs (2), cheddar, spinach and tomato on an english muffin.  Came to $4.49 with tax - yikes - but man was it good.

An indulgence for sure - and you gotta wait several minutes - especially if there is a line (at 7:45 there wasn't) as they painstakingly prepare everyone's sandwich, omlette or oatmeal ONE at a time.

Wow.  A yuppy puppy brekkie for sure!

I have been dying to try Bittersweet and now I can't wait to return.
Eli (at the front counter) and the other staffers are so friendly and helpful.
Note:  You order and pay first and then sit down and they bring the food to you.

Breakfast and lunch ONLY - except for Wednesday dinner (Dining Out in the Chaos aka Dining Under the Stars).

Creme Brulee Pancakes are a sweet-dessert like treat.
I opted for the savory special - Breakfast enchiladas and tasted a terrific side of Vegetarian Chili with Sweet potatoes and Black Beans (I loved that best!).  The cornbread accompanying the chili is house-made and perfect!

I want one of everything!
What a great place.

What a great find. Fabulous, family-run Thai with a cute stand at Booths Corners complete with Boba teas.

We'll be back.

Still great - but we had a 4 star experience.

Thankfully we dined early so we could order off both the Happy Hour menu (Nachos with skirt steak was good and surprisingly plentiful for a half portion.) and Dinner Menu (Planytains with Crema!)

Lovely food, delicious fresh cocktails.
Great Service.

LOVE IT!  (So close t 5 stars - please bring back the pomegranate salad).

$50 for 2 of us - one drink a piece and lots of bites.

On the LAST Wednesday of every month you can get a Medium 2 topping pizza for $3.99 (Normally it's $4.99).  Seriously?  You can't get a frozen pizza for $3.99

We love this deal and get one pie for every 2 kids and it's perfect for two (or one ravenous adult.).

Sashimi puts a sushi joint to the test - and the $13.95 sashimi app is a generous taste of 4 fish (tuna, salmon, seared (cold) albacore, Y.T. and 1 cooked shrimp).

If you love the inside of a spicy tuna roll without the rice try the spicy tuna ball app.  5 bite-sized balls of spicy tuna coated in crunchies.

I am a fan of this place!!!

Well, it's 6 years later and I am pleased that Jeenwong is still there - and my egg noodles with shrimp ($8.95) came with 6 BIG shrimp and lots of brocoli and carrots.  A little on the greasy side and not spicy at all (I am a wimp so that's fine by me - if you want spicy don;t get this one - or ask them to make it spicier which they will do.)

So pleased to have Thai within a short distance of my work.

We had an excellent lunch at Concerto - mostly sushi (which was fresh - not off tasting at all) maki and an excellent duck salad.

The staff wqas pleasant and the decor is very nice - sleek and modern as others have described.

I am sad to see some very negative reviews on here - and feel fortunate that we got fresh fish and a great tasting meal.
A large Wawa with a gas station and decently clean restrooms.  Got in & out and back on 73 with no issues.

A great place for a basic (or not so basic) Turkey sammie.  I love the turkey here - simple, tasty and not dry.  (Thank the lord.)  They offer alot of sides, too - but I usually just get the sandwich and then, if I am still hungry I head to Little Thai Market or Sang Kee for a small bite of something else.

Seasons - you have redeemed yourselves.

I ordered our Superbowl pies (2 large - with an array of toppings) and 25 wings 2 days in advance and they were ready,correct and piping hot when I picked them up at precisely 6:30 PM. (Tip:  get the NY Style crust - not too thick, not thin.)

Fabulous!
Much better than the pies we had last year (from a different place).

We'll be back for Superbowl food from Season's next year - and I bet many times in between.

Another great, simple, perfectly broiled salmon dinner with rice and cucmber salad at Lobster Claw.  The place was PACKED - every table filled - on a Saturday night.  Friendly service and simple, delicious seafood meals.  (Fried or Broiled).

LOVE IT here.

Still amazing after all these years.
My now 11 year old kid and I had a whopping $85 lunch including a Pachinko Roll (delicious), the Tartare Trio ($15), Naked Salmon roll and JUMBO Ebi Shumai.
Also Nigiri and sashimi a la carte (Salmon belly, salmon, REAL home-made tamago and more).

We love this place SO much!
We miss you!

So good for "Italian" hot sandwiches, cheese-steaks and roast pork with greens.
Garlicky spinach and sharp provolone (50 cents more).

I had a cheese steak hoagie - and it was one of the best (Tony Luke's and Jim's beat Pat's and Geno's any day!)

Fresh bread.

Good stuff!

A solid 4 this time for properly cooked Hunan Duck and (Special) Crystal Shrimp Dumplings.  They don;t always have these dishes but if they are on special (or ask - and they if have it they'll make it!) consider these.

Ian and staff are excellent and attentive.

No issues.
Our go-to for "Classic" Chinese-American in Media.

Love the service here from Katie who dotes on my parents (Mom gets the same meal EVERY time - A flounder sandwich, no bread, side of sliced tomatoes).

Wonderful seafood that is always fresh and tasty.
Cucumber salad is refreshing and sweet.  Love it.

My Shrimp salad sandwich was bursting with plump shrimp.  LOVE IT HERE.

Prices have gone up - $16.95 for the salmon dinner now.  Wow.
$19.95 for Ahi Tuna.

Still, love it.

Came here for my birthday dinner - just me and the husband (DH) - and poissoned myself on fresh sashimi (appetizer), Tuna Tartare (a bit oversuaced - heavy on the ponzu, but still tasty) and a delicious Salmon Belly, Cucumber hand roll.

Lovely food, decent enough service.
Best sushi around for the price (cheaper than Teikoku or Azie, closer than Sushi Nami).

A solid 4 now - we have been back at least 3 times for dinners with our 7 year old who gobbles down edamame, shumai, meaty delicious spare ribs (or boneless ribs) and fried rice.  (Good - but a bit greasy.)

Reasonable prices, great service from Annie and Ian, and Panda Cookies (from Japan) for $1.50 to take home at the end.

Oh - and they raise and release butterflies.  You can view the chrysali at the register.

A good, solid, delicious, "classic" Chinese-American joint.

LOVE it - and cheaper than Maggie Kuo.  (But we like it there, too, for fancy-schmancies.)

This store seems somehow better now.  Maybe the flow is quicker during the morning rush?  Maybe its now that the lady cashier knows me by face I get better service?  I still cringe when I spend over $7.00 on coffee/espresso drinks and a breakfast sandwich - so I am not in here often.

This starbucks at the corner of 20th & Market serves the local lawyers and stock exchange folks and they really manage the morning line well.  Staff is decent enough - and the bathroom is usually OK - kept locked.

Not bad!

We ordered from Uncle Oogie's for a company event - and my chicken.avocado salad was delicious.  The pasta and 'parm platters looked great, too.

Love it here, still.

Oh how my family - especially my parents who eat there nearly every week when they are "in season" - loves the Lobster Claw.

Run by a mother and her son and his partner, this home-town seafood joint has a casual feel (GREAT for kids) and tasty fresh fish, seafood and sides.

They are just such nice people and have been around for years.

My mom gets the fried flounder sandwich and dad is partial to the grilled salmon plater.  The cucumber salad is light and sweet - not too vinegary and JUST delish.  I like the mac 'n cheese.

Last time we went I had tilapia - but the fresh blue-fish was on special and it looked fetching as well.

W love it here.  They also sell loads of take-out.
The fried food is never greasy - the onion rings are so tasty.

You gotta try this "little nothing place" becuase it's really all-that.  5 stars for food and about a 3 for decor. (No atmosphere..)

Surprisingly good and what a value - $5.00 gets you a whopping big portion of rice (mostly), salad (iceberg and 2 tomato slices), chicken or "lamb" or both and white and/or hot sauce.

AND you get a can of soda and a bottle of water.

Whata value - and it's pretty tasty, too.

Nice guys running the show.
$5!

FIVE!

Wow.

Azie has evolved into our "special occasion" restaurant as it is just too overpriced to dine there on the regular.  

Meanwhile, my daughter was turning 13 so for the 4th consecutive year we booked a party of 9 here and had great service by Dan, Tom and Ashley (who remembered us from last year).
The service was great and we were seated upstairs in a lovely semi-private area.

Why not five stars?  The sushi here is just "meh".  A few of the white fish varieties (Snapper?  Fluke?  Who knows) were not fresh tasting, although the 3 biggies (tuna, yellowtail and salmon) were all just fine.  Stick with the tartar - the sauce is tasty and 2 orders of salmon tartar disappeared quickly.

Cocktails are delicious here - my Pom-Pop was so easy to drink, and the F.I.G jam is amazing, too.

The strip steak, diver scallops and crab (or shrimp) fried rice are all terrific.Feeling simple?  Salmon or Chicken Teriyaki (Usually so boring) are delightful here.

$4 cappucino and $8 creme brulee for dessert capped off a wonderful experience.
Many thanks to the staff for making a special birthday even more extra-special.

Ever since Tom's Dim Sum opened, we have not been to Da Shin for a while.
Today my kid was home because schools were closed.  So I ordered lunch for 3 including Shu Mai (delicious), Steamed Pork Dumplings (Very good but a bit doughy) and Sesame Chicken.  (Not my fave but my kid loves that fried dark meat chicken.).

Excellent service.
They seem to have updated the menu a bit and changed owners (again??)?

This location at 19/20 & Market is my "old faithful" when I am on my way to the office or running errands in this area o Center City.  There is usually a longer line during peak hours but moves quickly (hello, mobile ordering!).  They have occasionally screwed up my order but always make it right if they do - thankfully they don't mess it up too often.

Between this 'Bux and the one at 18 & Market I am well-stocked with overpriced caffeine to get me through my stressful rat-race of a week.

Mad props to the barristas who are "workin' it".  Especially the nice young man who works 3 - 7 PM ish.

Gotta have my latte. #DiabetesInaCup

Still there - Still just $5 (for lunch WITH a drink - I get a bottle of water) - Still as good as you can expect for street-cart food.

I get the lamb over Salad with "white sauce" - and it is plenty of food for lunch.

And - it's five bucks!

5 star service from Kelsi last night.
We tried to go to Dining Under the Star (aka Chaos out in the Humidity) but there were no outside tables.

So we sat on the 2nd floor (roof deck was also full) and enjoyed Kobe (actually Waygu) on a hot rock, sushi rolls, Crab meat Pad Thai and a delicious chocolate fondue for dessert (same as Teikoku).

Our 9 year old had never been here before and she loved it - especially the fondue and hot-rock beef.  She also devoured a California roll.

Good times!

About $100 for the 3 of us with no alcohol ordered.

This is my go-to Giant when I am in Doylestown.  I much prefer it to Acme as I know the layout of the store (I start in Produce and work my way aisle by aisle).

The freezer sections are clean and adequately chilled.
The Milke, OJ and Dairy are right on my way to the check out.

(Line up, folks, it's COVID time)

The young-ish cashiers are friendly and do a fine job.

No issues.

A strong four stars - but not five.  The service is rather spotty and some of the hostesses and bar staff need to up their game.

Meanwhile I had ($6) 2 pieces of Salmon nigiri - fresh and good, a spicy-crunchy tuna roll (very good but not the best ever) and a beet salad (loaded with blue cheese - next time I will skip it) and served over crunchy iceberg that others may scoff at - but I enjoyed.

Pork Belly app ($13) had barely a smattering of pricey foie gras on top (best part) and delicious braised kale underneath.  

Honestly - this is my favorite place in Media so far.
Great food and when the service is good it's a great spot - but twice now I have been made to feel as if dining alone there is a no-no.

Acme - you have redeemed yourself!  I desperately needed a roast chicken the day before Xmas (Christmas eve day) and they were not only open (and a bit crowded but not awful) but had fresh birds ready.

Psyched!

Happy Hour from 5 - 7 PM (Monday thru Thursday) is a great option with $5 cocktails (try the Azie Blue) served up by Juan - the long-time, friendly bartender.

Lovely atmosphere, great (albeit pricey) food and a good date or special treat place.

Take out lunch for me and my 14 year old came to just under $25.
She still loves that (fried) Sesame Chicken.  Pork Fried Rice.  Egg Drop or Wonton Soup.

I had B&B  - Beef 'n Broc.

Solid.

Great service, too.

Open from 7 AM - 4 PM only (sometimes even closing a bit earlier) this  breakfast & lunch spot (No alcohol served) is lovely for "Breakfast for lunch".  My Eggs Benedict (California - with Avocado and a slice or tomato instead of Canadian Bacon) was delicious. Came with slightly bland and slightly underdone hash-browns.  Plenty of food for $9.95. Friendly service - and you pay at the front.

It was jam-packed at precisely 12 noon on a Wednesday - so come earlier if you can.
Parking is also a drag - but the end result is worth it.

Sit on the patio under an umbrella if the weather permits.

NICE!

Had a 3 star service (4 star food) experience here for my birthday party (11 guests).
We were seated in the front bar area at two 6-top tables.  Splitting the check at the end was a nightmare, plus the pre-added gartuities rangesd from 21 to 40%.  (40%??  What???)

Everything got corrected eventually.

Meanwhile the best bites of the night were the Salmon tartare (magical) and the Chilean sea bass.

Very expensive for what it is - but it's one of our go-to spots for special occasion meals.
I wish the service was better - they get so busy on a Saturday night that I tend to not go there on weekends.

Many thanks to Matt and the gang for hosting my class's High School reunion at Villa Capri.  We basically took the place over with about 65 people in attendance for light apps (Calamari, bruscetta, "Brooklyn" pies, salad and mini cannoli).

We all had a great time and the bar was well run.

Excellent.  Excellent cheesesteaks.
I had the Italian (Sharp Prov and Broc. Rabe) and added mushrooms - $.75.
My friend had "The Works"/

About $11 a pop - but huges and delicious and NOT dripping with grease.

Crowded and cramped to eat there - but so. worth. it.
Teeming with tourists - NATCH.

CASH ONLY  (ATM on site)

I visited Azie for the first time alone - and it sure won't be my last.
Expensive - yes - but I had impeccable service on the (now open) rooftop deck and tried the delicious (and huge) Chicken Noodle (rice noodles) soup. Simple - but great.

Good selection of cocktails, too.

Can't wait to come back and try more.

A new, fresh, clean and well-stocked Giant that already is crowded on weekends and during peak shopping periods.  Way better than the crapolla Acme in Granite Run.

I still visit the Giant in Aston because i know the store layout (or at least i knew it before they renovated a piece of the store) and can shop faster there.

I am a Giant shopper for sure - more than Acme, Shoprite, Trader Joe's Wegmans's (too far) or Whole Paycheck (love it, too far, can't afford).

For my every day groceries, look for me in line, at Giant.

A much needed addition to Brookhaven/Media/Aston area as the existing Giant was getting super crowded.

Large aisles and (CoVid excluded) usually well stocked.

Yay!

Celebrated my kids 11th birthday here (we celebrated her 10th here last year) with a party of 7. Service by Ashley was top-notch, 5 star all the way - but there are some serious food errors that occured.

My mother & I shared the Strip steak, and while the flavor was delicious the meat was gristley and not pleasant to eat.  We also asked if we could have veggies instead of truffle fries and we got ONE sprig of asparagus each.  (What??!)  Luckily a plate of light cooked vegetables (quite al dente) arrived but over half way through the meal.

Dessert was divine as always and service good - but that steak?  I can and have made better at home.

Oh - and skip the shrimp shumai.  They're frozen.

First Watch (alot like Turning Point) is a casual breakfast/brunch/lunch place.
On weekends it gets very crowded but we were able to snag an outdoor table after a 35 minute wait.  (Thanks, Vince!)

Avocado Toast, Eggs Benedicts, Salads, Veggie Sandwich, Fresh juices and delicious (sweet and caloric) iced coffee.

All the food was great.

Pricey for egg dishes but a fun brunchy spot.
Large portions.

A delicious selection of coffee and espresso drinks, smoothies, pastries and other treats.  A chill, laid-back atmosphere.

Love it.

Just a hair away from a 5 star experience last night.  Dining Under the Stars was poorly attended due to spotty rain - but that was great for us as we snagged a prime table on the roof deck and had a fine and wonderful meal.

Great service and food.
Bulkoki spring rolls, Kobe Hot Rock, Sushi and Salmon teriyaki were all terrific.
El kiddo devoured her food - including a shrimp tempura roll.

So what's the problem?
No more green vegetables served with entree - only mashed yams (excellent).
I was craving some green beans or broccoli or kale.  Anything.

There is an $8 side of mixed veg - but we didn't go for it.  The entree was $22 alone for salmon and yams.  they used to include a vegetable but no more.

Also $10 for a side (huge - but still) of plain fried rice with only egg is CRAZY!

PLEASE BRING BACK the GREENS!

A perfectly made Iced Latte and a Smoothie for my friend with a clean restroom (need a code to use it) and friendly service.

No  issues.

Fergie's latest creation has transformed Oh! Shea's into the Goat.   Either named for the Goat statue in Rittenhouse Square or perhaps aspirational as The Greatest Of All Time?  In any case the bathrooms are clean, everything has been painted and the menu is re-vamped.

A full bar with any and everything you need plus short rib poutine?

All we need now is Chris behind the bar.

Good work and best wishes!

We usually visit the CFA in Lima, and this one has the same owner.
We finally got a chance to visit the drive-thru during the great Corona-scare of 2020.

That said the drive-thru moved very quickly except for an error when the cashier rang us up.  This was quickly corrected and we were on our way except - no ketchup.

They forgot ketchup packets.  Oops.  Thankfully we were going home and have ketchup there.

Also, did you know CFA serves FISH during Lent?  They are delicious - I got the filets (no bread) but you can also get them on a sandwich.  If you like fried fish - and happen to be here during lent - try the fish.  Surprisingly good.
