Wawa is a necessary evil.  I have a love/hate relationship with it, but all in all we are lucky it's still here.  The cigs, sodas and water bottles are there when we need them.

A quart of milk.
Some sliced Mango (really) and in a pinch, a wrap.  (Blech.)

Glad to have you nearby, Wawa.  Wish you had more parking.  The spots are nearly always full.

Attended a big (350plus) event in the grand ballroom.
Excellent service and surprisingly good food.

Recommend..

A good friend (who was a regular at their old location) and I had lunch at the new location of Taqueria Moroleon.

While the new "Italian Diner"-feeling location is spacious and clean (full bar with LED color-changing lights and tequila bottles shaped like skulls), it has lost some of it's charm from the "old days".

Thankfully, the food is wonderful (at least, we were very pleased).
My friend had a specialty burrito (can't remember which one) and I had the Lunch combo #2 with a chicken burrito (instead of beef) and a GREAT corn-tortilla wrapped cheese enchilada.  The tortilla tasted super fresh.

Service by Suri (Suril?) was great - what a doll!

Prices are a bit high - especially for dinner - but for lunch it's a decent value and the portions were huge (both of us took home about 1/2 of our meals).

Fresh (slightly greasy) chips and 2 kinds of salsa (not pico) were a refreshing change from the "Old El Paso"-style "ketchup" we are used to getting at El Tapatio.  (Sorry El Tapatio - we love you for different reasons).

This is for the NEW Capriccio that opened near Love Park.

So far so good - my 4 year old and I have been here 3 times and had ice cream and chocolate covered pretzels and milk for snacks.  She loves it here and usually when we come iot's pretty mpty.

It is brand spankin' new - and the bathroom (ask for a key) is still clean and fit for use.

It has pretty much the same menu as the Old Capriccio on 17th Street.

The manager, Liz, is really nice and has a son about my dd's age so that's cool.  I wish them much success.  Hope they can keep in clean and new looking.

So far so good - my 4 year old and I have been here 3 times and had ice cream and chocolate covered pretzels and milk for snacks.  She loves it here and usually when we come iot's pretty mpty.

It is brnad spankin' new - and the bathroom (ask for a key) is still clean and fit for use.

It has pretty much the same menu as the Old Capriccio on 17th Street.

The manager, Liz, is really nice and has a son about my dd's age so that's cool.  I wish them much success.  Hope they can keep in clean and new looking.

Wow!  Finally a clean, safe, fabulously-stocked (and equally highly priced) convenience grocer.  The have milk, shrimp shumai, honey candies, go-go squeeze (applesauce) and boar's head deli.

All the neccesities.

Thank goodness they opened!

Even though my daughter did not enjoy her veal parm (she said it tasted "like soap") and my father did not enjoy his lamb chops (they were "just fair").  My husband, mother and I enjoyed our dishes.  (My mom and I shared the Veal Francaise - which was delicious and, thankfully, not drowning in butter-sauce as we asked for it "light" on the sauce).

Salads were super fresh and the best part for me was the screppelle soup.  Awesome.

Good service, too.

My 10 year old wanted to give this place 2 stars but I like it here and next time I am coming without her.  Meanwhile, she polished off her New York Cheesecake for dessert with no problems and I enjoyed a perfect cappuccino.

So there!

Brand new - huge and much needed in this part of town.
A big improvement over the dinky "State Store" they closed on Chestnut.

So happy to be able to get a few bottled of bubbly for the holidays or a bottle or liquer or vodka when I need them.  (And an easy walk from 20th Street Station).

3,5 stars - but I will give them 4 due to excellent service from Cathy (??) and the hostess.

It was our first visit but we will return.  I had the Grouper (special that night - but I have a feeling often) with fresh tomatoes and lumps of crabmeat.  The fish was perfectly cooked and not dry at all.  Delicious but a bit salty and over-sauced (lots of butter.)

DH had the Chicken sorretino with spaghetti in a blush sauce.  (Again, way oversauced - but delicious).

The food is good and portions are large (we both took some home) but there are definitely some areas for improvement (salt and oil/butter content are too high).

As I said before - very good service that night. (Saturday at 6 ish.)
I will be back!

If you can take the noise level (excruciating - even when it's not busy) and the crowds - and you have a kid from age 4-8, then take 'em over to Giggleberry for the overpriced birthday experience of a little lifetime.  They have a gorgeous carousel (best part of the joint, if you ask me.), overpriced food & pizza, and Giggleberry Mountain - a place where your kid can run off some energy.

Lot's of video games and "token" gobbling machines, too.

We plan to have our daughter's 4th birthday party here.  I'll let you know how it goes.  I had to BEG the management to let us have milk & juice instead of soda (can you imagine feeding soda to a group of 3-5 year olds?)  No outside food is allowed, so you are stuck with their overpriced, non-nutritive package.  I hope the "free" cake is edible.

God help us!

Surprisingly good food here.  Especially for a local bar.
We had salads with grilled chicken, pecans, dried cranberries and goat cheese crumbles.  All for $6.95.

It does reek of beer though.

And the service was excellent.  A cool lady bartender with "Trust Me" and 2 crossed handguns tattooed across her chest.  She was cool!

Considering that I now work right across the street, I will likely be a lunch time regular.

For chain it's a solid 3.5 stars (I'll be generous and give 'em 4).  The Chicken Marsala and pasta are good.  Ask for light on the sauces if you are watching your calories - they are loaded with fat.

Service was surprisingly good and effcient.  

I would NOT wait in a line though - so try to avois Friday & Saturday nights.  It is easier to eat here when it is less crowded & less noisy.

Again - for a chain it's way better than the dreaded Olive Garden - and I loathe Macaroni grill (friends and family love it but we had  awful food at one) with their bitter, cheap olive oil.

If you must do fauxtalian - this is a better bet.
It's ain't Le Castagne, and it sure ain't Lusardi's but it's tasty and easy/family fun.

Wegman's certainly has established its formula - with grocery, cafe, pub and many pre-prepared meal options.  I stopped in for lunch on a snowy day and it was still fairly busy.  Sushi was good but not great (Grocery Store Sushi but more varieties than most) and steam-table Chinese/Asian-American was OK and fresh.

Inexpensive and lots of choices for lunch.

This location has closed - but they have re-opened a brand spankin' new one in Love Park (17 & Cherry ish).

Can't wait to try it - as I miss my Vanilla Italian Sodas.

We celebrated our 3rd wedding anniversary at JAI last night - and the weather and scenery were PERFECT.  We come back to the JAI (where we were married on 06/07/08) every year on our anniversary for dinner.  the past 2 years we brought our DD and both sets of parents.

This year it was just us and our DD who is now 6.
She had a delicious lobster mac 'n cheese with smoked Gouda.
She also ate one of my 4 lamb rib chops which were divine.
She also had 3 bites of my husbands salmon which was perfectly cooked.  (All that stuff was 5 star).

Here's the bad part - HIGH salt content for sides and sauces.  My sauteed mushrooms were so salty I had to say something and send them back.  Inedible.  They promptly cooked another (only slightly less salty) batch which I took home - and may toss.

DH's salmon was on a bed of soba noodles drowning in a sweet/salty sauce that, too, was over-salted.

What a shame.

Meanwhile the apps wre AWESOME - some of the best sweet potato fries we've ever tried (and we try them at lots of places) .  Served with a warm marshmallow "fluff-like" dip.  HEAVENLY.

The smoked duck tostada was great, too.  (If a bit on the smokey side.  Yes, it is very smokey indeed.)

Dessert coffees at $8.50 are a delcious indulgence - topped with a cloud of REAL whipped cream.  Chocolate covered strawberries (call ahead to speacil order these) are LARGE, plump, red, sweet and juicy coated in luscious chocolate.

We love it here - and got to watch the end of a Saturday wedding and the rehearsal for a Sunday wedding.  Lots of weddings, showers and events are held here - and we know why - it's a GREAT venue for events.  (And now they can accomodate a larger wedding in the expanded ballroom.)

We love ya, Tegue & Neil!  Best regards to Wendy, too.  See you in June 2012.

Came here in the dead of winter and tried the "Blueberry Pancakes" ice-cream (a special, seasonal offering).  very good - and they claim to make the ice cream onsite.

The decor is cute but very dusty - place could use a good cleaning - especially the display case in the front with the ice cream cakes.

Interesting nostalgia swag on the walls - but again - DUSTY.  Please clean!

Just had a "Taste of Philly" catered lunch at our office - cheese steaks, chicken cheese steaks, caesar salad (with chicken breast chunks on the side to add in), fresh fruit platter, individually wrapped pretzels, TASTYCAKES and more.

Very well done - and a nice change from pizza, pizza,pizza.
That said - at an April 2012 lunch we had the tomato pie (square pie covered in chunky sauce with circles of fresh mozz.) - sooooo good!

Yes, is may be a bit over-hyped and it is certainly pricey and pretentious - but you get what you pay for.  The fish is swimmingly fresh and the dishes are NOT traditional.  The sizzling bowls (one with Yellowtail another with Kobe Beef) and desserts are outstanding.  It budget and appetite permits, say "omikase" to the chef and you will be well taken care of.  This is a special occaision (or expense account) place.  FOr every day sushi eating, I go to Shiroi Hana.

Don't miss the succelent toro tartar.  What a treat!  The upstairs bar is a nice place for dessert and drinks afterward.
Avgolemono soup and dolmades for the win!  Can't wait to come back and have a REAL gyro - or even a shrimp gyro.  Fresh veggies.  SO happy to have found this place.

The Charcoal Pit is a local landmark and institution.  A friend of mine worked here as a teenager serving up burgers and soft drinks. (Lots of shakes.)

It's fun for a family to come here, too.

Not healthy - but nostalgic and fun.

A great location for conferences and conventions.  It is CONNECTED to the Convention Center and right next to Reading Termincal Market.

Rooms and Restaurants are average Marriott Corporate fodder.

An Italian Market staple - and a great resource - if pricey - to the city.
I also like Claudio's - just a block or 2 away - for Ricotta and fresh made mozzarella.

Dicbruno's has a great and vast selection of meats and cheese and they do catering, too.  Also a nice Olive bar (also try Talutto's Olive bar - smaller but nice and fresh.)

They get very crowded around the holidays and on weekends - so try to come on a random Tuesday to avaoid the crowds.

Whoa - expensivoso!  But very friendly nice Korean lady at the counter and GORGEOUS looking stock - a copious amount of produce and groceries stocked floor to ceiling.  Reminds me very much of some of the NYC mini-markets I used to frequent.

A nice addition to the nabe.

We got a nice container of chunked mango for $4.00 and they threw in a free banana.

A beautiful and renovated Wawa with gas, food and everything you might need.
Getting out of the parking lot during the morning rush hour is not easy so be careful and take your time.

Love me a Wawa iced coffee in summer.
My teen likes the new-ish "create your own" salad bowls.

Good value - 2 kiddie cones (with sprinkles/jimmies) for about $6.00.

Black Cherry was excellent with big pieces of cherries in it.
Brownie Batter was dark, rich and super chocolaty.

Yum!

No issues with this Chipotle location near the Walmart and PetSmart in Springfield.
Parking lot on this side is fine - on the Walmart side it gets crazy.

Line moved quickly - but we came at an off hour (5 PM on a Sunday).

Standard Chipotle grub.

I am a big Fellini's fan - and have been to multiple locations (none of which are owned by the same people).  The Berwyn Fellini's can get very crowded, but luckily the night we went it wasn't.

My usual go-to is the Penne Sophia Loren (or the classic Linguine Scampi or Vongole) but on a sweltering August night, we opted to share the (enormous) Mediterranean salad.  A simple bed of crispy-fresh romaine topped with 4 shrimp, a big blob of lump crab meat (so good) and seared tuna slices, plus hunks of tomato and (we omitted) red onion.

The lemon vinaigrette served along side was delectable.

Service from Victoria (she is a hoot!) and 2 expediters was terrific as well.

WINNER!

We'll be back.

Kailon catered a sushi bar fopr my husband's corporate party held at the DuPont country club.  He is such a great guy and makes terrific sushi including rainbow rolls, unagi maki, shrimp tempura & california rolls.  

Good party sushi - can't wait to dine in the restaurant and get some nigiri!

Thanks, Kailon - we love Okura!

I love Seasons 52.  Yes - they are a little pricey , but the food and ambiance are terriic.
Big comfy booths, a gorgeous bar area with orange and strawberry infused vodkas displayed in large glass urns.

Terrific iced tea and REAL lemonade.
Tast flatbreads, sandwiches (at lunch) and fish dishes.

Never disappointed here.
Great on a date or for lunch with the girls.

I am not a Fry-eater - but when my company so generously comissioned the Philly Fry Truck for a 2 hour corporate event - I could not resist - I asked for a 1/2 order and it was plenty.  We were given 2 choices (both with "regular" fries) - one was a "loaded" baked potato with cheese whiz sauce, sour cream, chives and bacon (or not - if you wish).

The other - which I tried was "Philly Steak" - with melted american (so good, so bad), steak meat and bacon.

Decadent.

So bad for you.
So tasty.

Perhaps my employer wants us all dead?  
Serve with a side of Lipitor.

We had an amazing meal and enjoyable evening at Teca along with stellar service from Jen and "Baba" the manager.

Initially we were told there would be a 20 minute wait for a table so we sidled up to the long bar and started to read the drink menu.  All of a sudden our table was ready!  (So great - because we were hungry by then - and the wait was only about 8 minutes!)  In future I would recommend reservations for Friday or Saturday nights here - the summer Gay Street scene is pretty hoppin'.

The tables are pretty close together (we sat outside on a lovely night) so we got to know a couple from Atlanta next to us.  Everything they ordered and everything we ordered looked amazing. We enjoyed our drinks - I had an $8 Kir Royale and DH had a Belgium Raspberry lambic that smelled and tasted so sweet and fruity (you better like fruit!) that even I could have easily drank it.

Our proscuitto and melon app - at $13 - was 5 star perfection.  The large ball of creamy fresh Mozzarella (di Buffala!!!) was divine.  It was served with 2 slices of panini-pressed bread that was good for dipping into the lemon-noted olive oil on the plate.

DH & I both ordered pasta as our main dish - mine was a special of pappardelle (house made - and a little on the thick side but perfectly cut and cooked to a toothsome al dente) with shrimp (5 medium sized ones) and lumps of crab meat (sweet, shell-less and delectable).  DH had the penne a la vodka and I did not taste it but it looked great, too.

We shared a delicious creme brulee (the top was stll warm from being blow-torched) for $8.

Cappuccino (at $5 - ouch!) was a let down.  Extremely bitter tasting and I fear the beans were burnt.  I could only drink a few 

They are sooooo close to 5 stars on food - but there are a few areas for improvement that are holding me out on the 5th star. (Fix your ladies room stall doors and the lights on the stars, please!)  Food snobs from NYC or Philly may shun the 'burbs - but Teca was a big winner for me last night.

We'll be back - hopefully soon - to see if they can keep it up.

Oh - and I wanna buy a bottle of that olive oil that is supposedly pressed at the owner's place in Italy. Good stuff!

Surprisingly excellent non-pizza items.  I had an extremely fresh garden salad - chock full of tomatoes and cucumbers, served with balsamic vinaigrette.  DD enjoyed 3 garlic knots (lighter and "fluffier" than what we are used to) - so fresh and yummy and a small plate of ziti.

Friendly service from "the guys" at the counter.
Reminded us of our favorite spots back in Brooklyn - but Bravo's is much larger and cleaner.

We'll be back!

Fabulous service by Mylissa for our impromptu party of 18 on a sunny Friday Lunch.
We ate outdoors and enjoyed a mountain of wings (with various sauces - try the Kickin' Korean, Mexican Garlic or BBQ), excellent cheese steak nachos (so bad for you, but tasty stuff), burgers and salads.

My $12.99 "special" salad with 7 tiny shrimp was just OK, but the $5 Strawberry Mojito made up for it.

It's really 3 star food but we had such a good experience I am giving 4 stars.

Probably one of the most happenin' places at the slowly dying Plymouth Meeting Mall - especially weekdays for lunch.  Try to come before 11:50 AM when the line forms out the door and down the hallway.

Standard Chick-Fil-A fare which my 12 year old loves.  Chicken Strips (or nuggets) a decent side salad (if you can wait 5 minutes they'll make you one without cheese.)

Wish they'd bring back the long discontinued Cheesecake - my kids loved it.  The "Ice Dream" will have to do.
I agree with Valerie S.  I frequent this Wawa when i need gas on my way back from Brinton Lake or other shopping spots.  Never a problem - get in, get gas, get out.

3 Cheers and 4 stars to Fran (our fabulous server) and the Silver Diner.

Yes, it's faux.  Yes it's a bit kitschy - but when we went (for a lovely lunch on a weekday at 2 PM) it was clean, nearly empty (great service) and the food was GREAT.

My dining companion had a decadent platter of 4 Challah-French toast slices drizzled in (not too much - just right) caramel sauce.  Served with 2 eggs and CRISPY long bacon strips.  It was the picture of perfection and - according to my friend - tasted great as well.

My unique dish was the crab-cakes benedict.  (luckily I asked for the sauce on the side - as I did not need the extra glop/calories).

The 2 crab cakes (one atop each english muffin half) were VERY good.  Lots of crab and not too much filler.  I was even able to get broccoli in lieu of home fries.

We each ordered soft drinks which were served in large "vats" (free refills) and Fran got us to-go cups, which was a nice extra touch.

We'll return for sure!  A great alternative to the mall restaurants.

really good, solid, pies - delivered fresh and hot - and ACCURATELY (Whoo-hoo).  Decent chicken-cheese steaks too.

Reasonably priced, ample dining space (albeit not glamorous - and packed at peak lunch hours).

Note:  If you work for a big firm - like we do - they wil do BREAKFAST pizzas 0 wth bacon and eggs and ham on them - they are slammin' good - but by special order only.  (Normally there's nobody there during the breakfast hours.)

Get here early or you may be disappointed.
We arrived at 6:45 pm on a busy Saturday and they were sold out of burnt ends, chicken and ribs. Luckily we enjoyed pulled pork, chopped brisket and wings.

Sides of cucumber salad, Mac 'n cheese and garlic mashed potatoes were satisfying.

Reasonably priced and super casual.

Cute, needed and pricey coffee spot on Bridge Street in "downtown" Lambertville.

Bought 2 brownies ($2.75 each - YOWZA) and they really weren't that great.

Nice counter staff, though and the place was hoppin' on a Sunday afternoon.

While I am not a 5 guys fan, I gotta give props to the attentive and friendly staff at this relatively new Media outpost.  I ordered a burger - which is 2 patties in a lettuce wrap.  $2.09 for a Dasani (shudder).

If your kid has a peanut allergy don;t go here - they serve peanuts-in-the-shell while you wait.

Typical 5 guys - not healthy, limited menu, but what they do, they do well.

And wow that cashier was great.  (Anitra??)  Big shout out to her.

No issues with this location of Giant - and fortunately I shopped at a non-peak time - a weekday at 5 PM.  Place was dead empty - just the way I like it.

Prices match my go-to Aston Giant location and selection here is a tad more limited and also a few more ethnic (Hispanic and Asian) and high-end items.  (Welcome to Newtown $quare).

Ah, Giant.  You put Acme to shame!

Met a fellow yelper here for dinner and we both sprang for the $26 lobster rolls.  Big, meaty and the real deal!  Excellent - and the toasted, buttered top-split NE-Style bun was just right.

I subbed tender green beans ($2 up-charge, dang it!) for the fries.

My Arnold Palmer was quite tasty, too, with 1/2 iced tea and 1/2 "rosemary" lemonade.  Herbaceous yet refreshing.

I would come back - but for the price (a bit too high) I won't be running back.

Happy hour is what you want here, not dinner. Service by Vinnie at the (crowded) bar and $1 buck a shuck oysters and shrimp on Wednesday nights are a good deal. And half of Philly was there to take part.

The $7 lemon drop martinis are well made, easy to drink and also a good bang for the buck. 

One of the best happy hours in Center City. 

Skip the dining room, hang by the bar!

Wow!  We got a Wegman's - right on my way to Whole Paycheck and just past the Fresh Market.

Love Weggie's - but very crowded and you can easily over buy/over spend here.  Don't shop hungry!.  The cheese department is terrific.  Also a "Pub" and dine-in prepared foods (and mediocre sushi).

Cute little coffee bar in the front of the store, too.

This place is kind-of a tourist trap and part business-yuppie lunch spot.
They do have decent food, cutesy decor (with swinging chairs at some tables) and over-priced cutesy-named drinks.

They also recently starting hawking 2-bite teeny-weeny desserts served tapas-style.

Whatever.

The "Green Submarine" is a veggie sandwich that I'll get in a pinch at lunch time when I am forced to eat here by co-workers who have no originiality and are too scared to try Matyson.

I had wanted to try Fat Salmon for quite some time and yesterday I got a chance to have lunch there.  For $13.50 they were offering a special holiday lunch.  You got a choice of soup or salad (I had the iceberg salad with tasty ginger dressing), and either 2 maki, 1 maki and 1 cooked item or 2 cooked items.

I chose 2 of the specialty maki which normally are $7.50 - 9.50 on their own - so this lunch was a good value.  Ask for sauces on the side - alot of the special rolls are loaded up with semi-spicy mayo and tempura crunch.

The regular lunch menu is also a great price point. Dinner prices are a little high but not crazy.

Cool, icy-blue decor made it feel like Christmas.

Service was quick and efficient.

I can't wait to go back. I will try the sashimi and then render a TRUE verdict.
For now though, I still stand that DOMA is the best sushi spot goin' in Philly these days.  (Save for Morimoto which is cost prohibitive.)

They have a gorgeous Olive Bar and delicious fresh-made ravioli.  I need to compare yet to see if they are beter, worse or on par with Superior.  Service was attentive and pleassant.

Veal ravioli were 7.79 per pound.

This is the Wawa in Ambler.  I stop here for gas and often coffee or other beverages as it is on my route that I drive (over an hour) regularly.  Friendly Staff (even during COVID19 era) and great coffee.

I am so pleased at how GOOD Diane's Deli really is.
Classic sandwiches - breakfast and lunch items.  Huge deli-style sandwiches, chicken and tuna melts.

The decor is dated - but comfortable and clean - and the service is great.  

We love it here for office-related lunches.
The closest thing to a REAL deli you will find near here - and the sign simply says "DELI".

This is the Panera closest to my work (at the moment - LOL) and as long as you go before 12 noon (like 11:50 or so) or after 1:15 PM, you're fine.

Otherwise there is a line and it's hard to find dine-in seating.
Salads are good here - I especially like the "seasonal" Cobb Salad with chicken and the bistro onion soup. (I get it without croutons to save a few carbs.)

They are somewhat famous for the pick 2 combination - soup or 1/2 sandwich or smaller salad.

It's fast food - but way better for you than Burger King or McDonald's.

There is also a honeygrow (better tasting but more money) and a Qdoba in this same strip mall/shopping area.

This place is so cutesy - and faux-euro-feeling.
I popped in for a quick take-out salade nicoise ($11) and will stop in for coffee one day soon.

I had good service - there was no line at the café at 1 PM on a Thursday.  The seating areas, however were full of people camped out there all day or for hours at a clip, so I could not have sat down even if I wanted to.

Very urban-chic bookstore.
Love the book machine.

3.5 really - our kid did not like her chicken salad sandwich on croissant nor the Boylan's Diet Soda (She wanted a true Diet Coke) but we (6 adults) all enjoyed our food very much.

Outstanding French Onion Soup and lovely salads and entrees.
Crabcake (either on a "snowflake" roll or addedto a salad) isvery good.
BlackPepper linguine is drowning in a too-rich sauce with 3 shrimp (small poriton).
Clams in Lemongrass broth were good but broth way very salty.

Too full for dessert - but we'll be back!

Stick to the Chinese/Cooked dishes and you will have a better experience (in my opinion).  Mandy, the server, is just lovely and treats my elderly parents - who are dine-in regulars - like royalty.  She even knows what they usually order.  (Creatures of habit).

The "special" house wonton soup is truly delicious and the meaty spare-ribs are so much better than "that other place" in Doylestown.

I like to get the Chicken with string beans, light on the sauce (to cut the grease factor). My parents love (but I am not a big fan) the Honey Walnut shrimp. It is fried so too rich for me.  If you like fried shrimp and sweet sauces you might like this.

The dining room at lunch on weekends is always nearly empty.
Take-out does a decent business.

Give Jade Island a try - it's really quite good.
For Chinese.

5 stars for food but 3 for the overworked bartender - DeeAnne - who tried her best.  There were 2 huge parties on a busy Saturday lunch so we sat in a booth in the bar area instead of the sunny garden room (perfect for parties).

My dad's ribs and my pork schnitzel were just terrific.

DeeAnne is a lovely lady, too but she had to make drink orders, tend bar AND serve about 5 tables.  Just too much.

Meanwhile, if you come during a quieter time, the Plumsteadville inn is just so nice.  We love it here.  Don't miss the crab cakes.  Out of this world!

We visit the Doylestown Saladworks about every 2-3 months when my DD wants "her usual" (She's 6) - a salade nicoise with shrimp instead of tuna, extra pasta, russian dressing mixed-in.

This may not be the healthiest choice - but if i can get my kid to eat vegetables, I'll take it.

This Saladworks is nice and clean and the lettuce and veggies are MUCH fresher than the scary saladworks in Phila.

We like it here.

Yum Yum is a real donut shop.  Good coffee, cheap prices, greasy fresh donuts.  Been there for YEARS.

Love it!

The Plumsteadville Inn is open and even has rooms available once again.
A good choice for lunch or dinner - with good salads (Caesar topped with steak i

I am gonna be generous and give them 4 stars as they cater 9and in a timely manner, I might add) many of our office functions.  The pizza is 3 star but the salads are chock full of goodies (eggs, olives, tomatoes, cucumbers, etc.)

They also served a unique hot sandwich platter at one of our meetings.

Very nice change from pizza.

As salad works go (they are a local chain of custom-tossed salad and panini shops) this Doylestown location of Saladworks (near the K-Mart) really isn't bad.  My little one & I order the same salad every time - and she loves it.   It's about $9.00 after tax but is way big enough for an adult anbd a child to share.

As with all the saladworks, they also have sandwiches (panini) but I don't care for them.  At least at the D-town store the lettuce is usually fresh and crisp (and NOT brown) and the ingredients are in good, cold, condition.  The high school gals (and a few guys) who work here are well mannered and friendly.

NOT like the crappy ones in Center City.

I am happy that Saladworks exist as I do not eat traditional fast food like burgers or subs.  Home of the $8.00 salad (or $9.00 for the one we get).  Do you want white or wheat (roll) with that?

This is our go-to Saladworks - and is far better (fresher veggies and lettuce, cleaner dining and restrooms than Philly locations or mall locations.

The staff is friendly and the prices ar $7.99 - $8.49 for salads (plus more if you add extras.)

My 7 year old loves saladworks - and if it gets her to eat more veggies - I am all for it.  (granted she loves her salad to have pasta in it - but she does eat veggies, also.)

Fantastic food and good service from Kate I the Chandelier room on a busy Saturday lunch.  Our party of 3 feasted on decadent chicken pot pie, fall-off-the-bone BBQ ribs and a classic Wedge salad. Best of all? Added a crabcake to the Wedge salad and it, quite honestly, was one of the best all-crab, no-filler crab cakes that I have ever eaten. Seriously.  That good.   I can't wait to have another! $9 a pop but so worth it. My dad pronounced it the "best crabcake outside of Maryland".

Lovely food. Such a treat.

This is a brand-new Royal Farms right on 452 in Aston (South Aston?).
My kid loves the fried chicken - though we are both not keen on their fries - which are BIG slabs of skin-on spuds.  Just not our thing.

But for gas, Chicken and Krispy Kreme? (Must get them in the AM or they get stale super fast.)
Here's your spot.

Back again for a wonderful $11.50 Honey Fried Chicken Tossed Salad lunch with that exquisite buttermilk dressing.  LOVE it!

Service is always great - and the Fish of the Day was Trout served with a delicious roasted asparagus and quinoa salad.

Kudos to Wendy, Jackie and the wonderful team at Day by Day.
We love it!

With all the great international cuisine in Philly, I almost never consider Chinese (my first love from Childhood) anymore, but when I am sick I NEED soup.  Wonton, Subgum Wponton or Hot & Sour.

Well, Square on Square came through for us last night.  Delivery took about 40 minutes on a BUSY, Rainy Friday night - which isn't horrible considering those conditions.

My husband enjoyed his sweet-yet-spicy General Tso's (The call it something else) Chicken.  I ordered a Quart of THE BEST HOT 'n SOUR (For real.  I love their version.  Chicken and tofu and just enough black pepper, red pepper and vinegar).  I also got a quart of the "special" wonton soup which had a tasty broth and was loaded with chicken, pork, bok coy and mushrooms.  My only complaint?  Only 4 of the DELICIOUS, petit wontons in one quart.  Next time I'll ask for extra wontons - and gladly pay for them, too.  

I ate a small bit of each soup and had plenty left for the next day.

You saved me, Square on Square.  Those soups are the BEST.

My father in law pretty much LIVES at grocery stores.  He's use $1.50 worth of gas to go to a store to save 50 cents on a dozen eggs.  You get the idea...

But we all can agree on Wegman's.  It is a pleasure to shop here and the selection is great.  If you are a comparisson shopper (and in our family - you are!), you can also nab some good bargains here.

We got some terrific imported cheeses and yummy prepared foods here and made a gourmet picnic for a fraction of the cost of having it catered.

Wegman's also does a fairly good job of appetizing/catering of their own - but we prefer to just buy the componenets and assemble them ourselves on trays.

Wegman's is great.  Wish there was one in Center City Philly!

The BEST Chinese around - and its not even in Chinatown.
We got delivery today - a day-after-the-snowstorm order takeout kinda day.

A QUART of the fabulous hot & sour soup always cures what ails me.
Delicious chicken & snow peas.
Pan fried dumplings are average - not mind blowing.

Service was friendly on the phone and lightening fast (They showed up in 17 minutes!)

Yes, it is pricey here - as in $13 - $15 for tricked-out burgers and sandwiches.
The best deal going - if you happen to like the day's picks - are the pick 3 which is a boring salad, a soup and a 1/2 a sandwich or wrap.

Today's picks happened to be great - a turkey club wrap with Turkey bacon and the soups (both sounded awesome) were tomato veggie or butternut squash.

I had the butternut squash soup and the salad and took the wrap HOME.
Two lunches in one for $12!  Plenty!

Good service and we sat outside as the weather was just perfect.
Got here at 11:50 AM just before the rush. Do not come here at 12:10 or 12:15 PM.  Come early or late for better service.

We had a great experience here - so much so that I made my 9 year old a VIP (unlimited session fees for $50 for a year).

No, it's not cheap, but you can easily spend 90 - 120 minutes at a clip here and it's a great rainy-day activity for artistically inclined kids.

Might even be fun for a Girls Night Out party with the grown folks!

We even came back the next day (Sunday - when one adult pays the $10 session fee - up to 2 kids under 12 pain free!).

We're in!

One night a week they serve - of all things - tacos - and they are pretty darned good.  I had shrimp tacos and gelato for dessert.

This is still not my favorite place - I want to love it but I just don't.

The guitarist in the background (again only on Mondays or Tuesdays - I forget which night) is terrific.  talented guy!

Great service, nice decor - but the food is just OK. If you plan ahead you can also have a larger party here - maybe 15 - 20 tops.  Above that and they really can't accommodate you.
Try to go for tacos - not Italian (how weird!!!!).

Very good sushi (better than Temaki in my opinion) and decent chinese (kinda pricey for what it is.).  I actually liked the Granite Run Mall location better for chinese (did not have sushi there.).

Specialty Rolls are expensive - $16 for the Eagle Roll - topped with chunky lobster salad.  Rainbow Roll ($12) was good, but stuffed with fake kani stick.

Good deal for lunch - higher for dinner.
Full bar.

Nice!  Will be back soon.

Fantastic decor and attentive device from Chris made up for a few minor problems with the food. 

Pizza are fresh tasting and there are so many varieties. The 7 inch mini is quite small, so get a salad to go with it.

Seafood salad was very good, however the beef on the land 'n sea salad was way too over cooked.

Pricey, but you are paying the rent on the swanky digs.

I enjoyed it here but next time I will modify my order.

I don't even like hoagies and I so love Primo.
We stopped by the "quant" Claymont location today for lunch where my co-worker frequents and is known by name.

The 2 ladies who man the counter at lunchtime are very nice and funny.

I got a (basic) Turkey wrap and he got a Sharp Italian wrap.
I love that they offer wraps now, because the bread is very heavy and chewy - yummy - but filling.

Also - if they happent o be hot and fresh (which they were today) grab a cookie - I got white chocolate macadamia - and oh, wow!

Yes - they really do deserve 4 stars.  Great catering - fresh salad, good pizza (and stellar tomato pie) and COOKIES!!!!!

A great value for a crowd.

A beautiful building with 2 restaurants (And plenty of room to host a private event) inside and engaging architecture.

Service is friendly and warm.
A nice seleciton of fine teas.

Casual yet elegant - and a decent "date place".

I stopped by unexpectedly while walking by "The Porch" at 30th Street station at about 9:30 AM on my way to work.

I ordered a "Cali"  (BLT with avocado and a deicious lemon/lime mayo that really added a pleasant brightness).  Menu said $4.50 but she only asked me for $3.50.

Sweet gal on the truck!

So very pleased.
I can't wait to try their burgers.

Wow - I can't believe I've waited this long to yelp Square on Square.  I have eaten here many times -mainly for lunch as they do a filling, mid-priced lunch special.  The Hot & Sour soup here is some of the best EVER .

Really.  5 stars for the H&S Soup.

We also had a large group party here in February 2008.  They offered a set meal with soup, appetizer choice of 6 entrees and dessert.  It was very well organized and our group of over 30 people left well-fed and happy.

The manager, Steven, is very nice and easy to work with.

The only detractors here (preventing the 5 star rating) is the extremely long lines at lunch time.  (Don't come at 12:30 on a Tursday of Friday) Also the decor is in need of refreshment.  Kinda grungy.

Don't miss the Mango Chicken and Filet Mignon - really tender and nice here.

Initially I did not have high hopes for La Belle Epoque - having read the menu and passed by many times - it just never appealed

French food?  Not my fave. 

Meanwhile, we went here last night and had very good service and EXCELLENT food.
And the best part?  One of the tastiest French 75 cocktails ($10) made to perfection.

The only food downer?  The French Onion Soup which had way. way toomuch rosemary - as in sticks 'n twigs of it.  (Not salty though - and served in a Big bowl for $8).
The best part?  Both entrees- mine and DH's.  He had the Duck confit crepe - which I tasted and we both loved.  I had the duck with raspberry sauce - cooked to perfection (I like my duck with plenty of quack still left in it).  The haricot vert and fluffy (buttery-chivey) mashed potatoes were also divine.

I shall return. And I will bring our 9 year old - she loves duck,
Very pleased!!!

Nice place for a date night,too.  Much smaller inside than I had imagined.

Brunch here is the real showstopper.  (Not really a 4 star for other meals).  The food is American-ish with a twist.  I enjoyed the bread basket offerings - they were really fresh and tasty.  Nice alcoholic drinks, too.  Pricey - but very genteel and worth it.  Gorgeous decor and professional service.  CROWDED for brunch - but worth it.

Make a reservation.

They are now cash only (except for large catering orders).
Still a great "safe" choice for lunch or brunch.

The crispy honey fried chicken salad is my favorite, and any "fish of the day" is great (Salmon, mahi mahi).  For dessert don;t miss the delicious chocolate cake with buttercream frosting.  So good!

Nice salad and hot specials.
Friendly service from Wendy and the crew.  (The cashier lady is lovely - I can never remember her name, though.)

And the support my child's school!

We love Day by Day!

Zio's can get very chaotic and crowded but the "Grandmom" pizza is terrific.  Sicilian is a bit thicker and cheesier - my 9 year old gets that.  Traditional cheese-steaks and a few goodies like rice balls and zeppoli keep us coming back.

No problems here - just good, reasonably priced pizza and sandwiches.

I was gun-shy at coming back here after my awful dinner experience - but I have eaten many lunches here in years past.  I got the $10 lunch special (includes soup and rice) and had the terrific hot 'n sour soup.

Large portion of food for lunch - took some home.

Avoid for dinner - but fine for lunch.
You have redeemed yourselves, Square on Suqare.
See you again for lunch.

543 is Urban Outfitter's answer to the (pricey) corporate cafeteria - and there are a bunch of good choices including soups, a salad bar, sushi (too expensive for what it is - Salmon Avocado roll is $8.) and sandwiches.  Hot entree's rotate.
Lovely salads - around $9.

If you work here - it's one of the only options, so I hope even more places will open up down here.  Lo spiedo is wonderful but too expensive for a "regular" lunch.

I pretty much agree with EVERYBODY (and I mean everybody) else on N. 3rd.  Great food, great & busy artsy eye-catching decor and perfect for brunch.  (SCORE!  A near-perfect bloody mary with a great kick to it.)

We enjoy it here - but it can be a crowded cluster-f&%k at peak times.

Had a wonderful lunch for 4 adults plus my 9 year old.
Excellent lunch specials (Chinese) and sushi, especially the "Flamingo Roll"  ($15 - ouch) with Mango, Avocado & Salmon over a shrimp tempura roll.

Wild salmon Nigiri ($3.50 for one piece) was heavenly.
Hamachi nigiri ($3.00) was very good also.

Great lunchtime service and bill was around $80.00 (no alcohol, no dessert ordered).

3.5 stars really.

Day by Day has been a reliable lunch spot and catering go-to place for me and many people at my firm.

The fried chicke toss salad is delicious and they serve a "safe" selection of sandwiches.  In the summer-  the gazpacho is a refreshing and tasty choice.

The specials of the sday - often fish and omelettes are also really, really great.  They often sell out of the fish special - so come early for your lunch.  They don't do dinners - although last summer they briefly toyed with a "dessert cafe" concept which I wish had fared better.

Anyhow - it's a great place to grab a safe, reliable lunch.

Stopped in today for "Linner" (We wanted to try Temaki but they close from 2-5.  DRAT!) with my 8 year old.  Service was cold as ice at first (maybe they were leery of the kid, but they warmed up.

They tried to seat us in the back (so dark back there) but we asked to be closer to the windows and they obliged.

Linner for 2 cost $50 with tax and tip - small plates.  1 cup of hot & sour (very good) for me, edamame (Huge portion for $4) for sharing, Shrimp Shumai (just Meh - 5 tiny pre-frozen ones) for the 8 year old (She likes Doma''s better - she's a shumai connoisseur), "meh" sushi appetizer (came with Cali roll and I never would gotten it had I known that - I was expecting all nigiri).

We also got VERY delicious seafood and spinach dumplings - these are a MUST try if you like fish (and an avoid if you don't).  The hand-made pasta/dumpling skin was light and pan fried on one side.  PERFECT.

Agedashi tofu was a bit soggy - but the dashi was delightful. That said, I WOULD get it again as I love fried tofu.

We'll be back - but I sure wish folks would give me and my kiddo the benefit of the doubt.  She's a well behaved kid and not at all bratty. And she knows her food!

Meanwhile - skip the sushi here - but I can't wait to try the Moo Shu Chicken here.  Their Chinese dishes are great,

I am going to be generous and give Tony A.s 4 stars (they may only deserve 3) as related to the DELIVERY ORDER we had for a large catered party (25 people) tonight.

Our group of professionals met at a nearby office complex so we needed a place that could deliver and provide a low cost alternative to Pizza.

We ordered a large hoagie tray (2 large platters) with Italian hoagies and Turkey & Provolone (no onions) with oil & mayo on the side.  Also we had 1 tray of wraps, vegetarian (GREAT - full of spinach, eggplant, peppers etc.) and Chicken Caesar wraps.

Additionally there was a large bowl of romaine salad with tomato, cucumber, sliced bolied eggs and sides of 2 dressings.

The pasta salad was not great - overly dressed in a vinegary dressing.  Yuck.

The dessert tray of brownies and cookies (Sugar, Chocolate Chip and White Chunk macadamia) were very yummy.

All in all a great experience.  Everything arrived on time and as we specified.  I can not speak for the ambience of the dining room as I ahve never set foot in the place.

I used the Edible Arrangements location in Commack NY.  I can't find a listing for it.

I will write a complete review when i know where to put it.

Note:  You can also order from FruitFlowers.com - a DIFFERENT company called Incredibly Edible Delights.

Both companies are great.

Stopped in here for a quick cafe au lait ($1.75) just before the yelpy awards.
Staff was a bit "snotty" - but not horribly so.  Coffee was perfect - so delicious - I love La Colombe and they even did our wedding favors for us back in 2008.

This branch is in a great location - right near city hall - and offers some respite from the high traffic area. Clean, wood seating, wood floors.  Very chic looking.

Oh - and no splenda (tons of other sweetners thought).
And - as per usual - no menus so just order what you want (Latte, double macchiato, whatev...)  That's a bit uppity to me - but that's La Colombe.

Uppity coffee to get you UP!

When they're hot - they are just heavenly - especially the White Chunk Macadamia - but DAMN they are expensive.  (And way too caloric for me to indulge in regularly.)

If you time it right you can get a free sample - which is just a bite or two and can be just enough to prevent you from buying and eating a whole one.

The buy 3 get the 4th free is a standard "special" - so that's really not so special after all.

Hooray!  The Thai Chef folks that I loved so well on Chestnut Street have an outpost in a stripmall in Glen Mills.

The Tom Kha is terrific - with a bowl of light jasmine rice, it's a meal in itself.

So glad to have found themand can't wait to return.

We had a private event for about 20-22 diners in the back room at Effie's and it was handled beautifully.

We had many vegetarian restrictions so the following dishes were served, family style:

Spanikopita (delicious!)
Tyropita
A large mixed plate with hummus, baba, feta, olives, peppers and dolmades (awesome domlades by the way)
Chopped Cucumbers & Tomatoes in oil & vinegar
Penne with Onions, Kalamata Olives and Onion in tomato sauce.

The food was wonderful and the 2 ladies serving worked their butts off.  Wer had an amazingly good time. (And the good weather helped.)

The outdoor courtyward is a fun place to eat as well.

I can't wait to come back and have some lamb chops!

Great job, Effie's!

Ok, here's the deal.  If you're going on somebody else's dime - do it!  It is really high-priced for faux-pub - but I gotta say they do a few things there really, really well.

For instance, one of my dining companions is from England and ordered a Bomdardier which he said was well poured and not "too fizzy".  It was however, served much cooler than you'd get back home.

My entree of Hake was delicious served in a buttery lemon caper sauce over a small bed-ette (to small to call it a bed) of kale.  Not dry - in fact it leaned toward the underdone side - and thus was tender and large-flaky.
I also enjoyed the cold poached shrimp (5 for $14 - large ones) with lemon mayo & cocktail sauce.  Simple - but so tasty!

Desserts are not a strong suit save for the hot chocolate pot. (worth the 15 minute wait - order this with dinner if you are in a rush). Skip the Eton Mess unless you like TART fruit.

My decaf cappucino (not listed on the menu - but ask and ye shall receive) was EXCELLENT.  Try a Pimms Deluxe (or a classic Pimms cup) for a refreshing treat. Oh - and they have (for $5.50 each - OUCH) fancy-schmancy organic bottled sodas from the UK - I had a Luscombe's Sicilian Lemonade that was great and worth the 134 calories of sugar-water.  (THat's ORGANIC sugar water to you!).  And they carry Ribena (a blast from the past!).

I may be back - but for the price point, I'll be waiting a while.
Oh - and I won't be missing Mantra!

PureBread is a great lunch option.  They used to offer a full coffee/espresso bar but they don;t anymore.  So, mostly I go for soups (the mushroom bisque and lobster bisque are delicious but caloric) and salads (I like the Cobb).

All the menu items are named after dog breeds and there is dog related decor and monitors with local dogs.  I love dogs so this is great for me.

A great choice in Glen Mills near tons of shopping.

Came here on the strong recommendation of a friend that their Sicilian Pie (or Tomato Pie) when baked fresh is some of the best. ever.  I agree - gives Corropolese a run for their money.  Meanwhile, today I tried a panini (on an enormous Ciabatta loaf) with pork, sharp provolone and broccoli rabe.  Asked for a bit of sauce on it - PERFECT.  This is amazing.

My friend had a small (still plenty) sausage and pepper sandwich/sub/hoagie and it was old-school and very tasty according to her.

Jeanne-Marie (sp?) our server was friendly and wonderful but way overworked - she was serving 2 full dining rooms at the lunch rush by herself.  Ouch.

Nice place for a casual red-sauce Italian meal.  Can't wait to come back and try a pasta dish.
Molto bene!

Lunch with a party of 5 (co-workers) and while a bit pricey it was perfect for a business-casual lunch. Service was fine - our male server (Mike??) was on point with drink refills and bringing the check (it was quite busy on a rainy Thursday from 12:15 - 1:30 ish). Restroom was clean and comfortable.  Decor is very nice.

My only complaint?  The chicken tostada was fried - as in battered and fried and dripping in grease.  Next time (if I get that item) I will ask if they can do it with grilled chicken.

Steamed spinach (by request) was perfect and I am glad I asked because one colleague's meal came with sauteed spinach which he said was loaded with salt and oil.

Please folks, ease up on the fatty foods and we will return much more quickly.

Thanks!

Really good - buttery - hand made Amish-Style pretzels.  Reminds me of when Auntie Anne's wasn't a chain - and really did have good pretzels.

These are so much better.  Get 'em while they're hot and eat them on the spot.

Carb-y goodness.  Little white head covering not included.

Yum Yum is a small, local chainette of donut shops.  I am glad they are still around because, as a kid their donuts and fried delights - like apple fritters and bowties were kick-a$$.  Waaaaaay better than Dunkin'.  (Although Dunkin's cofee is better than yum yums.

A cop and fire fighter-haven, yum yum used to be open round the clock - or at least until midnight - and then they'd open at 5 AM to start the morning baking (or frying, as the case may be.)

I loved it there as a kid.  Can't afford the caloric intake nowadays.

Super yay!  Love the turkey burgers here.  They are NOT dry and so tasty.  I pass on the big bucket o' fries in favor of their YUM-CITY mac 'n cheese.  I order mine sans the tomato "jam" garnish.

They also have kickin' sides like greenbeans (crisp and studded with tomotoes) and sweet potatoes.  (Grilled with butter and cinnamon suger - like dessertm baby!).

It can get crowded and crazy - which is why it is not 5 stars -but the price is right and this spot ROCKS."
When they're hot - they're HOT - and sooooooo delectable when fresh out of the oven.  these pricey, large, thick, butter-laden cookies scream with flavor and taste sublime.  Oh, my hips!!!!

So glad that Animo is still around and still delicious and a good source for a healthy meal.  The green Lemonade is still my fave - and I tried a Brisket and eggs breakfast bowl - made with love by Darnell (Yay Darnell!) that rocked my day!

Love it here and I keep coming back.

Even my vegan teen can find good choices here.  (They are not a vegan restaurant and serve cheese, eggs and meats).

Love it!  Wish it were bigger and more days - but I will take what I can get.

Support Philly's Farmer's Markets.
Support Fair Food.
Support Farm to City.

Join a CSA and patronize local farmers!

I had wanted to try La Padella for months and finally got a chance to dine here.  It was worth the wait and I can't wait to return and sample more of their fabulous Italian menu.  The meatballs are large and very tasty. If you enjoy Brussels sprouts, don't miss the Brussels sprouts app - with lump crab meat and a rich remoulade. Super fattening and heavy, so share with friends.  

Service from the amazing Laurie is top notch.  We love her.

Great food and even better service.

In general I really lurve Weggie's.  The bulk foods, the prepared foods, and the superb cheese section are stand outs for sure.  I wish there was/were one in Center City Philly and I would surely shop there.

we spend a little more when we come - not so much due to pricing (the prices are competitive for most items) but because we splurge on all sorts of specialty foods and unique items we just can't get at Is-It-Fresh (Superfresh) or Ack-A-Mee.

Go to Wegman's - but don't go if you're hungry and bring your shopping list so you don't impulse buy!

I love Whole Paycheck -and this location is no exception.
The Taco Truck on the roof, the hot and cold food bars for a quick lunch option, and the ability to shop here at an off-peak time (parking is bad during the weekday lunch rush).

Plentiful seating options (2 floors) and enjoyable.
Expensive - sure - but worth it to me.

Had a superb Chicken Cacciatore ($10) with orzo for lunch.
As usual, friendly service and great food.

We love Day by Day!

A strong 3 - maybe even a 4 - for the expertise of Laura who help me to plan a small happy hour event for my office.

We enjoyed the Raspberry Wheat beer (3.50 is a decent price for it) and other drinks.  We also tried the salmon spring rolls (excellent) cheese-steak eggrolls (good not great) and southwestern springrolls (my husband liked these).

In addition the Hawaiian Pizza was very tasty - and the crust was freshly baked.  I also tried the Ale & Onion soup which tasted good, but was very, very oily - almost greasy from the oils in the cheese.  Eew.  It was OK as "french"-style onion soup goes but I have had better (and I have had worse.).

The place is MASSIVE - a great idea for private parties -especially on a night when you can enjoy the deck.

The best part of the night?  Meeting fellow yelpers Jessica E. and Chris from Delaware!  Thanks for coming out!

They re-did this Sunoco a while back and the mini-mart has really improved with better restrooms, a Subway (inside) and hot foods.  The gas is "market priced" and it's easy to get in and out here - right in "downtown" Media (LOL - I have to laugh at the phrase "downtown Media").

No issues - and I come here quite often when I need gas in Media.

No issues with the Media "martini glass" bouquet delivered locally for a party and it arrived fresh and on time.

My 9 year old & I stopped by the store - because we had never been inside and the nice lady GAVE us each a free chocolate-covered strawberry.  Made our day!

EA is a nice alternative to a cake at a party (you can add chocolate covered berried or banana chunks) or instead of sending flowers to someone.

Another delicious lunch of orzo salad, Salade Nicoise (with freshly seared tuna) and of course the honey fried chicken tossed salad.

Wendy is still there and the gang is always friendly and happy to see us.

Love lunches at Day by Day!

Cathy, our sassy server, was a delight.  She is a pro and has been here for about 6 years.  We sat in their outdoor "Covid Tent" on a busy Sunday morning at 11.  We got a table for 4 right away and juice/coffee/tea.

The eggs Florentine are terrific but they come with cheese.  Next time I will skip it and also get the copious amount of hollandaise sauce on the side.  A calorie/fat bomb for sure.  Too about 1/3 of it home.

Now I need a nap...

So pleased to see a healthier alternative for lunch - the petitio burrito (small) is plenty big.  Prices are high and ordering system is too slow (no big menu - you have to read the small menu) - plus my juice was wrong.  (They re-made it with no issues.)

Love the food choices, not liking the slow ordering procedure (line is huge at lunch hour) and innacuracies.

Also the up charges for Guac and Meats is too high.  (The small burritos are 6-7 as it is - I don;t wanna pay $10 for a SMALL - when I could get a regular sized (large) burrito for $8 anyway.

A few kinks to work out - but I will generously give them 4 stars - for now - I sense trouble ahead, so please get it together and re-structure the burrito menu a bit. (Add ons.)

Keep the steamed kale - it's great!
Also, I am getting green lemonade (ask for it with less apple, more green) every morning for about a week now and I LOVE it.

P.S.  The breakfast "beans & Green" petitio is terrific and at $4.5 is a decent value. The eggs & greens is also a good and filling breakfast for $4.75

When it's fresh - that vanilla pound cake is simple, heavy and rich and DE-FRIKKIN-LICIOUS.  For $11 a pop - get 2 and freeze one.

So good.  A neighborhood staple and a "real" Philly treat.

This Wawa was literally my savior as I was trapped in a huge area-wide traffic fisaco when 95 was literally shut down (in both directions) as was 476 due to 2 major overturned truck accidents.

Traffic was crawling on 291 and all arterial roads.  A 35 minute drive took nealy 2 hours and I. Had. To. Pee.

Thank heavens for this Wawa - and the friendly female cashier who directly me safely out of the parking lot back on to 291.

OMG, Weber's!  I haven't been here since I was a kid.
Meanwhile, yesterday (a Sunday) about 6:30 PM we were driving back to Philly - and attempted to go to the Cherry Hill Mall - which was closed.
So we wound up on a whim, stopping at Weber's.

The Elvis impersonator in the driveway was an interesting touch.  Nice guy - actually (and he's available for parties).

DH & I both got cheeseburgers, DD got a hot dog with ketchup AND a cheeseburger.  We shared a chocolate milkshake - which the lovely female server offered to split into 2 cups for us.  So great!  DD & I each had a few sips of the thick chocolate goodness and then called it quits.  I can't imagine drinking a whole one.

The burgers tasted great and were so juicy. A little small - but they were heavy so that was fine.

DD liked her hot dog and ate a good bit of the burger, too - and of course then felt sick and stopped eating.

A little too much of a good thing.
A rare indulgence, for sure.
CASH ONLY.

So nostalgic on a cool summer night to be served by a "carhop".

Yuppie diner where clientele and staff are all straight out of a J Crew Catalog.  Excellent and good looking (mostly female) wait staff and FABULOUS albeit higher priced diner classics with a twist.

Turkey chili was terrific as was house-made oatmeal and Eggs Benedict (pricey) with a variety of add ons including spinach and crabmeat.

So good.

LOVE!

Can't wait to return.

Super yay!  Love the turkey burgers here.  They are NOT dry and so tasty.  I pass on the big bucket o' fries in favor of their YUM-CITY mac 'n cheese.  I order mine sans the tomato "jam" garnish.

They also have kickin' sides like greenbeans (crisp and studded with tomotoes) and sweet potatoes.  (Grilled with butter and cinnamon suger - like dessertm baby!).

It can get crowded and crazy - which is why it is not 5 stars -but the price is right and this spot ROCKS.
4 stars for the food.  I try to ignore the surroundings.  Great Duck.  And hands-down best steamed dumplings.  LOVE 'em.  Wonton Duck Soup can be a little greasy - but man, it's a tasty indulgence.

MInella's redeemed itself - specifically George, our wonderful server.  A friend and I came during Covid and the place was nearly empty so we could sit and eat.

We each got burgers - big (8 oz) juicy burgers.  Topped with whatever you can think of.  If you wish side of fries and (2) onion rings.  Massive pile of fries.

Very good experience, thank goodness.  I had all but given up on Minella's.

I have since been back to Talula's 3 more times - including last night.  Each time was a true 5 star experience.

But not last night.

Service was still great.
Food was not 5 star.  (The cheese plate was still 5 star - best bites of the night including Délice de Bourgogne and a fantastic onion-y Abbott's Gold Cheddar.  (Had that last time and swapped it into the "World Travel" cheese plate.)

The cavatelli app was superb.  But tiny.
TINY!
Yes, I know it's an app - but they presented it in a huge, deep "pasta" bowl and it made it look even smaller.  Maybe serving it in a more propotionate vessel?

My friend ordered the spring foraged salad which sounded heavenly on paper and in real life was just OK. The ramps were over powering and the foraged lettuces were a bit bitter and odd tasting.

The beets and ricotta side still rocks my world.

It was a strong 4 for food, 5 for service but...
...here's the BIG but...

The cocktails have somehow gone awry.
Even my Arnold Palmer was just "meh. (Did they change their iced tea??)
My friend ordered a "The Painter" - a champagne cocktail and it looked like a watered down mimosa with lemon juice instead of orange juice ($12 - FEH!)
And the enormous wine glass that the rose came in (Reidel crystal??) made the skimpy less-than-6-oz. pour look positively puny.  ($10 - FEH again!)

I am deeply saddened to have to downgrade Talulas as it was one of my absolute faves.

So sad.
So sad.

Meanwhile - come have a cheese plate here - but be wary of the new barkeep.

We came on a Sunday for a late lunch and had great service from Luna.
Cheerful (loud - they turned it down) music and Horchata (ask for it).

Delicious Al Pastor (I got it in my tacos) and fresh guac.

My partner's burrito (veggie) was chock full of goodies.

Very fair prices and portions.
Good tasting food.

Haven't been to Devil's Alley in years (try 5 or 6 of them) but stopped in for lunch on a not-so-busy Friday (It was 11:50 AM - so the rush had not yet hit) and had a great, basic cobb salad (I subbed Salmon for pulled Chicken) and it was terrific. 

The Honey Mustard and Blue Cheese dressings (I sampled both!) are very good and the lettuce was fresh and crunchy.

Service from the hostess (Alyssa/Alicia??) was outstanding, too.  She is young but been in restaurants for 7 years.  So kind.

We'll be back - and in less than 6 years, too.

Devil's Alley is still a good choice - even after all this time.
Keep it up!

A fantastic find on an unseasonably warm November day.  Lentil Soup, Horiatiki Salad -topped with salmon - so perfect - and "greek" waffle fries.

Great service from Ian.

We loved that house-made pita, too.

Everything was so tasty and moderately priced.  Lovely!

Delicious linguine with clam sauce (whole clams, in-shell) and just enough garlic in the not-too-oily sauce.  The long-stem (fried) artichoke appetizer is truly marvelous but so heavy for an app.  I had it as a lunch entree and was stuffed.  (The panko-coated artichoke halves are smothered in a rich rosa sauce - delicious but so caloric.)

A diet bomb but a special treat.
Attentive and efficient service.

Still a solid choice for lunch, dinner or drinks and munchies.
Very good quality food - but also high priced.

Heirloom tomato salad ($10) was small but very delicious.
Cheese Plate is always a fine choice as is the pint of Prawns or house-cured salmon.

Lovely food - simple, fresh ingredients.
Complicated drinks and high priced soft drinks ($5 for luscombe's!)

Ok service but a few little mis-steps. For example - we were not served any bread & butter until we asked for it - late in the meal.

A good pick for a Center City lunch.

3-4 stars - I will give them 4 as our service was excellent (we came on the Sunday night of July 4th weekend) and the food was surprisingly excellent.

Our party of 3 sat in the back dining room which was a/c-chilled to a crisp.  Bet that comes in handy on crowded nites - but it was DEAD at 6 PM on that particular Sunday.

We started with a DELICIOUS order of chicken nachos and they were served with blue corn tortilla chips, salsa, guacamole and a good amount of melted cheese.  YUM!

My friend ordered the grilled chicken (her usual - she's been 3-4 times and unlike other reviewers - she likes the grilled chicken here), my husband got the pork burger and I got and LOVED the (fried) fish tacos.  At 3 tacos per order for $9.50 - that was very fair.

The only culinary "oops" were the twice-fried french fries.  They were hard as rocks and cold.  Kinda greasy and blah tasting.  I bet they sat around due to the low-turnover night.  I bet they taste better fresh outta the fryer.  Too bad.

Oodles of beers on tap and by the bottle - even a choice "by the cask".  Hubby got a Blueberry wheat pale ale - which tasted great.

The chocolate beignets and other choices tempted us from the dessert menu, but alas, we did NOT order dessert as we were too stuffed to manage it.

Less pretentious (and less cutesy) than Pub & Kitchen - this is not a gastro-pub - it's simple bar food with a fresh tasting twist.

I live walking distance so I'll be back for sure!

We went to Indonesia last night as part of the foodie group (Shout out to Foodie M!) of 31 people.  For $35 (including tax & tip - BYOB) per person we had an absolute banquet of food. 2 Diet Cokes we ordered in addition were less than $3.00.  Dang - I should brought some bubbly!

Our hosts (the owner and 2 attentive, hard working servers) treated us so well.  We had the entire private banquet room upstairs, and it was lovely, with fresh flowers on the long table, and ice water ready for us.

Our appetizers were balls of sticky rice stuffed with aromatic chicken, wrapped in a banana leaf.  (The banana leaf is used prevelantly in Javanese cookery).  I liked it, but it coulda used some dipping sauce.

Next we had a choice of soup - Chicken with coconut - different than Thai - and a little thinner - or an EXCELLENT Lamb soup.  The soup did have bones (lamb ribs) in it - so that turned a few people off - but I loved it - as the flavor was so tasty.  Lime leaves and lemon grass - and not at all "too hot" nor "too spicy".  I really, really enjoyed that soup.

After the appetizer and soup I already felt full, but I tried to pace myself (and failed) for the formidable feast.  Each couple was served a lazy susan with about 6-7 different dishes on it.  Large bowls of yellow aromatic rice (so delish) were placed on each table so we could all have as much rice as we liked.  (The rice had a faint jasmine tea aroma to it and was so sweet and wonderful. - Carbo loading at its best.)

The dishes on our lazy susan included a succulent and tender beef curry.  Now, I am not a curry person - but this was terrific.  A lovely "barbequed" chicken in a sweet red pepper sauce was fragrant and tasty.

All the meats were flake-tender.

I was not a big fan of the mackerel - again steamed with spices and wrapped in the ever-present banana leaf.  It tasted too fishy and cat-foodish for me.

The Udup-Udup - mixed vegetables with FRESH crispy bean sprouts and crunchy green cabbage was a good palate cleanser.

Fettucine-like strands of egg omelette were simply delicious as well.
Nasi goreng and Sate (yummy chicken sate) were on the platter, too.

Another stand out was the crisp, slightly sweet and calorie-laden corn & egg fritter.  Two of them were perched atop the center of the lazy susan and DH and I ate those right away while they were hot and perfect.

By now I was so full I could barely try the tempeh with shrimp and green beans (sounded better than it was) and Potato-meat croquettes (not my thing, but other people loved them).

Not one but 2 dessert courses followed.
Fried bananas - one of my favorites - were served with a small pitcher of syrup.  "They're not just for breakfast anymore"!  The batter evokes a french toast (sans cinnamon) taste.  They were a little thickly breaded (I am accostomed to Japanese Tempura bananas) for my liking - but I was so stuffed that I really didn't mind.

The final dessert was really. Well.

Weird.  It was a warm "soup" of sweet (slightly chalky) coconut milk, with pieces of (yummy) jackfruit), tapioca pearls, mung beans, shredded green jello (eeeew) and pieces of white bread.

Maybe it was because I was now too full to enjoy anything - but this type of dessert (take every tpical Javanese dessert item and put it in a bowl) would not ever be my cup of tea.  (Or soup - as the case may be.)

The best part of the evening was the terrific conversation and friendships made.  Foodie M.'s mom and sister sat near us - and that was terrific.
We also met another couple who were smart and funny and had been to Indonesia before (Though Balinese cuisine and easter Javanese are quite different.)

I would highly recommend trying Indonesia and supporting this wonderful local business.

A great time was had!

This outpost of Smashburger is infinitely better-run than the one near my home.
The red-shirted managers were serving the lunch crowd (Quite busy on a Friday) and very attentive.

I actually ordered the Kid's meal and the portion was just fine for me.
Glad to see this option.

Still, I wish they'd allow upgrades to sweet-potato and/or "smash" fries from "regular" fries.  The sweet potato fries (to me) are much tastier.

A calorie-bomb for sure - but if you stick to salads and get grilled (not fried) chicken or the (fairly decent) turkey burger you can get away with it once in a while.

Cute little place with a limited menu and a selection of Viso's partries.  We come here for cannoli when we are too lazy to drive to Viso's in Aston.  Friendly service and nice & clean inside.

Pleasant.

We have enjoyed coming to OOka for years now.  Whenever in Doylestown and we want sushi -it's where we go.  They offer alot of Americanized (fattening) non-traditional rolls, and the sashimi parfait (with strawberries).  Also some seared nigiri - one with foie gra which is a decadent treat.  I was not as impressed with the kitchen entrees - having tried the veggie yaki-udon which was bland.

My fiancee likes the chicken dishes, butusually we stick to sushi creaions here.

It can get crazy-crowded on weekends.

Better - much better - but still very heavy-handed with the Olive oil on nearly every dish.
The burrata of the day ($16 was truly outstanding - served with paper thin slices of speck and roasted peppers and beets (purple and gold).  Gorgeous and delicious.

The table-side filleted whole branzino (enough for 2 to share at $36) was perfectly cooked and served with roasted veggies (terrific) and potatoes.

A side of broccoli-rabe was textbook - but again - drowning in garlic and olive oil.  

Service was perfection.  Decor is beautiful.
Love this place.

Even on a PACKED Saturday night my 9 year old & I had a terrific time at Ruby's.  We opted to sit at the counter rather than wait for a table and watch the plethora of fries & burgers being whisked away.

El kiddo had an "Orange 50/50" milk shake and a fried seafood platter (so healthy, i know!).  She even likes the coleslaw here.

Not gourmet, not fancy - but good family fun.

Surprisingly good service on such a busy, busy night.

Love these guys!  The name-sake ravioli is delicious and affordable - usually frozen and many varietys.  Great tortellini, too - meat or cheese (I love the meat).  Great hoagies and sandwiches.  SHARP Provolone.

The real deal - straight from sou-philly.  Oh - and they support the Mummers - so go to P&S!
believe it or not we had a sandwich tray CATERED from Barrels (to a swanky law firm no less) and the food was Di-VINE!!!!!  The chicken cutlet with rabe was perfection on a roll.

OK, I gotta update my review of OOKA, as we just had an incredibly GOOD night here.  Our first time coming with our 4 (nearly 5) year old and sitting at the teppanyaki grill. (No, it's not Hibachi.  It's teppanyaki, thank you very much.)

We made a same day reservation for 6:45 PM on a Saturday (tonight, actually) and were accomodated and got in just before it started to get packed & crazy - as Saturday nights at Ooka D-town are known to be.

Service was truly excellent.  The waiter and teppanyaki chef were both extra accomodating to the little princess - the chef even made an extra Onion Volcano during the teppanyaki grilling portion.  She was mesmerized.

The place had an unusually high number of kids and families - I guess I never noticed this before because every ogther time we have come sans bebe (thank god!) and usually we sit in the sushi dining room or at the sushi bar.

Once again I ordered the Seared striped bass with foie gras suishi and once again it was melt-in-your-mouth delicious.  Next time 2 orders!  It's that good. 

Toro was a bit of a disappointment (but at only $7.00 I had to try one).  I also ordered 2 pieces of Maguro ($5.50 for 2 pieces vs. $7 for ONE toro - they said "O" but I bet it was "Chu".)  Anyhow the toro was a little gristley and the Maguro was perfect.  Next time I'll be skipping the toro and loading up on Hamachi (perfect and ocean-fresh) and the aforementioned seared bass with foie.

DD & DH had teppanyaki meals -which are never a HG for me.  DD loved her shrimp, noodles and rice.  She wouldn't touch the veggies.
Hubby ate his chicken meal but said (as predicted) it was too heavy on the soy and the margarine (yes they slather that grill in grease).

Bringing kids?  The teppanyaki will keep them very entertained.  Want a better meal?  Order sushi based dishes.  (Just my opinion.)

Go Ooka.  What a change from the Domino's pizza and ultra-conservative Christian Bookshop that used to inhabit the space.

Nearly 5 stars - the food is 5 star for sure!
I had a huge platter (ate about hald) of Chilaquiles with 2 delicious fried eggs over top.  ($8.00 for lunch)

Wonderful service and delicious, authentic selections - like Chiles en Nogado (the real McCoy with Pomegranate seeds - in season!)

My friends had the Burrito Maya and it looked great (I had one small bite - and it was!).

What a find!

Let me preface this by saying (again) that I am really not a steak 'n hoagie kinda gal. But Lee's makes a darned good one (both steaks and hoagies are good here - and believe me, they are 2 entirely different species in the sandwich kingdom).

I have had a very good chicken cheese steak with shrooms here within the last 5 years.  Prior to that - probably 12-15 years ago (yes really) I used to have roast beef hoagies with lettuce, tomato, no oil, no onion.  (But this is probably too far back to comment on.

Decor is sparse - and functional.  Fairly clean - BIG PLUS and I would feel just fine taking friends or my 3 year old to grab a meal here.  Take out is even better.  (wink, wink)

I honestly don't remember if they sell Beer. I highly doubt it given PA's restrictive liquor laws.

While i can't speak for the other baked goods (and I have had many at the RTM location), the traditional cheese and chocolate chip filled-to-order cannoli at the Comcast outpost of termini Bros. are TERRIFIC.

Very crisp cannoli shells and a thick, but not gelatinous, creamy ricotta based filling.  Soooooo good.

Went here on the recommendation on a friend and was NOT disappointed.  Came in early (5:30) on a Saturday night and it was still slow.  By the time we left at 6:40 it was filling up.

Even though most people probably go to the Outback Steakhouse next door - I would say to come here instead.  Great service and solid Thai dishes.

We only oredered one item off of the Japanese section of the menu - a Tuna/Avocado Salad - served in the avocado shell.  YUM! ($12).

My fave - classic Tom Kha - was heavy on the lime juice but still delish.
Steamed Thai dumplings were light and luscious.  (Will definitely get these again.)
Drunken Noodles were a tongue-tingling treat.  Perfectly cooked noodles - tender not mushy.

LOVE IT.

Good service.

Why not a 5?  They neeed to CLEAN the fabric ceiling drapes - they are loaded with dust.  Eew. Also the Thai iced coffee was not great - and I usually love this.  There's was clyingly sweet and the coffee was so bitter. ($3) Won;t get it again.

Meal for two (no alcohol, I think it's BYO).

Note:  I have now been back 2 or 3 more times and the dishes are all good - sushi is fresh and Thai food is great.

I finally got a chance to try Estia - I walk by it all the time.
We were part of a LARGE private event held in the huge downstairs ballroom.  You could easily have a wedding here (150 people or less is probably best - we had 187 in our gfroup and the room holds 180 max. We were crammed in like sardines).

The tables were pre-set with salad (romaine with dill dressing - quite tasty), bread, pita and hummus (yum!).

Entrees and dessert platters were served family style.  Food was delicious and excellent - especially the Branzino over "greek-style" roasted veggies - potato, zucchini, eggplant, peppers) - all were terrific.

Pasta alla Greca is an inexpensive way to feed a crowd.  Tasty - but too light on the spinach, IMHO.

Deseert of a very nutty baklava (good but not the best I've tried) and a moist bordering on wet-with-syrup walnut cake.  People either loved it or hated it - I enjoyed it, but it is WET and very, very, cloyingly sweet.

Note:  They have a private wine room for dining up tpo 14 people.
I sense a party in my future at ESTIA!

Great for pre/post theatre, too.  They know how to get you in and out.

Chambers offers a terrific brunch, and great lunches and dinners.  Our family has gone there for years.

At brunch time (which can get really crowded so go early) they have an omlette station and a very nice (and cute) young man pouring waffle batter.  It's a bit of a wait but so worth it for a fresh hot waffle that you may top with fruit or whipped topping (alas it was NOT real whipped cream).

Yum-my!

For dinner, my mom favors the petite filet which is cooked to order, and the strawberry salad.  I adore the pear salad with goat cheese and a sweet poppyseed vinaigrette.  Add a heavenly grilled, sliced duck breast from just $4.00 more.  (I add it every time!)  I have dreams about the "duck salad".  That duck breast was crispy-skinned and yet medium rare inside and soooooo tasty.

Chambers is a marvelous place to go and it's right in the heart of Doylestown.

And, Matt - the Chef - is a doll!

Our 8 year old just LOVES ruby's.  Everything from the train that runs around the track on the ceiling to the red & white decor and uniforms and the "old fashioned" feel.

It's really 3 star food - salads, burgers and fried chicken and fish - but it's a fun place to take the kiddo. Kiddo always gets a (small) milkshake. I usually splurge on a vanilla diet coke ($2.89 - but free refills).

She also loves the huge gumball machine in the front.

Service is OK - can be great if you get a good server.  (Lots of teens and college-aged folks working here).

Not bad!

3 words:

Butter Bean Honey.

'Nuff said.
Go there now!

If you can get a seat at the nearly-always-packed- counter, Profi's is a welcome respite from the bustle of RTM.  I enjoy the fruit filled crepes and get mine with banana & strawberries - no "glop".  I do not like saucey crepes and Prfi always makes mine to order.  (They do a great job - and I really enjoy the crepes themselves which are lightly sweet.

I have never tried their savory crepes - but I'm always tempted to.
I am glad they are in the Market.

We ate a lovely lunch here today.  Service was slow, but pleasant.  Our server, Lisa did a terrific job with our party of 8 and everything was served as ordered.

I had the Chadwick's chopped salad (minus the bacon, dresssing on the side) which was terrific.  And for $10.95 it is gargantuan.  Topped with a warm, sliced, grilled chicken breast.  The interesting addition?  Shaved white chocolate.  YUMMY.

CInnamon sweet potato fries were cold, but still addictive.

A nice place - very upscale "country club" decor.

The only complaint?  Very slow service.  Slow for a hostess to greet us, and slow to order and get our food.  Don't come here if you are in a rush.  Thankfully we weren't or I'd have to give it 2-3 stars.

Food is GREAT!
