A fine selection of meat and poultry products and friendly, attentive service, but boy do you pay for that.

I wound up getting 2 lbs of fresh chicken breast for 3.99 per lb. I also tried their steak tips.

They offer good looking prepared foods, salads, sandwiches and there us a cheerful place to eat there if you wish.

We need more butcher's so I will support them, but I pay less for my duck breasts direct from D'artagnan. So glad you carry D'artagnan, though.

I'll be back!

Chambers offers a terrific brunch, and great lunches and dinners.  Our family has gone there for years.

At brunch time (which can get really crowded so go early) they have an omlette station and a very nice (and cute) young man pouring waffle batter.  It's a bit of a wait but so worth it for a fresh hot waffle that you may top with fruit or whipped topping (alas it was NOT real whipped cream).

Yum-my!

For dinner, my mom favors the petite filet which is cooked to order, and the strawberry salad.  I adore the pear salad with goat cheese and a sweet poppyseed vinaigrette.  Add a heavenly grilled, sliced duck breast from just $4.00 more.  (I add it every time!)  I have dreams about the "duck salad".  That duck breast was crispy-skinned and yet medium rare inside and soooooo tasty.

Chambers is a marvelous place to go and it's right in the heart of Doylestown.

I can't believe D-towners have not yet tried this place.

Wow!!! Such good values on certain things -like Globe artichokes, Haas Avocados and mini pumpkins.  (I won't ever buy pumpkins at Linvilla again!)

I am so glad I found this place - and starting at $20 they make fruit baskets - great for holiday gifts.

Oh - and it's mobbed.  I went on a Thursday at 4:30 and the parking lot was nearly full - I can only imagine what weekends must be like.

Hadn't been here in a while and I was long over due.
Delicious made to order crepes.

Prices have been raised since 2009 - but that's to be expected.
Very good customer service from the gal up front and the man making the crepes.  (Choice of white or wheat flour - NICE!)

Love me a good quick crepe.

Expensive - but you get what you pay for - decadent treats at Miel.  Not a place for an "everyday coffee" - although some will beg to differ - but I love the mini-sized cakes and tarte tatin that is old-school elegant in the true (vraiment) French tradition.

Bonne chance!

Better.

I have been back a few times - and they HAD the items I needed (and my very commonly prescribed medications in stock).

Friendly service.
CLEAN store that never seems crowded (at least when I go.).

Plenty of parking.

Smile Cafe has better food that Erawan which is why I am giving it 4 stars to Erawan's 3.  But I happen to like the new Thai Chef & Noodle Fusion place that just opened on Chesnut even better.  The service here is quick and friendly and the place is as big as a minute.  

Seriously - it is very tiny in here and somewhat cramped.  It's like you are eating in someones apartment,  Lunch prices are reasonable.

Let me preface this by saying that I am a "verge-atarian" (On the verge of vegetarianism) and even I can appreciate the carnivorours, juicy joy that is Five Guys.  The "little" burger is big enuf por moi and I load that bun with all the complimentary veggies.  (All the toppings are free - other than cheese and bacon - which are not even neccessary - given the amount of artery clogging fat already present in aforementioned juicy burgers.)

I have also never gotten the fries - as after eating the burger my grease quotient has been met for the day.

But I do occaisionally indulge in a single little burger from five guys.  It is worth the 8-10 minute cooked to order wait.

Yes.

It's worth it.

NYAJ had surprisingly decent bar-food.
Our bartender, Abraham was attentive and friendly.  The $5 Fresh Fruit sangria tasted like fruit punch and was so cloyingly sweet that i did not finish it.
$5 guacamole and chips (chips were huge and freshly made) had bland guacamole.  Tasty - but not at all spicy.  More like Avocado dip.

The best was the entree - a Pappardelle loaded with asparagus and kale in a garlicky pesto sauce.  Very tasty and the grilled chicken on top (you can get this dish sans chix) was juicy and perfectly grilled.

I'd come back here - but with Harvest across the street (which I much prefer - but it's more expensive) I won't be rushing back.

All in all this place is a BIG improvement from the Outback Steakhouse that was in this spot years ago.

Little Italy delivered oodles of pies (Plain cheese, mushroom and veggie) for a large block party I attended.  Very good pizza.  "Class" neapolitan pies - not too thin (not pizza-on-a-cracker) not too thick.

Very good.

This family-owned and run outpost of Lee's is a good, quick option for hoagies, cheese-steaks (try as a wrap) and sandwiches of all sorts.  They also make wings, fries and a few appetizer/snack items.  Chips and soda, of course.

Healthy?  No.
Well run?  yes!  The owner/owner's wife is a doll and has been running the place for 17 years.

Walls are covered with sports memorabilia.

Love me some Lee's from time to time.

Peter Mac does it again - with great assistance from Joey - they have opened a catering/take out place with terrific Italian (and American) sandwiches, platters and catering.

We sorely need this.

Do not miss the smoked wings and ribs - fan-flipping-tastic.

We attended the Grand Opening event on 10/1 and all the food was terrific - especially the sides of roasted red peppers and brocolli rabe.

I am thrilled and delighted that La Porta and now La Porta Via (next door) are here!

Had not been to Firebirds in quite a while, maybe years?  Lunch with a corporate party of 4 was very good with stellar service (it was not crowded at 12:15 on a summer Friday) and solid food.

Deviled eggs with a candied bacon garnish were indulgent and spicy. (The fresh jalapeno was strong and kicking.)

My entree was a simple grilled salmon, served with broccoli and mixed veggies (zucchini, carrots, onions, sweet red peppers and yes, more broccoli).  The fish was done just to my liking. 

Colleagues dishes all looked great.

I would definitely come here again and it us great for a corporate event or even a date night.  

Great Lunch! Kudos to Jessica and Phil who served us.

Beautiful restaurant with ambiance and a young, good-looking, friendly staff. Bar is gorgeous and colorful.
Our group of 3 enjoyed the $23 Three-course feast and $80 kids meal- 1/2 a rack of ribs.

I can see how this is likely "formula" cooking and college kids are running the joint - but they are running it well.  We enjoyed the crab cake app and grilled salmon.  Many items are way too salty (smoke flavoring??) though.

Good stuff and strong drinks, especially the ($10) double black diamond martini (akin to the Flyin' Hawaiian) which is basically pineapple juice infused vodka.

I love coming here for an old-school memory.  I first came here with my parents as a child and had shirley temples and Chicken Cordon Bleu in the '80's.  I have been to luncheons here and weddings - but to simply come and dine off the regular menu is the best.

Great service and conutry-style decor. (Could use a bit of a re-fresh)

I will bring my daughter now!  Shirley Temples all around!

Oh - and it is beautiful for a Christmas or Winter dinner - lots of twinkly lights all around,

OK, now that I have tried Crepe Maker in 30th Street station I am even more impressed with Profis.  The crepe batter here is far suprior - much more flavorful.  I am lovin' the crepes at Profi's.

It's hard to get a seat - but once I snag I stool you best believe I am ordering!!!

Honeygrow is now on my heavy rotation for work lunches and I try to stick to salads and limit the dressing and carbs.  Service is good and ingredients are fresh and tasty.  Lots of choices.

Improved performance on new app.  YAY!!!!

Shout out to Steve who works the lunch rush - a very pleasant man.

I hadn't been to Smile Cafe in a long time - and got the Pad Thai lunch special as take out (it's a small place).  Very good value - a small (iceberg) salad, two little dumplings and a nice serving of Pad Thai with 2  (yes only 2) Shrimp in it.

Hey - for $8.50 including tax - who cares?

Tasty and cheap.

Excellent choices but yes it gets pricey - especially the honey bar which is over $6 to $9 depending on all the fruit you add.

The stirfries are tasty but sodium and sugars (carbs) are high unless you opt for lettuce cups (no noodles, no grains).

I will be back.  And bringing more money.

Very clean store and friendly staff.  I spent over $11 - no beverage for a beef-based stirfry.  (At Qdoba next door it's about $8.50)
Trying to watch carbs so avoid the "sweet soy" - loaded with sugar.
Tried the (spring only) pesto.  Very good.  I wonder how many carbs that one has?

I am not a pretzel lover - but man, these are good.  I eve like the pretzel dogs here.  The dough is just perfect.  The salt ratio is right on!  Chewy but not tough, wheaty flavor and FRESH out of the oven.

Tip:  only come to this brnach - Philly Soft Pretzel Factory has alot of chain branches - this one (as grubby as it seems) is best.

Karla's has been a New Hope institution for eh ver (well maybe not quite as long as Jon & Peters) and it draws out the tourists a-plenty.  The food is good and it has typical New Hope prices.

The drinks are also mixed well and they offer specials - summertime grets a little crazy - but a winter weekday is the best time to go.

Great mixed drinks.

5 star service from Sally and Ronnie (a 24 year veteran server - she is amazing) and 4 or 5 star food - but the noise level was deafening - and we dined at 5:30 PM (by 6:15 the place was packed).

Elegant (albeit pricey) cocktails at the bar (I had a Strawberry Basil martini that was delicious) followed by an elegant dinner, complete with an enormous ($130) chilled seafood display that was a meal in itself.  Crab Cocktail here is a treat!

Dinners included filet mignon, ribeye (overly sauced, for my taste - but the guys liked it), lobster roll (very good but not better than Cape Cod) and crab/lobster stuffed "sachetti" pasta.

Enjoyable desserts like fried donuts, creme brulee (yum) and buttermilk ice cream (very good).

Kudos to the chef and servers.

Stopped at this Wawa at 10 or 11 PM on our way home from Hershey with a sleeping kid in the car.  Ran in and out.  No issues.

Snacks, drinks, smoke and coffee.
Well - no smokes in front of the kiddo.  Ever.

Wawa.  There when u need them.
Grateful.

Delectable donuts holes - laden with sugar and oil.  Caloric BOMBS of goodness (or badness).
So melt-in-your-mouth crack-dictive.

Food is great - margaritas (at least the $2.99 house special Lime Marg on Wednesdays ) are awful.

Great nopalitas salad (Marinated cactus leaves) - fresh veggies and a light dressing.
Shrimp Ceviche was HUGE and tasty.

Serive at the beginning was great - but the server messed something up with my dining pal's credit card and we waited, and waited, and waited to pay our bill.

Nevertheless, we'll be back.

Muy delicioso!

This is a BIG, clean, super Wawa - with a gas station and tons of convenience food items, smokes, cold drinks, magazines, a deli counter with touch-screen sandwich ordering and lots of things now common to most Wawas.

It's convenient for the guys at the office, so we come here often.
I usually get a Jr. or Shorti Hoagie.

Whoop-dee-doo!

A great source for nuts, candies, spices, teas and roasted coffees.  A fantastic find in Ardmore.  Walnuts, pecans, macadamia, almonds, all types of flavored/shelled pistachios. 

So great.

Um, but not if you have a nut allergy. 

Love.

While the food (I get the breakfast scrambler - no tots) is just OK, Austin behind the counter is a gem.  He has personality to spare and is so charming.  A big shout out to Austin.

Also - if they offered soup (tomato soup here is good) in the AM (yes, really) I would get it.

Another fabulous outpost of El Limon (I have also been to the Conshy and Fraser locations) and it is just great.  BIG-a$$ burritos (wet or dry or in a bowl), delicious Al Pastor, free margaritas if you dine in, friendly service, fresh guac.

LOVE me some El Limon.

Do not miss their Al Pastor - just enough pineapple and succulent pork.
So good.

I was in this area for an 8 AM appointment and desperately needed coffee.
Target (Starbucks) does not open until 8, but Ruby's is open at 7 AM and does a VERY nice breakfast.

I had coffee and a very nice "veggie" eggs Benedict with spinach, tomato and avocado.  The hollandaise likely came from a mix - but i asked for it on the side and it was pretty good anyway.

So after tax and tip - I blew $15 on breakfast but it was delicious and a welcome respite.

Excellent service - the place was nearly empty - just me and one other table at 7:05 AM!

This is a large, clean, well-run starbuck on the corner of Marsh & Silverside roads in Wilmington.  We usually stop by in the morning - and even at the height of the AM rush, the lines move quickly.

Fourbucks, Charbucks, whatever yoiu call it - it's nice tohave one around when you need it.

Especially in the Culinary wasteland of North Wilmington.

This is THE Starbucks - smack dab in the middle of New Hope's tourist district.  Right over the bridge from Lambertville.

And while, I tuly believe that "friends don let friends drink Charbucks" (or "Fourbucks") this one is not bad.  Nice customer service and the line (if there is one) moves quickly.

As Fourbucks goes - this is one of the better locations.

4 stars for the food and 5 for the entertainment.  Maria herself - who had a cooking show on PBS for years - was in the kitchen when we came here for Mew year's Eve 2006.  (I was wondering why it took me so long to yelp her.)

We had a very enjoyable evening.  The best part were the home-made meatballs and the (keep it on the d.l.) tray of limoncello and cordials passed after the meal.

My only regret is that we have not yet returned.
We will!
You can get them now at the Media farmers market!  Whoo-hoo.  REAL Canele!

OK, so it's still MEHxican - and the salsa and chips taste like tostios and old el paso, but the servers now know us - and we now know EXACTLY what to order.  The servers and cooks here work HARD and are very gracious to us.

I always get the #75 burrito with chicken instead of beef (I don't like the shredded beef here for whatever reason), guac on the side.

Fresh brewed iced tea.

I'm set for my "usual" business lunch - and most days we can get in, out and back to work in an hour.

We'll be back - because we have few other choices.

Still very pricey - but great new digs and dining options.
We'll be back!

The Pizza Wagon comes to my office in Chestrbrook, PA about once a month or so.  (Kinda wish it was more as it is a culinary wasteland around these parts).  For $10 you can pick from 5-6 pies and for one person they are huge.  I think the $10 also includes a drink - can of soda or bottle of water).

I like the Spinach pie (it is supposed to be white but i asked for sauce and they did it!).

This is our go-to Wawa all summer long whenever we are at the Ridley Park Swim Club - you can walk there!  My kid and assorted friends load up on snacks, candy and cold beverages.

A g-d-send,

I love whole paycheck, er, i mean Whole Foods.
I stopped in when the store was very empty (YAY!) and the breakfast buffet was still up - so no hot foods for me.

I got a thing of Whole Foods Guacamole ($4.99 for a small) - so delicious, a $7 tub of mixed berries (yikes) and a $12.95 genji sushi salmon plate.  

Funny how just a few tasty snacks add up here.

All were terrific.

After we get our pet supplies at Tobin's (Feed Store), it's so tempting to stop for a breakfast sandwich or lunchtime feast.

Classic food served by friendly(mostly female) staff.
Cute place and good, simple, "safe" food.

Stopped in here to do a small shop (about $50 worth) because it was on the way home and I really loathe the local Acme.  This Giant is pretty nice - I vacillate between 3 and 4 stars.

Giant - for me - is my go-to for non organic food and select household goods.  I usually like Whole Paycheck (aka Whole Foods) and Trader Joes - but for low cost staples - I gotta trust Giant.

We'll be back.

I dither back and forth between 3 & 4 stars based on each experience.  This time a gal-pal and I dined in and shared Chips & Pico (Not enough pico for that big pile of chips) for $7 and 2 orders of 2 tacos.  2 shrimp and 2 pork.

The tacos were fresh tasting and the pork ones were LOADED with pork and avocado spread. 
The shrimp tacos were very skimpy with 2 small shrimp in each taco.  Delicious crema and radishes.

Next time?  I am getting extra pcio and skipping the shrimp tacos.

Having been to the original shake shack and a satellite NYC location before, I knew what I was getting when I walked in (and out) of the Philly Shake Shack a few weeks back.  12:30 is NOT the time to go.

So today I was wiser and went at 11:40 AM.
Perfect.  No line.  2 minute wait for a single burger with lettuce and tomato (no Shack-mayo for me) and a Half 'n Half made with STRAWBERRY lemonade.  I also got a taste of the Red Velvet Custard.  It was uber-rich and loaded with cake pieces and cream cheese icing.  The taste was enough - I did not need to get a cup of that caloric-disaster.

Meanwhile, my burger was great (I also enjoy the burgers at 500 degrees and when I've got cash to burn, Village Whiskey).

And they don't call me the "Empress of the Arnold Palmer" for nothin'.  That half 'n half was just what I needed.

Counter lady (I can't remember her name) was lovely and the guy cleaning the tables on the floor was a doll.  Execllent service (prior to the thundering herd that arrives at noon).

Do not come here during peak times.
It's night and day.

Oh - and they were selling a $9 (NINE Dollar!!!) artisinal Brooklyn chocolate bar at the front counter.  Come ON!  It can't be THAT good????

I have been a big fan of Sushi Nami's Paoli location for lunches (and the occasional dinner) for a while so I was eager to try the Wayne Location on Route 30 not far from my office.

Yumi was there (she is usually in Paoli) and  the place is new - but has the exact same menu.  Lunch specials are still there and still great at $14.00 for the salmon lunch.  The pork dumpling soup is a great winter treat - hot and fresh with 3 pork gyoza and a bunch of veggies.

Love it here.
Will be back!

4 stars for the food.  I try to ignore the surroundings.  Great Duck.  And hands-down best steamed dumplings.  LOVE 'em.  Wonton Duck Soup can be a little greasy - but man, it's a tasty indulgence.

Oh - and watching my 4 year old scarf down 3 different types of dumplings was precious.  She sat at the counter like a pro.  She tried the shrimpdumplings, wonton (sans soup they are very tasty) and the steamed chicken dumplings.

Can't wait to take her back here.

3 star food - maybe 4 star if you order selectively.
I had a very nice salad (sans calorie bomb of fried tortilla bowl) with Avocado and shrimp.  Lovely.  Elote served on or off the cob with Chipotle mayo and Cotija cheese.

Friendly service, colorful decor and kid friendly.

Next time I am getting a margarita for sure! (And there WILL be a next time.)

We had a splendid late-summer/early fall meal "just the gals" at T's next door (The European Side - not the Italian side).  My duck salad which contained delicious macerated cherries and a slab (yes a huge slice/slab) of honey chevre (the "gateway drug" to all soft cheeses) was perfect.

An $8 side of Brussels sprouts was large enough for 3 to share and contained more bacon than should be legal.

Mussels (Moules Frite) come with fries (Frites) and 7 different sauces to choose from.  A classic Provencale was ordered.

The booze selections are many and varied.  Pick your fave.

Had a nice evening here - but had to beg for veggies instead of chips (trying to watch carbs) for the $7 pico 'n chips.  They eventually oblidges with delicious cucumber, celery and carrot sticks.  PERFECT!

I wish you'd offer veggies on the menu as a sub for chips - I'd be willing to pay $2 - $3 extra for it.

But man, that pico (avocado chunks in pico de gallo) is terrific.

Great service.

A lovely meal at Teresa's (not Next-Door - but we shall try that next - LOL).
All the pastas can be made with spaghetti squash - so I had Spag. Squash in a beet sauce with a blob of goat cheese/mascarpone.  So decadent.

Basic - but just about the BEST Caesar salad I have ever tasted  5 stars for the romaine, baby!

Too full for dessert but the coffee and iced teas were great - and wow, what a list of WHISKEYS!

El Vez gets 4 stars for the GUAC - not for the rest of the menu - which would get 3.

The guacamole hear really is tasty - although if you've tried the guac at Xochitl - which is made tableside with cotilja cheese fresh-ground to taste - WOWZA - but that's another review (check out Xochitl and Tequila's in Philly - regional Mex fare.)

Anyhow, back to El Vez which is filled-to-the-brim with Starr-kitsch.  Kitschy or not, this is a good place to get an over-priced fruity drink and schmooze with the yupsters.

I better go again before I turn 40 and get permanently banned from the joint!

This Acme (a larger one) is on my way to work so today I literally ran in and out at 7:20 AM for a quart of milk and box of instant oatmeal packets.

The place was nearly empty at that hour so it was no biggie.
Friendly cashier, too.

No issues and I know I'll be back.

Went for lunch with my 11 year old and we actually enjoyed it - but still there are flaws.
Rice is not the right texture. Too hard and crumbly. Hwever, the salmon sushi (nigiri) we ordered was fresh and tast.

The "rich man" roll ($13) is basically a souped-up spicy salmon roll topped with MORE salmon.  I got the 2 sauces (A sweet mango syrup/sauce and eel sauce) on the side which was a good move.

Kiddo got a rainbow roll sans "fake crab" kani stick.  She hates fake crab.  Smart kid.  $11.

"Regular" rolls are $5.25 - and for that I'd just as soon get 2 Alaskan rolls for less that the cost of the "rich man".  Dessert ($4.50) was an overly greasy tempura banana.  El kiddo devoured it.

A decent place but there are better places closer to Media and even better in Philly.

Great diner food at a reasonable price served by lifer staff in a neighborhood institution.  Can get SLAMMIN' crowded on weekends at brunch time.  I like to go for dinner and have breakfast for dinner at Zoto's.

Fun stuff!

4 -5 stars for the view alone.  They could serve old shoe leather (which some steaks kinda resemble) and it would still be a great ambience.  Meanwhile, as hard to believe as it is, Chart house is a CHAIN.  It is a such a nice place, though - and a great "special occaision" restaurant.

Just don't have a steak.  The salmon was excellent when I had it years ago.
Come to think of it the steaks I also had quite a long while ago - perhaps they have a better beef supplier now.

But anyhow, yes I do recommend the Chart House - especially for Mother's Day (Father's Day) and birthdays.  It is just a joy in Spring and Summer.

I heart Sephora - I liked it even better when they first started in the '90's and had even more brands (probably too many) and harder to find items.

Love it.

3.5 stars. - A decent breakfast place for the Diner Classics - and Eggs benedict with "hollandaise from a mix".  Big portions and OK prices.
Surprisingly decent hot coffee - maybe I lucked out with a fresh pot?

Overly made-up servers (can you say black eye liner at 10 AM)? wearing support hosiery.

Nostalgic - and a darn sight better than Country Squire (Blech.)

I am optimistic about Gavin's - an Argentine-owned Euro-style cafe, right near Taney Park and sorely needed.

The original Irish Bar (from years ago now serves as the coffee bar.

We had some cold drinks here yesterday and I got a home-made beef empanada that was so delicious.  The salad menu sounds great, too.

This is sorely needed in this area and I hope they will be successful.

Go, Gavin's!

This is now my go-to Saladworks near my job.
The ladies who run the lunch rush are so kind and friendly.

The salad is consistently good (fresh lettuce is a must for me) and I sometimes add on a cup of lobster bisque or Turkey Sausage/Kale soup on a cold day.

I come in about twice a month.

Kovacs doesn't look impressive from the outside, but the man who runs it is terrific and was very, very kind to my friend who used to walk here almost daily from his Media Station apartment.

A great place to grab snacks or a sandwich before catching a SEPTA train into Philly.

They also have grocery items, lottery tickets and COFFEE!

Kovacs' is a neighborhood institution.

Raw - the sushi & sake lunge from 12 & Sansom - opened a 2nd branch inside Boyd's Department store on the mezzanine level.

I just had lunch there today and for $13 it very well may be the only thing I can afford at Boyds!

Less of the snotty attitude, too.  Much quiter and more refined.
I had a yellowtail bento box and the sushi and all of the elements (miso, salad, gyoza, and spicy tuna tartare) were all top-notch.

I'll be back soon!

Chick-Fil-A Lima is very well run and has worked with my kid's elementary school many years now to organise fundraisers and family events.  There is a play area for the little ones, and even though I can not STAND the political views of the company's CEO, I was not able to boycott them, because they are the only fast food I will allow my child to consume.

The chicken sandwich (whole wheat bun available) is pretty good for a fast food option - and you can get fresh fruit instead of fries.

El kiddo also loves the mini cones (not so mini!) of "Ice Dream".

So glad we finally got to try La Porta - and especially the 5 star Caprese - one of the best I have had in a long, long while.  Home-made Mozz - so creamy; A drizzle of "the good stuff" - aged balsamic; red, ripe, roma tomatoes; basil chiffonade.  SUPERB.

The lasagna was so rich I almost could not eat it.  (Although others I know would swoon over this.)  An excellent meaty bolognese - but the creamy sauce on top was just too much.  Delicate house-made pasta sheets.  Topped with a fried egg that was, alas, oddly cooked (Thus precluding me from awarding LaPorta the fifth star).  The egg was, indeed, fried = the bottom was actually crispy and brown - the top?  Raw.  Not runny (which I like) but raw albumin over the yolk.  Slimy.  Not good.

Meanwhile the 2 pizzas our  table tried (Malfatta - neat! and a classic Margarita) were excellent.

Lots of love and care goes into this food and it shows.

LOVE IT and will return soon.  But I'll try other things (like the salads which sound great) that are not quite so rich and heavy.

Gorgeous bar area and a rustic older dining room, too.
Lizzy - our server - and a brand-spankin'-new bus boy were pleasant and friendly.

Good job, Peter!!!!!
Welcome to suburbia.

Fabulous service at the bar during Happy Hour from Paul and later Hailey.  $5 White Cosmos were terrific.  $7 mini tuna tartare was a tasty treat.   Skip the deviled eggs, the ones at Paramour are better.

A nice change of pace from my usual. I will be back!

I stopped at this Starbucks in a state of latte-emergency.
I desperately needed a caffeine pick me up and this location at 5:30 PM on a Friday was nearly empty so I got in and out quickly.

Staff was friendly and restrooms were clean (enough).

No issues.
Thankful they are here.

We had a marvelous first-time experience for lunch on a Wednesday at the Metro Diner on Concord Pike - just South of the PA state line.
Our server Eddie was terrific and later the manager, Isaac, came over to see how things were.  (Everything was great - believe it or not.)

One of us is vegetarian (not vegan so eggs are OK, this is not a vegan place - lots of eggs and dairy) and she had a veggie wrap (huge - took 1/2 home) with Avocado and the "usual" suspects but also with FRIED JALAPENOS - inside the wrap.  Wow.

I had a "trying to cut carbs" eggs Benedict so - no English muffin and plain steamed spinach instead of potatoes.  $13.29 (no tax, baby, we're in DE).

I am sorry others did not have a good experience, but honestly, we had a great lunch and I can't wait to return.  (That divided highway, though...)

I have always supported food coops, CSA's farmers markets, Natural food stores and the like, so I was delighted to find Weaver's way.

In amongst the crowded, cramped, narrow aisles - along with farm-fresh local produce (much in season - less in the winter) are other treats.  Honey.  Peanut Butter.  Fresh Eggs (with round deep yellow yolks), and a nice selection of snacks and prepared foods.

If I lived in the neighbordhood I'd be joining for sure!

Without Whole Foods and Trader Joe's I'd be sunk.
So, Whole Foods - I am be-whole-den to you.

High prices and all - what choice do I have?  My child must have chemical-free, persticide-free, herbicide-free non Genetically Modified organisms on which to feed.

That meat case is impressive!  As are the baked desserts.  The juice bar is a saviour - and sushi never hurts!

O, Whole Foods - how I love thee - though parking really sucks.
A least they'll validate the lot and save me a few bux.
Very good ice cream - not withstanding the long lines that are par for the course at the RTM - my 4 y.o. dd loves Bassett's and as an occaisional special treat we get her a small cone.

A-may-zing.
So good.  For $3.75 I got an excellent iced decaf latte.

Perfect.
Gorgeous setting, great service and smooth, rich-tasting coffee drinks.

YUM!

Returned to La Porta for 5 star food and service but oh  - so many flies!!!!
You need to do something about the black fly population inside and out on the patio (which is lovely, otherwise).

Tracey our server is terrific and the Caprese Salad (with August-ripened Heirloom tomatoes) was perfection and the house-made spinach gnocchi were terrific.

Can't wait to come back - but please get a bug zapper!

This has been my go-to Whole Foods for a while now - sometime I will trek to Glen Mills or Plymouth Meeting.  I know the layout of this WF better than others so I can get in, get what I want, and leave relatively quickly. 

Also if you go after 7:30 PM or before 8 AM it is much less crowded.
Avoid lunch hour and the after-work rush.  (Although - lots of these yoga-pants ladies look like they don't work.  Must be nice.)

Chi-Chi Devon location with prices and attitudes to match.  (Attitudes from the patrons - not the hipster staffers.)

I was treated to lunch here today by a coworker and had the salmon lovers ($13) special.  6 pieces of sashimi (I asked for all sashimi as I am trying to cut carbs and they complied.) and a [mild] spicy salmon roll.

Also came with choice of miso soup or iceberg salad.  I got the salad with the ginger/sweet (carb) dressing on the side.

Service from Rebecca was excellent and the place was not crowded on a random Tuesday at 12:15 PM.

I will return when my sushi/Asian craving hits next.

Dee M.  said it best - and I agree.
Cheap gas just over the DE border, plus all the Wawa usuals.

This section of the city is a great mix of old, historic Americana and new, hip trendy boutiques, galleries and restaurants.  It's lots of fun on First Friday - and good for families in the spring & summer, too.

A nice place to visit and live.

OK - I am upgrading corner bakery cafe for their excellent work with catering.
No, the food isn't all that wonderful - but it's better than lots of others we've had.  The cavatappi pasta salad (side) is great and the breads for the sandwiches are fresh and not sogged-out.

Nice presentation and better yet - they arrive on time and don't cost alot.  (Hot pasta meal for 8-10 is $90.)

For whatever reason the food seemed better this time as we watched our child's figure skating competition.
We had lunch AND dinner here - including a decent cheesesteak quesadilla.

Wings were overcooked and dried out.
French Onion Soup is not tasty - had a weird acidic component.

But - the Fish Sandwich ($8) with fries was good.

Counter service and a full bar.
Friendly staff.

It's been YEARS since my kid - now a teen - has begged for fro-yo but we found an ancient Sweet Frog gift card and it still is valid so - YAY.
Cookies and Cream for me and my vegan teen (They had 3 vegan options) had the dole-whip Pineapple (no dairy).

A plethora of candy toppings and fruits.

$6 for both of us (small cups).

Delicious 5 star hoagies - so good (and I don;t even like hoagies).
Chicken Suprimo, Bada-Bing, Nonna's Veggie and the new Meatball Sub are all winners.

Alas, one star off for the super-high price.  My wrap  was 8.99 plus $1 extra for subbing eggplant for red peppers.

2 subs and a small mac salad was almost $20.  Ee-gads!

Meanwhile, our kid likes it here, too.

A lovely - albeit pricey - lunch at La Porta.  Anything they make with their house-made mozzarella (or scamorzza or burratta) is amazing.  If you are a fan of fresh mozz - you must try it here.

We had the special salad of the day - a summery mix of lettuce, fresh burratta (decadent) red and golden beets and sliced peaches.  LOVELY.  The blackberry balsamic was perfect for it.  I added shrimp to mine (which made the $13 salad go to $20).

I really do enjoy the food here.

The best diner in my area.
A bit pricey - my salmon salad was $15.95 - ouch.

Breakfasts come in around $10 for omelettes or pancakes with toppings/fillings/sides.

My kid had a gyro platter with onion rings subbed in (upcharge!) for fries.

Soda was $2.45.

Bill for 4 people for lunch was $70.  Yikes.

5 star food and 3 or 4 star service for this update on Peter Mac's delightful La Porta on route 352 in Media.

Ate here for the first time in over a year and the late spring/summer menu is wonderful with crisp salads, pizzas, pasta and rich, flavorful entrees.

My pork cutlet stack with fresh mozz, spinach and peppers was so delicious and a generous portion.  I took about 1/3 home and enjoyed it the next day.

The bar was hoppin' on a Monday night and my Cranberry Moscow Mule was served icy-cold in the requisite copper mug.  Deeeee-licious.

Can't wait to come back.

Wow!  Swanky renovations in 2017 include a REAl in-store Starbucks (Yes, you can use your Starbucks app or card) and re-done ladies room (THANK YOU).

Nice new floors in the deli and prepared food areas.

Still a great spot to get some cheap sushi for lunch.
I come in a few times each week on my way to work.

Returned to Teresa's on a balmy, busy, summer Thursday night for a delightful plate of eggplant, spinach and cheese.  So good.

I always like the food here - both sides are good but different.
Lots of alcoholic choices, too!

I had a fine experience my first time at this Saladworks.  There were 3 women working the counter during the lunch rush on a random Thursday.  There was a short-to-medium line and it moved quickly.   They offered about 8 soups (my old Saladworks offers only 3 or 4) and I got a Cobb Salad with Turkey instead of chicken and Brussels Sprouts instead of Bleu Cheese.  

No issues.

Dining room was medium-crowded (we got a table and were not packed in).  

Did not use rest room.
Plenty of parking.

I will be back.

I can't believe I have NEVER been to a Bonefish Grill before, but I have not.
And I will be back.

A little pricey for what it is (Chain - owned by Outback), but very tasty.
Nice atmosphere.
Great for my daughter's friend's 12th birthday dinner.

For happy hour (4 - 6 PM) the $5 drinks are a great value.
The blueberry lemon drop martini is like candy in a glass.  Lovely.

Also enjoyed the Cobb salad with shrimp.

Good service from Jess.

We'll be back!

I was turned off after my last lunch here so I did not return for a while but now, I am glad I did.  The Thai Basil stir fry (I chose chicken but you can get beef, shrimp or veggie or tofu) is delicious and inexpensive as a lunch special (back page of menu).

I also had some sashimi but stuck to salmon and tuna which were fine.  The escolar, snapper and hamachi here taste slightly "fishy" to me - and hamachi especially can taste "off" if it is not uber-fresh.

Lots of pre-frozen product in that sushi case, but hey, it's Wilmington, DE - not NYC or LA or Tokyo.

This is a good option for pan-Asian near my office.

My first experience at Yummy sushi was actually quite, well, yummy.

It was a busy lunch rush, so I sat at the sushi bar and ordered the $13 sashimi lunch special with a choice of salad or miso soup.

Sashimi, to me, is the litmus test for any sushi bar.  Yummy passed!  My plate had 3 slices of 4 fish and all were fresh and good, no fishy odor. Tuna, salmon, and 2 white fish I am guessing were sea bass or fluke. It was not yellowtail. It was not escolar (fake white tuna).

Salad was the standard iceberg with ginger dressing that many places serves. Also fresh, crispy and good.  

I will be back as this place is steps away from my office and relatively cheap.

Yay!

It seems much like the Vic's in Philly - but different owners.  Similar menu - and best of all TUNA DUMPLINGS - you gotta try these - so delicious.

I also got a sashimi sampler (app) with 2 pieces of tuna, salmon and yellowtail.

All were fresh and delicious.

$12 minimum for credit cards.

It will be hard to write a captivating review without re-stating many of the sentiments already expressed below, but I shall try...

Last night we went to Buddakan Philadelphia (there are now 3 locations) which is celebrating 11 years in operation.  Surprisingly, even after living in Philly for nearly 4 years and trying tons of restaurants, this was our first visit.  Years back we visited and peeked inside to see the amazing Golden Buddha and the waterfall wall fountain. I had read the menu many times on the website - so I felt like I knew what to expect.  (N.B. they will be CHANGING the drink menu and dinner menu in a few weeks - finally.)

Decor and Service were easily 5 star, but there are too many small details overlooked for me to give Buddakan that elusive fifth star.  (As Starr restaurants go, this is pretty typical in that there is some over-hyping going on - but for a restaurant like this to survive and thrive for 11 years - an eternity for a restaurant - they are doing alot of things right!)

We started with $11 - $13 drinks at the nearly empty  bar (from 5:30 - 6:10 on a recession summer Thursday - it got crowded around 8).  The enlightenment was too strong with tequila for me to drink, so I sent it back and tried the tickled pink which was cloyingly sweet and the Malibu rum was not a great idea.  Oh well.  Meanwhile the ASIAN MOJITO was well-balanced, with freshly muddled mint, a hint of ginger and delicious.  (NOTE:  THey are changing the drink menu in a few weeks - many of these cocktails have been on the menu for years and it's all gonna change.)

Next the 3 of us sat at a great table on the main level (there is also a cute bar upstairs and more tables.).  One of us is a vegan and there are very few vegetarian options (and NO vegan apps! The edamame ravioli uses chicken stock)  He had vegetable fried rice (or could have had noodle dishes or the house salad.)  If you are a vegan - this is not a great place for you - unless you just want some drinks.

Everything is served family style with sharing plate s- which for us is great as we all like to share (execpt my vegan friend who, natch, would not eat the fish or duck).  Chicken Dumplings were a step up from the frozen gyoza we get at our favorite sushi joints.  Tasty for sure - but not worth $9.  A scallion pancake topped with shredded shortrib meat was enjoyed by DH but way too salty for my tastes.  A miss at $12.

Entrees were much better.  The miso black cod, that was so famous, lived up to most of the hype.  Perfectly cooked.  I subbed a DELICIOUS eggplant in lieu of the wasabi mashed potatoes.  That eggplant was GREAT - reminiscent of Kung Pao - it was studded with Pine Nuts.  YUM!

DH ordered the thinly sliced duck breast - a bit too well done for me - but I like my duck with a bit more QUACK left in it.  The accompanying Corn Spoon Bread was AWESOME.

Desserts were by far worth the extra calories.  3 people shared the chocolate Bento box ($14 with chocolatey-good 6 selections - easily feeds 3 by itself).  We also got the hot, fried, five-spice & sugar donuts.  Now this is how I wished the churros at Xochitl could be!  WOW!  Five slightly greasy, hot donuts with 3 delectable dipping sauces (well - the cream cheese was too thick to really be called a sauce) including a rich ganache.

A cup of green tea and a Millenum Cocktail (rimmed with Tang - what is with Starr and his obsession with Tang in cocktails???) capped off a lovely early summer dinner.

Great for special occaisions - and the tab was $180 or so including tip which really isn't bad.  Expensive but not obscene (we spent more on dinner for 2 at Morimoto!!).

I will be back - but maybe just for drinks and dessert!  (HA, HA!)
\
Oh - and I must mention our bartender Adele (She's there Thursdays thru Sundays) and our 5 year veteran server Meg who was charming and spot-on with our orders.

Oh - and if you want to (we didn't) they will valet park your car for $18.00).

So close to 5 stars - but not quite.

Very good service from a friendly Covid-19 compliant staff and tasty burgers - 2 thinly-smashed patties.

I had a lettuce wrapped cheese burger with fried mushrooms, lettuce and tomato and wee bit of M2O sauce (Ketchup plus mayo).

The owners were from Kosovo - interesting.

I would definitely come here again.
Better than Smashburger comparable to 5 guys with more choices (salads, smoothies and shakes).

Loving M2O so far.

A new fro-yo place (akin to those in Philly - pay per ounce).
Lots of toppings.

My 8 year old loved the pink and green decor.

Christian-owned FROG - Firmly Rely on G-d.

Whatever.

Still lovin' it.  Brought a crowd of 5 here for bao, har gow, noodles and more.
Try the stir-fried green beans. - So good.

Inexpensive and fun.

A fantastic breakfast - real banana pancakes with both bananas on top and IN THE BATTER which is what i like.  Alas, fake syrup - I would gladly pay an upcharge for REAL maple syrup.  Yes, we know how much it costs!

Very nice service from our old-school server and the male host was efficient.

The "Springfield Benedict" (get the faux-hollandaise on the side) is delicious with spinach and bacon instead of canadian bacon.  HUGE and filling.

This large Wawa is nearly always hoppin' - especially the morning, lunch and after-work rushes (avoid).

The coffee lines in the AM are almost comical - you'd think they were giving it away.
Service is quick, efficient and depending on the gal or guy you get - can be friendly and funny (The young man I saw last night when I stopped in for a quart of milk - $1.59 - was so funny.).

Wawa is a very convenient thing!!!

Love the food here - burritos, quesadillas (traditional or Tex-Mex) and the Camarones Platter ($14.95) with Mojo de Ajo is a garlicky dream.

Service is down to earth and you may need to be a bit patient with the staff to get what you want.

Don't miss the house-made salsa verde - with fresh tomatillos.

Can't wait to try their Al Pastor next.

We had amazingly good service from Alexa (and a shout out to Jeff the manager) at my ladies night Happy Hour (6 of us) at the bar area.

While Happy Hour prices (which are a great value - $5 drinks and $6 apps) only last from 4 - 6 PM we stayed until after 8:30 and a few of us enjoyed (Shrimp) Cobb salads (always terrific), Bang Bang Shrimp, Shrimp Tacos and Lobster bisque from the "regular" menu.

There is also a lovely server named Sara who treats me so well any time I come in with family or friends.

Yes, Bonefish is a chain, but I really like this location of it.
Don't miss the brunch menu - very good also.

Very friendly and helpful young guys running the place.
tasty selection of pre-cooked (softshell crabs, crab cakes) fried items that you can reheat.

Good for takeout (they have 2-3 small tables if you want to eat there.).

Lots of frozen seafood soups (Chowders and Bisques).

I'll be back to try the Salmon Teriyaki Rice Bowl. ($8.99).

This Maggiano's (Cherry Hill Mall) is much better than the one in Philly.
Cleaner, better service and for whatever reason the food tasted better to me. (Even though it's the SAME menu.)

Pasta dishes are a great value at lunch - but I ask them to go lightly on the sauce(s) - the garlic load is pretty intense.

A good place for a "family meal" - no, it's not earth-shattering - and it can feel a bit "cafeteria-like" as it gets loud and the acoustics are pretty awful, but we take the 5 year old here and she loves it.

Chima is the kind of dining where you much have a clearly mapped-out strategy before dropping $60 plus on lunch (or $80 ish for dinner).

Two words...
Meat. Sweats.

Two more words...
Food. Coma.

Some rookie mistakes to avoid:
1.  Skip the little cheese/bread - yes, they are delicious but they will fll you up.
2.  Go very, very easy on the salad bar - BE SELECTIVE.  
3.  Ask, ask, ask your server to bring you the cuts you most want.  Once they do get 2 slices of those you love the most (for me the Lamb (chops not leg) and Angus Beef (Classic) were the best picks.
4.  Allow adequate time - at least 2 hours.  This is not a place to go if you are in a time crunch.

Yes, I would go back here - especially for a celebratory meal, but I will also ask for a side of LIPITOR.

P.S.  NOT vegan friendly (Um, duh!).

I got takeout (delivered, actually) when I needed a quick lunch one day at my firm's Cherry Hill office.  It was really very good.  Cindy's is located in a nearby strip mall,  They have "the usual" Chinese food and a few Japanese selections as well.

I would definitely order again.  I never got a chance to dine-in so I can't speak to the decor or service.

I've had some great meals at Pag's (the main restaurant has the best food of the 3 - wine bar, pizza cafe and restaurant.).  We shared a delightful Mozzarella di Buffula (the REAL McCOy - and priced to match) with red ripe summer tomatoes.

The garden area outside is a great summer night's treat.

In winter - try the (a bit heavy) house made pastas.  Tagliatelle was perfectly al dente hear and served in asugo di burro (Butter sauce - I think I spelled that wrong - sorry.).  Fresh shaved parmesan over the top.

Yes, the prices are steep - and a bit "too -too" for people like my parents - we prefere Luberto's which is more "homey" and alot cheaper - but for a romantic date or a birthday celebration?  In D-town I love Pag's.

Oh - and I came here with my daughter when she was just under 2 years old and they treated her really well - spaghetti and everything.

Back again and lovin' it!
Got a case of Blackberry Hint Water (10% of a case of anything), some $18 maple syrup, a pair of duck legs and tons of boutique yuppified frozen meals. Plus crispy-fresh bean sprouts, mini bell peppers and a $2.17 single humongous mandarin orange called a Sumo.  Lady at check out was a doll - Kenishon??  I know I got that wrong.

I'm stocked up!

The Manhattan Bagel in the Chesterbrook Shopping Center is my go-to these days for coffee on my way to my new job.  Service is quick and friendly and they all know my boss there - she is there every morning.

There are usually 5 pre-brewed selections - Decaf, House Blend, Hazelnut and 2 others (today is was Dark Roast and Pumpkin Spice).

Bagels are good too - but I need to lay off of those for a while.
This is a much cleaner location than the one in Center City.

OK - again I vacillate between 4 & 5 stars.

Decor and Service were top-notch.
Cocktails are delicious - albeit pricey - with freshly "crafted" ingredents like smoked cinnamon and house-made bitters.

For "healthy" food - many of the dishes were oily or had fried components or incorporated bread.  The cauliflower was fried and oily.  Potatoes and root veggies?  Fried.

The best bite of the night?  Parsnip spread - on white toast (odd that so many things are served on bread??

Come here in the summer for fresher better choices.  Winter veggie fans, rejoice - you can get parsnips, turnips, potatoes, radishes and a plethora of beet varieties.

I wish I could remember our french female servers name - she was patient and kind.
The "bus folks" were workin' it, too!

Love it here.

This is for the Halal Cart with Green & Yellow Signage parked on the corner of 20 & Market (South East - not the Falafel Man on the NE Corner).

$5 got me a huge rice platter with 1/2 chicken cubes and 1/2 gyro (salty but not horribly so) meat cubes, iceberg "salad" with 2 slivers of tomato and a pile of rice.  "White" or "Hot" sauce (or both).

INCLUDED a soda or water - not bad for $5!

Please note that I am NOT an Indian food lvoer - in fact - I generally don't eat it.  I can't deal with all the cardamom and curry and fenugreek and such.  I will be generous and give it 4 stars - but my conscious is screaming "3 stars".  I reall would like to see them succeed.  The Callohwhill area needs new businesses.

But 3 of us had a very lovely dinner there last week.  The place was nearly empty - but you can see that the decor (which is lovely) is brand new.  The ladies room was clean and marble-ized and nice.

Service was very attentive - some might argue a bit much - as he asked my husband if he'd like to order any bread 3 times.  (I ordered a poori - with Shrimp as an appetizer which was fabulous in all its deep-fried glory).  My husband did not want any bread.

Really.

Our friend who dined with us is FROM India - and he ordered a Chana (can't remember) appetizer which we all enjoyed but it was served on a bed of shredded ice berg lettuce - which would NEVER happen in India.

The Lamb Curry was tender and mildly spiced.
The rice was excellent - as well cooked basmati can be.

I would go back - but again - I am just not an Indian Food lover.  For Philly - this seems like the best of the lot.  For betetr Indo-Pak food try Queens NY or North Jersey.

Oh - our dessert (Galub - can't spell it) fried cheese balls, was syrupy and friend and just as I rememberfrom the Dipavali festivals I used to attend.  Yum-my.

Oh - it's BYOB - so BRING something. (We didn't and wished that we had.)


Dinner for the 3 of us was $60 even including tax & tip.  Really not bad.

It's a 3 star place but I am giving 4 stars for the extremely well-executed holiday party we threw here for our party of 9.

Granted, the food was family style - which meant it all came out promptly - but it was actually good (Chicken Parm, Chicken Marsala and a baked ziti with meat in it).  Best of all were the huge platters of (very good) tira-misu.

Chrissy our server brought cappuccino and beverages right away.

Considering how busy and crowded the restaurant was (and the place is huge) with every holiday party under the sun - groups from 6 to 36 at long tables - the service was AMAZINGLY good.

For a faux-talian chain.
Stopped in on a DEAD Sunday night at 30th Street Station and needed good coffee.  Old Nelson Hooked me up with a REAL La Colombe Latte for under $2.00.  SCORE!!!!

Well, it doesn't feel "New"
And the hoagies are NOT "Tiny"
But the 6 inch Chicken Cheese Steak I got was great - and the friendly young lad at the counter was personable AND good looking.

I don;t eat hoagies often - but when I want one I'll be skipping Wawa and heading straight here!

Plus they deliver (even out my way in the boonies) for $1.50 charge - $10 minimum.

I will try the pizza soon and let you know...
So far great for steaks/hoagies.

Take out ONLY (not where to sit - not even a card table).

Stopped in last night (walked in did not use drive thru) and the place was empty at 8 PM.
I actually thought they were closing, but they were just cleaning.

Very nice shift manager and 2 female baristas.

Got my kid a Peach Iced Green tea Lemonade and I got a Grande Caramel Macchiatto.
Both were just perfect.

No issues.

Lots of fun to poke around the old-time-feeling Booth's Corner's Farmers Market.  Not as much produce and food as I expected - and alot more gift and knick-knack shops - even a LAWYER has a stall here.

I especially like Esh's Eggs and Stoltfuz meats and produce.

Only open Friday - Sunday.
Wish they had more days open.

Had GREAT service when refilling a prescription here early today at 7:55 AM.
Pharmacy Manager (female) is very sweet and entered my new insurance information and got me my medication promptly.

No issues.

Located in a Shopping Center in Plumsteadville - of all places - this place has decent NY style Neapolitan pies.  Get one fresh made - as the pre-made slices can vary in quality depending on when they were made - but you CAN'T go wrong with a fresh baked pie from here.  Cheesy and not too greasy.  Good stuff.

A nice array of whole and fileted fish, frozen crustaceans, battered ready-to-fry items and smoked salmons.  You can also have a seafood meal prepared to eat at the market - but I have never done this.  I have bought shrimp and Halibut here both were fine. (Fresh and not fishy smelling.)

Not bad.  A homey little place for pizza and sandwiches. Beverly, the sassy waitress will bring you your order and a sunny smile.

The Red veggie pie (no sauce) was delicious and at $8.50 for a small was perfect for 2 of us to share.

Once time for lunch I had a tasty tuna melt. 

The dining room can get very crowded (and loud) at lunch time so come right at or before 12 noon to get a seat.

Oh - and that home-made Lemon Crunch cake looked mighty tempting.  Maybe next time...

This Starbucks just moved "down the street" from the Paoli train Station (where there was NO PARKING) to here - where the old Burger King used to be.  

I have not yet gone into the store, but I used the convenient drive-thru today and got in & out quickly.

Glad there is parking!

Excellent choice for a casual lunch, and on a nice day you can sit outside.  I got the "Breeders combo" (The restaurant is dog themed) with a 1/2 size Cobb Salad and a cup of delicious lobster bisque (not much lobster in it, but still tasty).  Next time I will try the mushroom bisque.

They have alotta bisques - and chicken noodle.

The sandwich my friend got look great, too.

Can't wait to come back.
Hannah (Cashier and later in dining area) was a doll.
Still lovin' it here.

Some of the best popcorn, bulk-roasted in-shell peanuts and chocolate covered treats (pretzels, graham crackers) in Philly.

Such a fun little place crammed with snackies.

4 stars for $6.99 Taco Tuesdays - I usually get the fish tacos (You get 2 tacos and a side of Beans).  You have to get it to go.

I also get a (pricey) $2.50 Strawberry Ginger Iced Tea (They Used Premium Steap teas and I love them).

Fast service - especially if you call your order in and then go pick it up.

I've had Old City iced coffee many, many times at the RTM location.  I like that they keep the milk IN THE FRIDGE (not sitting out in pitchers) and pour you as much or as little as you wish (soy, skim, whole or half 'n half).

Thanks for NOT being a Charbucks.

Great coffee and a fun place to just hang out.
And a pleasant older gentleman and a nice young lady barrista to boot!

I love the coffee at Old City Coffee.  I will continue to come here.

Catered hoagie trays for a corporate lunch - and it was fine.  Ham, turkey and roastbeef on seeded rolls, lettuce, tomatoes and cheap white American cheese.  (Mayo pre-spread on the turkey hoagie-piece I ate.)

Served with may small bags of Herr's chips.

No issues.

5 star service from Vera and 3.5 star (heavy, carbo-loaded, caloric) food.
A gal-pal and I shared the whopping-huge "Marco's Meal" and took home most of it.

With the $42.95 (We paid $52.95 - as we each opted for upgraded entrée choices) you get EITHER an appetizer (we got the $10.95 stuffed mushrooms - very good.) OR 2 small side salads.

Then you pick 2 entrees (Classic pastas only.  If you want "special pastas" or a chicken dish - pay $5 more).  

Then you get 2 "classic" pastas (cold and pre-prepared/wrapped that morning) to take home.

And ANY dessert you want to share (we got the $7.95 hunk-o'-cheesecake).

But VERA (serving here for about a decade!) is the best part of all.  She is hilarious and warm and wonderful.

Is the food "haute"?  "Fine cuisine"?  Heck, no.  This is a chain.
The digs are cafeteria-meets-checkered table cloth "Faux-talian".

But we had fun - and left with enough for 2 more meals.

Easily!

P.S.  The pricey cappuccinos here are actually GREAT.  Get a cappuccino in lieu of dessert.  Good stuff!

Always crowded at peak lunch times - especially when its raining.

Loaded with lawyers and other corporate types, the $16 grilled fish is wonderful for a healthier choice.  They also have burgers and a wonderful veggie burger wrap.

Nice addition to the area - and way more upscale than the Saladworks that used to be in this space.
Glad it's here - but it is expensive - you are paying for convenience.  Also the deli (Dietz & Watson) looked nice - but just didn't appeal.

This is a great (small) asset to the neighborhood.  Selling cases of beer, soda and ice.

Believe me - when you need it -it's great to have someone who sells ice.

Bring cash.

We had a corporate pizza lunch for about 40 people and brought in Anthony's salad and 15 pies including a very good Margarita pie, meatballs with roasted peppers and of course pepperoni.

They also had a cauliflower crust pie which disappeared so quickly that I did not get a chance to try it.

While I am not a big pizza fan, Anthony's is quite good. A nice alternative to the ubiquitous sandwich trays we usually get for catered lunches.

Good job!

Brand-spankin'-new Whole Paycheck in Glen Mills.
So happy to have access to my beloved Hint Water, Frozen meals, Fresh fabulous produce, bakery items, olives and so much more.

I love Whole Foods - prices be darned -sometimes I just gotta blow $70 on maple syrup, water and fruit.
My husband will freak, but hey - we gotta eat.
It's not like I'm buying meth.

Anyhow - I am grateful that a Whole Foods opened near us.  (I miss my branch in Center City.)

This location has been a coffee place, a somehthing else (I forget) and now it's Old Nelson - which sells a little bit of everything.  Cereal, coffee (La Colombe, even!) and breakfast foods, sandwiches at lunch, snacks, chips, beverages, paper goods (at a pricey premium - but convenient).

Glad they are here and hope they make it in this highish-rent ever changing location.

I've had 2, 3 and 4 star experiences at du Jour - but the food is always great.  The service (and crowds - especially on rainy lunch hours) can make or break the experience.

Today, however, the stars were all in alignment.

Perfect iced tea.
Delicious (grilled mahi) fish tacos
Speedy, friendly server

Hooray!

A bit more money that I usually like to soend at lunch - but perfect for business and much better food than Bistro St. tropez or the other places we are often forced to visit.

AVOID during peak times, if you can (12:10 PM - 1:45 PM is the height of the madness).  Get there at 11:50 AM and the place is EMPTY.

Very nice staff!
I popped in (famished) to the Chetserbrook Manhattan bagel and needed to get both breakfast AND lunch.

The Avocado BLT (Turkey Bacon) thin on whole wheat was delicious - and the added cucumber to it upon my request.

The also sell FIJI water for $1.79.  (My fave - and yes I can tell a difference.)

The iced coffee was very strong and a little burnt tasting - but suffice nonetheless.

The staff were just so friendly and accomodating - I can't believe it.  I'll be back!

What a great place!  This is the "real deal" Italian Food, the way it is meant to be - Concetta is lovely and there is an abundance of great food.  Chicken picatta is perfect in its simplicity.  Veal (or chicken) Marsala is delicious.  Bruscetta, marinated carrots, roasted red peppers and what?  Cornbread!  (Yes, you read that right - cornbread in with the Italian bread.)

Loud and raucous bar area, but it lends to the jovial atmosphere.
Parking is a NIGHTMARE.

Otherwise 5 stars.

You gotta come to Pesto.

Two words.

Taco Tuesdays!

They now offer (carry out only) $6.99 Daily Specials - and on Tuesdays - you can get tacos.  I got the fish tacos.  For $7.45 with tax - this is a great lunch!!!

Call your order in and they'll have it ready and waiting.

Good food and GREAT service but the parking lot at lunchtime (mixed with the drive through line is an accident waiting to happen.  Treacherous.

Be very careful driving in and out of here.  So busy at lunch (Monday - Friday) you would think they were giving it away.

Beautiful architecture in a partially remodeled old building. Decent food and stellar service from Erin (our server) and Christine - at reception.

Food was just OK though and perhaps it was just that I ordered a salad.
A nice selection of Bigelow teas.

Great place to take a client.
Maggiano's catered a large company meal for the holidays and did a great job (in our office).  Food was hot and tasty and the dessert platter was surprisingly luxe for a chain catering/dining place.

3 star service (Danny is terrific but the food came out rather slowly and we were on lunch break)
4 star food - upscale "gastropub" type bar food.

I had been wanting to try Roots, and my group of 5 coworkers came for lunch - we only had an hour and lunch took easily 85 minutes.  Next time we will advise the staff that we are on a tighter time frame.

3 of the crew had burgers and they looked terrific with any toppings you could want - cheddar, bacon, fried (a little over cooked for my liking) egg.

I had the $10 lunch special of French Onion Soup ($6 on its own!) and a 1/2 sandwich (I chose the Chicken, Avocado and Pork Belly panini - yes, please!).  Both were scrumptious - albeit caloric.  Best of all?  The French Onion was not overly salted.  It was perfect.

I will return - but not on a day when I have a 1 PM meeting!
Great selection of beers - and a full bar ('natch!)

Tried K of T again - this time for lunch with my vegetarian, Indian friend.  We split an order of Chana Chat - a cold chick pea appetizer that is very good.  (Still served on the bed of iceberg.)

I had the same shrimp appetizer with a freshly fried poori - it is an appetizer but for me was perfect for lunch.  It came with 4 medium sized shrimp in a tomato based (tasy) sauce with onions and green peppers.  The sauce was so good on the poori (or over rice - I snagged a bit of my friends HUGE veggie biryani).

I have never been a big Indian food lover, but I can deal with the food here and find it very good.

I shop here.
I admit it.  I do.

And I love that they carry Hint Water and a select aisle of organic goodies that I know and love.  Decent prices - and never that crowded on evenings or off hours.  (Weekends can get hectic.)

I prefer it to Acme, but will also shop there.

This place is too high priced for an every day lunch (at least for me - maybe it's fine for the attorneys with expense accounts) but - but - BUT...

TACO TUESDAYS!  (Take out only) gives you the (normally $11) fish tacos (2) with a side of black beans - to go - for $6.99 - about 7.60 with tax. Guac, Sourcream and some sort of chipotle crema (I get them all on the side).

That, I can live with.

I love Taco tuesdays at Du Jour.

Oh - and today I got a free breakfast sandwich (regularly $4.95 served with a small coffee) for signing up for their loyalty card.  The sandwich was great!  (Not sure if I can afford spending $5 on breakfast normally, though.)

An Italian Deli with a good assortment of REAL Italian meats and cheeses, plus dried pasta and olive oils.

A few hard to find items, too - and tomato pie and DiBruno Brothers products (a few) to save you a schlep to Philly.

A little taste of Sou-filly in good old "white bread" Aston.

The lady and young man working there were very nice to my 9 year also - who devoured a 1/4 lb of macaroni salad right IN the store.

Kudos to Ellen G. for telling me about this place.  It's in a strip mall which is one of 3 strip malls on 452 and that all look similar. I had driven right by many times and never thought to go in.  Big mistake - you gotta try this place.

Let's hear it for my 1400th review on yelp.
Well - here it goes...

I just got back from a delicious lunch at Mixto with a good (vegetarian)  friend of mine.  After we each had a stiff, refreshing Classic Mojito each (and I was beginning to feel the buzz). Our friendly - if a little slow- waiter took our orders.

I had the Plato Vegetariano and my friend had a Salad with Avocado added on top.  Both were fresh and excellent.  I asked them to omit the tostones (green plantains) on my platter and sub maduros (sweet plantains) and thus I had an abundance of maduros to share with my friend.

I also gave him some of the Yucca, black beans and 1/4 of the SCRUMPTIOUS white corn arepa.

Wow.  I can not wait to go back.

Why not 5 stars?  A few reasons - in fact I was dithering between 3 & 4 stars.  Service here is, indeed, weird.  Since we arrive just before noon and the place was dead empty our service was better than it could have been - but I imagine at peak times this place is just NUTS.  They do kind-of check you out upon arrival.  The hostess was icy-cold.  Bus person (male) was very nice.

Also some might say that there are not enough vegetarian options - you basically can have salads or the plato - and that's it.  Fortunately I loved the plato - that arepa and the maduros were PERFECT.  It aslo had steamed (bland) veggies, yellow rice and a clump of mixed green salad in a tasty sweet dressing.

The mojios were STRONG and well muddled.  We went back again a few weeks later and had Vanilla and Pasion Fruit mojitos which were, indeed, sweeter but so delicious.  Oh - and the LARGE ($13) really is large.

I can't wait to return.  Again - I'll try for a non peak time. (The weekend madness here is just not for me.)

Oh - and they DON'T take reservations unless it's a party of 5 or more.

This is pretty much as "good as it gets" for a Fourbucks.
There is a drive through - but the walk-in service is even better with a spacious dining area - and super clean (brand new) facilities.

Excellent service and a full staff during the AM rush.

Plenty of parking.  Yay!!!

Finally got to try house - and while the food was very good beware - service is SLOW.  Do NOT come here in a hurry.  It took 35 minutes to be served entrees (My friend's cup of tomato soup arrived right away and we all stared and watched him eat it.)

I tasted 1 spoonful of the tomato soup - it was drizzled with olive oil (just a bit) and tasted good but as others have said - not mindblowing.

The eggs benedict was EGGs-xcellent.  The crab avocado one and the spinach/tomato one were both great.

It took me a long while to come here and now I will definitely be back.
But not when I am in a hurry - and I will not come at 12 - closer to 11:30 is better.  The place gets packed at lunchtime.

I've had Old City iced coffee many, many times at the RTM location - but it was not until today that I had the pleasure (and it really, really was a true pleasure) to sit and linger (we scored a great outdoor table - they only have 2) over a yummy iced coffee (my friend had a HUGE mug of cappucino with a hearty cap of yummy foam in it - PERFECT!) in Old City today.

We had such a great time - and spent nearly 2 hours just drinkin', smokin', yakin' and having a great afternoon.

Thanks for NOT being a Charbucks.

Great coffee and a fun place to just hang out.
And 2 nice, young, handsome barristas - eye candy never hurts.

Kafta Lamb Kebab over salad was great, Chicken Shwarma was too dry for me - but that said I did not load it down with sauces and tahini.  I did try the (very good) baba gahannouj and (not as good) garlic whip - on the side.  The Yogurt-Cucumber was very nice also.  Tomatoes and cukes were fresh.

I got in and out for $10.50 (including tax) and had a BIG whompin' bowl of Lebanese-inspired goodness.

I shall return.  The Qdoba of Middle Eastern.

I have purchased pretzels and pretzel-dogs at a few locations in Center City Philly and they are always fresh and tasty.

Carbo-loaded goodness.

The frozen custard is quite good.  I am not a water ice eater - but I love the custard at Rita's.  News flask their "Gelatti" is NOT Gelatto.  It is a bastardizion combo of water ice and custard.  Whatever.  It tastes good.

I truly love this place (looks like nothing in a strip mall but PLEASE seek this place out).  Parmagiano Reggiano for $14.99 per lb?  Amazing.  Viso's cannoli shells.  Cookies.  Pastries. Pasta.  Eggplant (grilled in store).  So many cured meats.

The REAL deal Italian - plus deli stuff.  Snagged a dozen eggs for 89 cent.  89 CENTS!!!!!  Cheaper than any supermarket.

Owner is a very kind man and related to Claudio's in South Philly.

WE NEED MORE PLACES like this!  We need a REAL butcher shop.  Any takers?

Stopped in to inquire about wheatgrass - and they DO carry it.
Will be back later this week to get some.

Update:  Got a shot of wheat grass for $1.99 yesterday - EXCELLENT.
I will be back several times per week, budget permitting.

Friendly service - place was nearly empty at 12:45 PM on a Monday.

Visited El Gran Rodeo with a friend and we sat in the bar area.
Enjoyed our Drinks (Mojito was perfect) and Hot Queso app.

Delicious burrito and chimichanga.

So great.

What a great spot for Mexican - and in a strip mall, no less.
Our excellent server (kinda looked like the guy from Entourage on TV) got my friend and I in and out of there quickly during a weekday lunch.

Oh - and they serve not only chips and salsa - but a spicy creamy ranch-like dip, too.  Good stuff.

Great lunch specials and reasonably priced.

Can't wait to try it again!

This place is so cute, it's PRECIOUS.  Everything from the cutesy sayings about their cash-only policy, to the old-fashioned cash register that rings up your order (manned by a very cute man dressed in white with a white paper soda-jerk hat!).

This place is a gem.  A true taste of nostalgia with home-made ice-cream and old-time soda fountain treats.  You can even get a NY style egg cream.

I would definitely come here.  It is a like a modern day trip down memory lane.  (And yummy, too.)

But bring the cash!  You'll need it.

3.5 stars is probably more accurate - but I am rounding up to 4 because my husband enjoyed it (he says it's better than Alma de Cuba - I disagree) and they were very accomodating to our 7 year old on a bustling Friday night.

Alma de Cuba is also great for its bar and party vibe.  My $9 Classic Mojito was perfect - not too strong (but if you like a strong drink you might not agree).

Vaca Frita, Ropa Vieja, Maduros, Chicken Empanada (a little small) and Classic Bean Beans & Rice were all they way "they are supposed to be".  Excellent Food, a bit high priced for cuban.

Better than Mixto, not quite as good (nor as pricey/trendy/hoity-toity) as Alma de Cuba (IMHO).

Go and enjoy.

Ryan - our server was cordial and attentive.  A great guy!

Many thanks to Alma de Cuba for participating in Friends Select School's Dining with Friends program.  We hope many people will come here!

So happy to have found this place - and for lunch ($7.95 Bun or Broken Rice Plates) oit is a steal.  Delicious Wonton Soup and Bun (Rice Vermicelli) bowls.
At dinner the carpaccio appetizer ($7.95) and  DELUXE Bun - with pork, chicken, meatballs (grilled to perfection and so juicy) and spring roll is super filling at $10.95.

Perfect Summer rolls.
Wonderful service from lovely ladies.

We'll be back - and I hope soon.

I like Grand Rodeo - mysterious "ranch dressing" white sauce and ketchup-y salsa and all.  It's great for families with or without kids.  Service (Kudos to Ricardo) was terrific even on a jam-packed (20 minute wait) Saturday night.

Love it here.

I have now been to 3 of the 5 (or is it 6) El Limon locations and I have just two words to say:

Al Pastor.

Seriously.  I have dreams about it.

Brand-new CFA serving up all your favorites with a cheerful "My Pleasure".
Closed Sundays.

Double-laned drive thru.

Always busy but so well managed.

A great place to pick up authentic Mexican products - and produce.
Plus fresh baked pastries and breads, canned goods like beans and chiles en adobada.

Nopales.
Chiles.
Frijoles.

Everything you need.

Soooooo close to 5 stars - and definitely 5 star service from Jack today for a leisurely, late lunch (L.L.L.) including that fantastic "power green" soup.  I just love it.  (Does contain dairy so not vegan - and very rich with cream and parmesan cheese thus negating the veggies.)

You gotta try that soup.

So delicious.

Still terrific and now some brand new digs!
Went to Gran Rodeo at the new location (down "the block" from the old building) twice now.  Much more space and a bigger, nicer bar area.

Food was great - cheese dip (with chips) never disappoints and shrimp fajitas and Chili Colorado were both tasty.  Pineapple Mojito (I asked for it light on the pineapple so it would not be too sweet) was spot-on!!!

Service was good but our one server was a bit grumpy
Bartender was friendly and funny and the lovely 2 hostess-ladies are so sweet whenever we come.

Love me some Gran Rodeo.

My review from 2 years ago still stands - service is slow but everything is cooked to order and tastes great.  The "green soup" - a hot soup with kale, broccoli and other greens, garnished with Parmesan, was delightful (special) and once again, I got the crab eggs Benedict.  Fan-flipping-tastic.  Amanda our server was terrific, too.

It's worth the wait (and there usually is one on weekends) so bring friends to chat with or a book or magazine and settle it for a leisurely brunch, lunch or breakfast at house.

We love it.

Fluctuates between 3 & 4 stars - our service happened to be wonderful - the food is always the same.  Reliable, good, not mind blowing - but the shrimp and beef filled items are very nice.  Our 11 year old just LOVES it here.  Guacamole is very bland - but made fresh.

Salsa tastes more like watery picante sauce.

Not a holy grail but OK for east-coast suburban.  For better Mexican try Dos Gringos in Media.

My kid and all her friends LOVE it here.
Especially the Burrito California with steak or shrimp (extra charge).

Well stocked Russian and Eastern European market with a vast selection of treats, snacks, candies, dairy, meat and prepared foods.

Really great.

Stick with salads, skip the overpriced drinks and you'll be ok.  The herb ranch dressing is actually fresh tasting.  I never get pizza here. 

Service by Ciara was very good.

Fantastic service for our pre-arranged buffet luncheon of 27 people by Jackie, Kaylie and the team.  Mustard Crusted Pork loin, Stuffed mushrooms, penne with chicken, Caesar Salad and rolls.

Parfaits for dessert.

Wonderful place for an old-school (bring your grandparents) luncheon.

This Acme has beer & wine (a pretty decent selection, too) available.  They also have a sushi section, next to the deli and hot foods bars.

Crowded on weekends - but a great place to get everything you need in this area of Ridley.
